Kratom has helped me manage my plantar fascitis and arthritis pain for the past 4 years. Before I discovered this miracle, I was prescribed Norco for my pain which quickly became habit forming and made everyday life miserable for me and my family. A doctor friend of mine asked me to research Kratom and give it a try.

It has proven to be a life saver for me. There is no cognitive impairment at all and keeps my pain at a tolerable level without having to take any prescription painkillers, I can enjoy life again! I have experienced absolutely no negative effects whatsoever.....zero. 

This remarkable plant has been a true blessing to me. I can't fathom why it would be categorized with dangerous, highly abused drugs. Please keep kratom available so others can benefit from this miracle plant.

sincerely,
Ric Henderson

documents.commentText:
I personally support an adults right to sovereignty over his or her consciousness.  I feel we all have the right to put anything we want into our body as long as we are fully informed on the dangers.  

That said, I am appalled that a plant that grows out of the ground, that helps people get over opiate addiction could be banned.  We have a problem.  Good people are becoming heroin addicts because of prescription pain killers.  We all know it but no one wants to have a dialog about it.  And now there is a plant that can help with that.  A plant that has been around forever.  A plant that was used as a supplement dating back to the 70s and should be protected by law as such.  

I don't want to believe it, but it's hard for me to think there aren't people in the DEA being influenced by prescription drug companies in this matter.  We are not beholden to you.  You are there to serve us and protect us.  So please prove me wrong.  I assume you are all good people in the DEA and you are working in the interest of the public to keep them safe.  Prescription pain killers are destroying our country but are deemed to be safe for the public.  Thousands of good people die every year on these drugs.  So they are not safe.  If there were a few overdoses a year on Kratom (I have yet to hear of a single verified OD that didn't involve other drugs too) but all in all, it helped thousands of addicts get off opiates, well then it seems like a no brainer to me.  

Kratom is the greater good no matter how you look at it. Do all the testing you want.  It's only saving lives.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,   I am close to begging you, with much respect,  to PLEASE withhold from making kratom a controlled substance.  It is a wonderful plant with so much promise to help people with a multitude of problems from drug addiction to sleep issues to pain control.  There is so much to be studied with this natural substance. I am a nurse, and I have used kratom for 3 years.  I drink the tea to control the long standing pain of a lower back problem . I used to be on opioid medications and found myself groggy and worse.. . becoming addicted!  As a nurse I knew the signs and knew I had to stop.  I found out about kratom during an internet search of natural pain remedies.  I tried it and found exactly what I needed, good pain relief without the side effects.  And the best thing.....it wasn't addictive! I can go for weeks without drinking the tea when I'm not having pain and that sure beats the way it was with opiates, I found myself wanting/needing to take them even when I was not in pain.
I happen the a Christian, and Genesis tells me that "God created every plant and herb for the benefit of man".  Please don't take away this God given plant!  I will always have chronic back problems, I desperately don't want to go back to opiates!  I can continue to work and be a productive member of society when my pain is relieved by kratom alone.  People have used it for millennia without harm!  It's so hard to feel that we live in this awesome country and yet sometimes it seems as if when we find something good and helpful, the government wants to take it away!  Millions of us depend on the aid of this plant which keeps us from unhealthy other options.  I know all of you there are educated and intelligent and want what's best for the good of the people......that's why you have your position.  So PLEASE hear us, and have compassion, please don't take away this plant that helps so many yet harms none.  
Thank you for hearing me, for hearing all of us who have taken the time to write to you,
Respectfully yours,
Anonymous

documents.commentText:
Dear Regulators:

I am writing to you today about an organic herb that is the ground leaf of a tree in the same family as coffee. The media has recently begun portraying this safe herbal tea as some kind of "new" heroin or cocaine, or even a hallucinogen, which couldn't be further from the truth. And we all know about the 'hasty' ban that was narrowly avoided. Kratom should be viewed as an important tool in the solution to the opiate/opioid epidemic, not just another green plant for government agencies to vilify for profit.  Kratom has a 2000-year history of safe, responsible use as a detox from opium and alternative to dangerous drugs such as opium and heroin which is easily verified. The Botanical Education Alliance website (botanical-education.org) and Transnational Institute (TNI.org) have extensive medical and scientific papers available showing both its efficacy and almost foolproof safety profile.  Ithas greatly enhanced the chances of opiate addicts to achieve permanent recovery for the same period of time, inexpensively and unofficially. During the last 15 years it has become a staple of many successful Narcotics Anonymous participants, boosting long term sobriety rates by preventing PAWS relapses.

There is no respiratory depression associated with Kratom, an established scientific fact, making it impossible to overdose, since one simply upchucks a larger than necessary amount. There hasneverbeen a death associated with use of Kratom leaf alone --compare that with any prescription opiate/opioid, much less street drugs.

I worked for a time as a legislative aid, so I understand that lawmakers and regulators have many demands on their time and sometimes only have time to scan the lobbyist statements before voting on some issues.Don't let that be the case with Kratom.

You wanted a silver bullet for the opiate crisis? --here it is use it!

Many thousands, or more, mature American citizens have found kratom to be a safer alternative to opioids or western medicines' "solutions" and an entirely new lease on life without any of the harms or side effects associated with either street drugs or the tightrope of prescription substitutes.

The only connection that Kratom (mitragyna speciosa) has with opiates is its ability to safely block withdrawal symptoms of street drugs like heroin or dangerous Rx opiates/opioids and provide a safe alternative for pain management and/or mood support. It does not produce a "high" that users will chase, and is ineffective as a a recreational drug. It is actually quite subtle. Other than an absence of pain, no one would notice its effects any more than an espresso coffee. The rest is media hype and misinformation by mislead anti-drug groups and pharmaceutical companies who have noticed a drop in their revenues from the highly-addictive opiate/opioid Rx medications that are wreaking havoc on our society.

Thousands of older adults have been spared the horrid effects of prescription drug abuse by using this relatively harmless dietary supplement as a simple tea. If a ban on Kratom becomes law, responsible adult Americans will no longer be free to avoid the snare of chronic opiate dependence.Leave Americans a choice, don't let the DEA become the drug pushers!

Allow the many adult, responsible users of this herbal tea to educate you, and you will likely come to the same conclusion as the legislators in most States, that an age restriction of 18+ or 21+ is more than enough "protection" for consumers of this rather harmless herbal tea.

Thank you for allowing common sense to rule this issue rather than media hysteria and misinformation. I realize the war on drugs is always a high political priority, but don't shoot yourselves in the foot. Americans will benefit from your good sense. Good health to you.

John Hilger
Penacook, NH 03303
highwaterz2@gmail.com

documents.commentText: I have a BS and MS in engineering, have a long history of academic research, and I've tried Kratom on several occasions. It's hilarious to think this silly plant should be made illegal. It barely does anything in terms of psychoactive properties. Cough syrup can get you more "stoned" than kratom, and it's ridiculous to think our government plans to lock people in cages for using this thing that grows naturally to help with heroin and opiate addiction, alcohol withdrawal, smoking cessation, and chronic pain. With so many potential benefits to society, zero recorded deaths resulting from its use (I looked into the claims of 10 or so deaths over the course of almost as many years and there is no evidence that unequivocally concludes kratom was the cause of death...the claims are utterly unfounded). In an era in which people are waking up to the terrible collateral damage to society that results from making widely used substances illegal (e.g. cannabis, which accounts for the vast majority of non-violent offenders locked up in America today, which is a country that locks up more of its citizens than any other country by far--1%!) it's ludicrous to insensibly make plants with illegal that a vast array of people are clearly benefiting from, and which appears to produce a far greater benefit to society at large and humanity as a whole than it produces consequences (the biggest consequence of kratom's existence would be its illegality and potential to get people thrown in cages for its possession and consumption).

documents.commentText:
Regarding DEA Docket# DEA-442W Mitragynine proposed rule, I am strongly opposed to the scheduling of this natural herb
which is related to the coffee plant. The statistics which the DEA put forth are grossly misleading. I have occasionally used 
herbal kratom during the past three years. It provides a mild analgesic effect which helps me to function normally with clinical-
ly diagnosed osteo-arthritis of the knees and hip. I do not use any over the counter analgesics because of adverse risks and 
side effects. Tylenol is a good example of too risky and dangerous. Tylenol causes irreversible liver damage and has killed
numerous people. It is known as the drug of choice for suicide, as all emergency room doctors well know. Acetaminaphen
doesn't even work very well. It causes uncomfortable sensations and a feeling of unwellness, not unlike poisoning, yet is still
the most popular and recommended and remains OTC even though PROVEN REPEATEDLY LETHAL.
I could rail against all of the others (naproxen, aspirin, ibuprofen) with similar strong arguments as to their deficiencies.
I am a strong believer in the use of unadulterated, non-synthesized, natural products. I have found no adverse side effects
with the use of kratom leaf. In fact, if it were to be compared to oxycodone, there are some notable differences, in which
kratom has distinct advantages. There is clinical study evidence that shows kratom does not cause constipation, which can
be a major problem with oxy use. There is clinical study evidence that indicates kratom does not cause respiratory depress-
ion. Respiratory depression with oxy use is a major problem. Empirically, with three years of occasional use, I can definitely
say that I have experienced NO adverse side effects. Kratom has helped me greatly to maintain a very active work and
active personal life not otherwise available to me. Do not regulate and/or schedule kratom.

Why is alcohol and ridiculously addictive painkillers legal (that have killed countless people) while natural safe alternatives like marijuana and kratom being made illegal?  This is absolute hypocrisy.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

              In 2012 I started using marijuana for many medicinal reasons. Marijuana has helped me a lot and also got me through very tough times. Through out the years my obsession became more and more. I started abusing marijuana every day for many years. It had become a huge problem for me. Between 2012 through 2016 I've been fired from a job I very much liked because of testing positive, used many other hard drugs, drank alcohol in large amount and blacked out nearly every time. 2015 I was arrested for DUI with alcohol and marijuana in my system. My life was a mess. I was depressed, I had no motivation to live and I had no energy. I did all the drugs I did to forget about my life. I was stuck in a vicious cycle of drugs and contemplating sobriety. I couldn't see any light at the end of the tunnel. My family and I knew I had a problem but I did not know what to do. I was a wreck and a disfunctional drug user at the age of 20.
             Summer of 2016 I read about kratom on a forum and I decided to try it. For the first couple weeks I didn't understand why people used it. I continued my addiction with marijuana. One day I finally said enough is enough and I did my best to be sober. 3 days later my marijuana cravings were so intense I had not slept at all those night and picked up my phone to call my dealer. I remembered about the bag of kratom I had and took a tea spoon. 30 minutes later I could not believe what I was feeling. My cravings had completely disappeared and I was filled with energy and a warmth happiness. Suddenly I had an attitude that I can do it! I had motivation to live and get it done! One month later of being sober from marijuana and hard drugs I felt normal I felt like the real me. I was not intoxicated I was not high I was simply content with life. I had the energy and motivation to live. My performance at work went up because my depression and anxiety had gone away.
            Thanks to God and kratom my life has been restored back to normal. I can now function and be a part of society. I have been sober from marijuana and hard drugs for 5 months now, which is the longest I have ever gone and I plan on continuing my healthy life and never looking back. Recreational drugs are not part of my life anymore. Although I wish I could be functional without kratom it has made me free to live my life. Maybe someday slowly I will stop taking kratom. But for now it has been a blessing to me. When I heard about the ban on kratom I was scared for my life and filled with intense sadness and anger. How could a plant so useful and so wonderful be banned? Is it for money? Is it so people would use pharmaceutical opiates? I don't want to use hard drugs again. I don't want to destroy my life again. I don't want to combat my depression and anxiety with pills that I would get dependent on. I just want to live a normal life and kratom has made that possible. I am 1 in thousands of people who has gotten their life back on track. Whether it be recovering from fentynal, heroin, and prescription opiates or severe depression and suicidal thoughts. Kratom has saved our lives. Please dont take that away from us. We are people trying to better ourselves and step in the right direction.
             Sincerely,
                              Dave Esparza

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern, 

  The idea that one group of individuals can tell other group, who benefit from the use of a substance, without any harm to others, that it is against the rules to use this substance, belongs to the infancy of modernity. Kratom should be studied and be more understood, but a free society shouldn't be burdened by law before it is understood. We as humans are free to participate in risky behavior, whether it be skydiving, rock climbing, or eating McDonalds everyday. Who is the DEA to tell others that this plant, which aids their health, is too dangerous for human consumption. 

 Moral judgments are all you need to figure this out, never mind pharma money. The moral thing to do is let these people continue their use of Kratom and if further study reveals harms, release the information, but don't make criminals out of people trying to help themselves get off other, more harmful substances. 

 Thank you,

documents.commentText: Although the CSA gives the DEA broad authority to schedule psychoactive substances, kratom is not known to be powerful or harmful in the same manner as other schedule I drugs (e.g., drugs like heroin that are responsible for thousands of deaths every year). It would not serve the public interest to ban relatively mild substances whose effects are similar to other commonly used herbal supplements that hundreds of thousands or millions of American use regularly and safely. Placing kratom under Schedule I would set an ugly precedent and call into question the legitimacy of the CSA and law enforcement's efforts to curb drug harm.

documents.commentText:
Many people that use kratom are NOT addicted to kratom, just as many people that use alcohol are NOT addicted to alcohol.  

I am sorry that this person has struggled so much. But turning thousands of people who responsibly use the herb into criminals is not the answer. 

Instead, I suggest better addiction prevention programs, and better addiction treatment programs. The best prevention or cure for addiction is a warm, supportive community, and a life that is enjoyable enough that the person no longer yearns to escape into substances. If you incarcerate people for using or posessing any substance, you destroy whatever life they had. Once they leave prison, they have few friends left, their families have moved on or now look down upon them, and it is EXCEEDINGLY difficult for a convict to find work. All of that is VERY depressing and life-dampening. No wonder there are such high recidivism rates.... The life a person goes back to after prison is abysmal, so they will return to drugs. 

Stop the War on Drugs. Utter failure.

Dear Sir or Madam: 
My wife of 51 years has been suffering from dystonia for approximately 9 years and has had her quality of life greatly diminished. She is under the care of a neurologist who had been administering Botox injections in her neck for about three years. After her last injection, she did not receive any relief and her pain levels increased dramatically. She spent most of her time in bed and could not complete even the most simple tasks. Her posture became terrible as she had to always lean her neck towards her shoulder as her muscles tightened. As a last resort she researched Kratom, we ordered some and have had amazing results. She is almost back to normal as far as her posture and has decreased her pain level from a 9 to a 2. This herb has been a God send for us and enables my wife to lead a pain free life in comparison to her life before Kratom. She was taking 2 Percocet tablets every four hours throughout the day and is currently taking 2 for the entire day. With Kratom there is no "high", only relief from pain. documents.commentText:
Preface: I am a 22-year old college student, I also work full time. I hope to be a college professor of history within the next few years. I come from an upper middle class family in one of the many wealthy suburbs outside of Atlanta. Addiction touches everyone, kratom can help everyone.

I was eight years old when my grandmother first over dosed on pain killers. My mother hadn't heard from her in a few days, which was extremely out of the ordinary, so we went by her house just to check in on her. The first thing that hit you upon walking into the house was the smell of rotting food-- plates left throughout the kitchen and living room that she had been too high to care to clean. She had been notorious for keeping a gun on bedside table, and fearing that she would hear us and think that we were intruders my mother had me keep yelling "Grandma! Grandma!", as we slowly walked up there stairs. After hearing no response I finally peaked my head around the corner and into her room, where she lay hanging half-way off of the bed. The doctors told us that had we arrived any later she would have died that day.

Looking back on that day, I can't help but wonder what the difference would have been. After  a few short weeks in a psychiatric hospital, they let my grandmother return home. She was a smart woman, and in the manipulative way that only addicts can do, she convinced her doctors that there was no problem with her continuing to take those pills. She spent the next eleven years of her life locked up in her room with the blinds pulled down. Every time I spoke to her, her words were slurred, sometimes falling asleep in the middle of a sentence. She began to live in absolute filth. My sweet grandmother, the former beauty queen, quit bathing herself. No rehab would take her. She knew how to clean up when she needed to. 
After well over a decade of subscription pill abuse (that awful day when I found her half-dead, the doctors estimated she had taken 60 pills), it only took 10 to kill her. She'd had a glass of wine before bed and a benadyrl. A cocktail that surely seemed harmless to her took her life, just when I was starting to get my grandma back. We found her the exact same way that we did when I was little, only this time we were too late.

The same month that my grandmother passed away, I was diagnosed with crohns disease. For the next two years I spent weeks at a time in the hospital, became far too familiar with the emergency room staff. Every time I came in, they pumped me up with dilaudid (a form of heroine the pharmaceutical industry has found a way to monetize), sent me home with 60 oxycontin. Crohns has proven time and time again to be an awful disease. Even having gotten it under control, there are many days that I've spent crying in pain. I needed that relief, many people do. But one day, I realized that I understood what my grandmother and addicts across the country love so much about them.

I found kratom around August of this year. It's a powder. It can't be smoked, it can't be injected, its too expensive in a pill, you can make it in tea (but I'm from the south so I'll only take it sweet). The easiest method is swallowing the powder and washing it down with gatorade. Simply put-- its a pain in the ass to take. You can get a similar high as from pain killers, but it takes A LOT to do that. The value in that-- is that when you're addicted to that high, you can still get it, but never to a point that you cannot function in the way that prescription pain killers do. I've had small withdrawals from pain killers before, and I would only take a few at night to relax. I can't fathom how much worse heroine, or a person who truly misused pills, would experience. With kratom, I was able bypass those withdrawals. 

Most importantly, kratom took away my pain. Better than any pharmaceutical drug had ever hoped to. I haven't missed a single day of class or work because of pain or pill-indueced fatigue since I began taking this plant. Now that I've weened off my pill habit, I take it when I need it. Rarely enough to get high. As doctors rightfully make prescription pain medicine more and more difficult to get, they need to be handing out kratom. There's no reason that kratom should only be a cure for addiction, I truly believe that it will prevent it from ever happening. 

Kratom has undoubtedly bettered my quality of living. I truly believe that it would have done the same for my grandmother as well. Kratom does not need to be illegal. Doctors, and the public, need to be better educated about it uses. I will have crohns disease for the rest of my life. Its incurable. I don't want my life to go back to the way that it was before. I don't want any other little girl to find their grandmother the way that I found mine.

I'm a 47 year old retired US Army Warrant Officer and my specialty was AH64D Apache Pilot. At some point in my career I broke my back and damaged 7 disks which caused me terrible pain, I was sent to pain management and for years was treated with opioid pain medications. Before I found Kratom I was prescribed 16mg of DIlaudid (Hydomorphone) a day and secretly taking much more. I was hopelessly addicted to the drugs my doctors were giving me for the pain. I was dying. I remembered hearing about Kratom and on a day when I was in the deep throws of withdrawals because I took all my Dilaudid before I could get another prescription I sent my wife to the local smokeshop to see if they had it, and they did. I took 5 grams of Kratom orally and my withdrawals stopped. I never looked back, I continued to use the Kratom and stopped all opioids completely without going to rehab or even tapering off of them. I am able to start and stop the Kratom without withdrawals  when I'm not in pain. This plant saved my life. If it was not available legally and I had to go back to using opioids I am sure I would end up dead. 
Mine is not a unique story and I have recommended it to a friend who was addicted to opioids after surviving cancer with success and to my 72 year old mother who also has debilitating back pain. This plant is saving lives. It's not for kids. but adults should have unlimited access. Please do not schedule this plant.

Shane Dix
CW2,AV
USA (Ret)

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
I have been using kratom for chronic pain for years and it is incredibly beneficial and less side effects than the opiods i used to be prescribed. Here are some testimonials from www.businesswire.com:

Ryan Estevez, MD, PhD, MPH, a psychiatrist and psychopharmacologist in the Tampa area who has worked for years in emergency rooms, community health centers, and prisons, says: I am well versed in both good drugs that help people on a daily basis, and bad drugs that are epidemically abused and create a tremendous burden on society. Kratom is [a natural herbal supplement] and not one of these 'bad' drugs (I have yet to admit anyone for kratom-addiction) and efforts to ban it are misguided and wasteful. Grieving parents, well intentioned policy makers, and opportunist politicians often seize on opportunities to assign blame and then offer a quick fix. The proposal of an absolute ban of Kratom perfectly illustrates what can happen when hype trumps science, as this plant has been benefiting millions of people for decades of time. I have been troubled by an increase in news reports and misinformation that has been disseminated about the dangerous and addictive drug Kratom. Even worse is the subsequent careless and knee-jerk response by many legislators and policy makers to ban Kratom. I believe much of the negative publicity surrounding Kratom to be the result of being incorrectly lumped in with synthetically derived mind-altering substances such as spice and bath-salts, substances that deserve their reputations for being dangerous and harmful."

Phil Schoenwetter, MD, Family Practitioner in Southern California since 1980, commented: "My first encounter with Kratom was stunning and unexpected. Janet, my wife of 35 years, suffers from migraines and last year had a breakthrough episode that normally would require strong pharmaceutical treatment. While fueling our SUV at a Chevron station in Nevada, Janet went to the food mart and noted a lady requesting her daily eight capsule packet of Kratom. The kind lady said it helped with her midlife aches and pains and no other adverse side effects. Janet purchased the same packet and took one capsule. Although a licensed physician in several states since 1978, I had not even encountered the word Kratom. Some 60 miles down the road Janet announced she was OK, pain free, clear of thought, (not 'loaded' as with morphine) and ready to take the wheel, which she did flawlessly for some 165 miles. This was the clarion call to wake up, smell the coffee (another botanical) and delve more deeply into natural agents and understand mechanisms of action and implement in my family medicine practice. Adverse events are infrequent and when occurring are minimal, transient, and most often is light heartburn lasting a few hours. Kratom already is a must have adjunct to numerous long term conditions and its role in my practice already exceeds the usual and customary uses that one normally will find referenced in literature found on the internet."

Here is a link to a study that proves kratoms major alkaloids had benifits for pain, there are many others, please look into them and reconsider this ban.

documents.commentText:
I have been diagnosed with spinal arthritis and lower lumbar disc disease.   I took prescribed narcotics from 2007 to 2015 in escalating doses.  I made the decision last year to discontinue using opioids.  I take 5 - 7 grams of Kratom 3x a week, to manage pain  and successfully manage pain symptoms.    I can confirm that the substance has a discontinuation syndrome, with symptoms lasting a week, that occurs with daily useage.  I'm willing to live those symptoms in the increasingly rare occasions of flare ups lasting for multiple weeks. and need to be able to function despite pain scores above 6.     The substance is effective, though escalating doses work in reverse.  You don't get increasingly soporific effects by using more.  Whatever euphoric effects one gets when first using the substance, and they are very mild compared to opioids, wear off rapidly with continued use.   I don't have "cravings'" when not using KRATOM.

I'm a 52 year old working professional with no interest using any drug for recreational benefit.  I have found exercise and Kratom to be the ONLY two things that allow me to live a somewhat normal life.  I'm opposed to the DEA banning it outright but would welcome government enforcing standards so that what I take isn't adulterated with other substances.

Please do not leave people like me no choice.   Pain is pain, and when unmanaged, it motivates one to do whatever it takes to alleviate it.   The unintended consequences of banning the substance outright is more illegal drug seeking, ruined lives and deaths.    Don't make the problem worse for yourselves, because you'll end up having to clean up a bigger mess.   If you won't let people like me make responsible choices , at the very least, allow medical research to continue on the active substances found in KRATOM.

documents.commentText: To whom it may concern... I am a 35 year old mother, author, and investment lender that has suffered  from various spinal and nervous conditions throughout my life. Because of this, I spent 12 years in pain management treatment just in attempt to have a quality life and to have the ability to perform my duties as a patent and in my business, as well as my personal life. I was taking opioid medications during these 12 years, and although it took the edge off of my pain, I felt as if I was living with a ball and chain, imprisoned by these drugs. I have never been a person who indulges in the recreational use of substances, and always only took my medication as prescribed. But as years went on and my tolerance grew, the amount and dosage became frighteningly high, just for a bit of relief. Due to having to live my life around a medicaton, and feel more like a criminal than a patient as opioid regulations stiffened, I struggled with depression and lived in fear of what I'd do when there were no higher doses, what would happen if laws became more strict and I couldn't get enough medication to be able to walk and live, and constantly worrying about the dangers and side effects associated with the meds. Then I learned about Kratom,  and was able to almost painlessly get off of all opioid medications  (very high doses as I said), and achieve all naturally, much safer relief without all those awful side effects and risks. I believe this plant has saved my life and has renewed my energy and we'll being. And that's speaking only for myself and in summary. It would take hours to really convey the wonderful things that it's done for me, my life, those close to me, and countless others I know that have been helped emmensly by this plant. I'm utterly terrified at the prospect of having to ever return to chemical pharmaceuticals to have even a fraction of the quality I have today. I don't feel that it's a viable long term solution. From the extensive research I've done,  there is such a miniscule amount of kratom related injuries, especially compared to even seemingly innocuous household items such as laundry detergent, and no DIRECT kratom related deaths. Kratom may have been in one's system, but was not the sole cause of death. Compare this to the staggering and ever growing number of opioid related deaths. We do not want to return to those risks or way of life, and some of us don't have the choice of just foregoing any therapy unless we wish to resign to a life on the couch or in a wheel chair. We deserve better, and we deserve healthier, natural options. Besides any health concerns, it seems another concern about Kratom is that of people abusing it or using it to "get high." But what history and even common sense shows, is that for those out solely to seek a high, banning a particular substance isn't going to stop that. They'll find another way, another substance. And the ones who truly suffer are those benefiting from said substance. Also, from a social standpoint, since no one can stop drug abuse as a whole, is it not a lesser evil for people to be using a substance with lower risks than alcohol,rather than much more deadly subalances? Kratom offers little to no negative side effects, and "overdose" results in a stomach ache or vomiting (again, no worse than our legal alcohol, and isn't even fatal as alcohol can be), haso no criminality surrounding it, and does not have nearly the abuse potential of opioid medications or street drugs. I implore you to please reconsider any ban to be placed on this plant,  which to me and many others from ALL walks of life has been nothing short of a lifesaver. I, for one, don't want to lose my ability to be a great mother, a businessperson, a wife, daughter, adventurer, or any of the other things I now enjoy being to the fullest, simply because my only options go back to being immobile and useless or playing Russian Roulette with medications. Please consider the benefits, please see this as a blessing and viiable option to more dangerous "drugs," please don't take away the quality of life that this naturally growing gift of God has given me and so many others. Thank you for hearing us!

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern - 

My name is Michael Hansen. I am 31 years old. I work part time in retail. I started using Kratom in 2014. I read an article online when searching for natural ways to relieve stress, anxiety, and symptoms of PTSD after fatal car accident I was involved in. The accident was related to a domestic situation, in which a partner of mine, attempting to stop me from leaving, jumped onto my moving car. He fell, subsequently breaking his neck, and after nine days in a medically induced coma, was taken off life support and died. The trauma of the event caused me to lapse into a serious depression. I suffered extreme anxiety. I do no use drugs. And I rarely drink. I refused to go to a doctor and have myself put on addictive, dangerous drugs such as prozac and xanax. 

A great deal of research and taking responsibility for my own treatment led me to Kratom and has made it possible again for me to function to the fullest. I believe there is a lot of misinformation being spread, including that it is a dangerous, addictive 'drug.' Let's be clear -the dangerous, addictive drugs are the ones that are already perfectly legal: antidepressants, benzodiazepines, opioids, alcohol. I plead with you to allow persons such as myself and others - people who suffer from mental and physical pain - to continue to have access a safe, natural alternative. The 'war on drugs' is already a travesty and complete failure. Increasingly states have defied the DEA and federal government and begun allowing marijuana for medicinal purposes. This is a step in the right direction - allowing people options and access to alternatives. Banning Kratom will turn hundreds of people seeking alternatives into criminals. And placing Kratom as a Schedule 1 makes zero sense. I think you send a dangerous message to people by putting harmless substances in a category with substances that have legitimate dangers. Marijuana has killed literally 0 people. Kratom has killed literally 0. Why group these in with heroin, a substance which is being abused at epidemic levels? 

Let's use common sense when regulating things. And let's allow people the choice to chose a treatment that works best for them. Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be banned.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S., and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Kratom is a tree native to Southeast Asia. It is in the same plant family as the coffee tree, known as Rubiaceae. It is used for chronic pain relief, treating addiction to opiates, alcohol and some pharmaceuticals, chronic inflammation, anxiety, PTSD, depression, insomnia, high blood pressure, fibromyalgia, multiple sclerosis and the list goes on. It has also been used as a stimulant by workers in Thailand for hundreds of years.

The DEA is claiming kratom has a high likelihood of abuse, zero medical value and poses a serious threat to public safety. It has therefore decided to enact an emergency temporary ban to stop the masses from dropping like flies until further research can be done. The DEAs strongest argument is from a small number of deaths associated with kratom and 660 calls to poison control involving kratom. But it has been found that most if not all deaths involving kratom were cases where it was combined with other dangerous substances, not just kratom on its own. And the 660 poison control calls were over the past 5 years. To put that in perspective, there have been 6,843 calls for children exposed to laundry detergent pods just in the last 7 months.

The problem with the DEAs proposed temporary ban is Schedule 1 status would make it nearly impossible to conduct research that would lead to kratom ever being unscheduled. Meanwhile thousands would be suffering not only from the conditions mentioned above, but also the endless side effects of the pharmaceuticals they are forced to take because the only healthy, safe and effective alternative has been made illegal. With the ban, tens of thousands of ill people will become felons overnight including injured veterans, seniors and accident victims.

I have personally used kratom almost daily for the last 2 years as an alternative to coffee by mixing the leaf powder with water and drinking it or brewing a tea and I can confirm it has been an entirely positive experience with zero undesirable effects whatsoever.

Everyone knows someone who has had problems with chronic pain and/or opiate addiction problems. The fact is kratom is the single biggest saviour for these people and the most effective tool against the countries current opiate epidemic. While I fortunately do not live with any of the debilitating conditions mentioned thus far, I would like to rest assured knowing that if I (or anyone else) did in the future, we would have access to this life saving gift of nature. Rather than being forced to use the unnatural, addictive, dangerous and expensive prescription drugs that wreak havoc on the body and turn people into unproductive zombies who are unable to work or even drive.

Nobody is writing or calling in to senators or congress or marching in front of the whitehouse to tell them how alcohol or tobacco has changed their lives for the better, yet they are perfectly legal despite tobacco being responsible for over 480,000 deaths annually and alcohol being responsible for over 88,000.

documents.commentText:
I would describe my body as athletic type around 155 pounds. I'm a male, age 32. No history of major illness, no medication I take regularly. I did take finasteride from May 2008 to Jan 2014 for regular hairloss but quit taking it. Many side effects I had originally thought were from taking kratom I discovered to be entirely from finasteride.

I started taking kratom in October 2008. I take it for back pain originating from either a gym injury or work injury around 2007, I'm not really sure which. It wasn't a readily apparent back injury whenever it happened. My back pain is bad enough that I have trouble sitting upright in chairs without feeling pain or standing straight for too long. I had no health insurance at the time (Oct 2008) so I never went to a doctor about it. I have tried oxycodone and hydrocodone which I had prescribed to me  for wisdom teeth surgery and different dental procedures. I never used them for dental pain and have refused all pain medication since starting kratom. I discovered at one point as an experiment that kratom and hydrocodone cross tolerate so you get nothing from taking hydrocodone and kratom together. Neither hydrocodone or oxycodone seemed to do much of anything for my back even when taken at higher doses than recommended.  But when I started taking kratom it completely rid me of my back pain outright. It also didn't make me itchy like oxycodone and hydrocone did. Kratom didn't make me tired either like those drugs did. Kratom is more of a stimulant like caffeine is. When I first started taking kratom it wasn't daily it was one large dose every other day. Then after a few months I started taking half of that dose daily. I have quit kratom for about 6 months total since Oct 2008 almost always when financially strapped. I would say it's addictive but only as addictive as caffeine, maybe a little less addictive than caffeine. I've NEVER tried to quit caffeine and never will in my life but have quit kratom. Sometimes I tried quitting outright and sometimes weaning down. I've found weaning down to be more effective for quitting and staying off it for longer periods. Quitting outright seems to make me more prone to going back to it a week later. The withdrawals usually peak the first day or two after quitting then you just feel the normal pain you're in after a day or two. In my experience you can't really build up any tolerance to kratom lasting more than a day. I take the same dose everyday for many years now around about 6 to 12 grams a day spaced out as a little under 1 gram per hour. When I first started taking it I had a problem with the taste of it but now I'm just used it.

The way I take kratom is by pouring about 1 gram into a small cup of water, let it sink in, then toss it back in my throat. Then I drink a small sip of water after. I've never and I repeat NEVER gotten any of the symptoms for kratom I've seen listed on a lot of scare stories about kratom like hallucinations, delusions, trouble breathing, or anything of that sort. When I ever do take too much kratom it seems to make my hands shake some but only after about 20 grams in one day. Around 30 grams in one day it feels like you're wired kind of like after drinking a bunch of energy drinks. I've only ever done that much in one sitting just to see what would happen. I've never vomited from taking kratom but know some people that have. I've never really experienced any constipation on kratom but have heard others that have. I have experienced more frequent urination when using more kratom than usual in a day but I'm also drinking more water with the kratom to wash it after on those days.

The current work I do is box lifting and moving at a transportation company. Very heavy manual labor job. I've done it for a little under 7 years now (same work at two different companies). I usually take 1 gram of kratom before going to work then one gram of kratom when returning 6 to 8 hours later. Without kratom I would not be able to do that job. At home I do paintings in my freetime and again I would not be able to sit upright in a chair long enough to paint anything without taking kratom.

I've climbed and hiked literal mountains on kratom. I'm very outdoorsy and enjoy mountain hiking. I restrict how much kratom I take at higher altitude because with or without kratom I get terrible altitude sickness to the point of vomitting after eating nothing. Even when going from sea level to Denver I'll get altitude sickness. I usually take one gram of kratom before starting up a mountain then one gram while coming back down. I've really turned my life around since I started taking kratom and I do thank kratom for that turnaround.

It should remain available to any consenting adult capable of making his/her own decision regarding pain relief treatment.  Lastly, with record high cases of opioid addiction in the United States, it would be irresponsible to ignore the positive results kratom can have on overcoming addiction. 

Consider wisely.

documents.commentText:
I write to oppose the possible ban on kratom. A substance should not be banned without a substantial amount of high quality scientific evidence of the need for a ban. Even then, there must be substantial policy bases for a ban, demonstrating that the substance in question is completely devoid of any legitimate use. A Schedule I listing make research almost impossible. In particular:

		Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
		If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind  bars.
		Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
		Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
		Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
		Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Our long-time approach to drug problems has not turned out to be adequate to the challenge. We must look to alternatives. 

Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I just wanted to say, thank you so much for withdrawing the notice of intent to schedule kratom and giving us a chance to voice our opinions. I am writing anonymously, but I really want to stress the fact that this situation is very, very important to me. I don't even really know where I would be right now if I didn't have kratom available when I needed it.

I suffered injuries from a weightlifting accident a few years ago and experienced a rather large hematoma in both of my legs. I was having a lot of trouble sleeping and was in constant agonizing pain to the point where I couldn't think of anything else. I ended up seeing a doctor who prescribed pain killers and instead of helping with my injury I just found myself quickly becoming addicted to the medication. I eventually suffered a seizure from my usage and was put in the hospital. When I got out I thought it would be business as usual, but I quickly found myself addicted to my medication and it was getting harder and harder to stop.

Eventually the pills started running my life and it was all I was thinking about. I got sick of it one day so I decided to do some research and I stumbled across several stories about people using kratom to wean off of opiates and breaking their addiction. I ordered some online and followed some dosage/preparation guidelines and never looked back. It has helped me immensely in regards to fighting my addiction and keeping my head on my shoulders. 

I eventually decided to cut down on the kratom as well and now I only use it to curb any cravings if they end up rearing their ugly head. The best part about it is I don't have this constant urge to take any substances now like I did when I was on opiates. When I was taking pills my entire day was just thinking about the next time I could take pills again. Kratom freed me those shackles and really improved my life.

Thanks a lot for reading my story and PLEASE keep things like this in mind when making your decision. I urge (heck, I even beg!) the DEA to keep kratom legal. I don't think prohibition is the right idea here at all and if anything has to happen it should only be regulation.  Kratom isn't some crazy new synthetic drug that is ruining everyone's lives, it's a plant that is helping a lot of people deal with their addictions, anxiety, depression and many other things. Since starting up this fight to keep kratom legal, I have spoken with doctors, nurses, addiction specialist and many other highly respectable people who are fully in support of keeping kratom available. It's truly been amazing to see all of the good people who are coming together and standing by this plant. There was never this much support for other substances like spice and whatever else in the past because mostly everyone could understand why it was being banned. That isn't the case with kratom.

So again, I urge you to keep stories like this one in mind. Please. I am a responsible adult and I only want what is best for me and I really don't want to go back to my old life before I had kratom available. Kratom has played a huge role in who I am today and I would be eternally grateful if the right to use it wasn't stripped from me. Please help us out here.

Thank you.

Hi.

This is my second comment.  I wrote in once before expressing why kratom needs to stay legal, emphasizing the fact that the vast majority of kratom users are not teenagers seeking a fast buzz, but adults who need kratom just to function and feel normal.  I need to reiterate the fact that kratom can help people to feel "normal" and productive from the standpoint of where we are right now as a society.  There is already so much hopelessness out there, a condition that kratom can somehow take the edge off in some way.  For some reason, even with life's inevitable bad turns, kratom seems to have anti-anxiety properties that can somehow make one feel that they have the strength to push through and still do what s/he needs to do to progress.  To deny people this plant in this way alone could be disastrous to our way of living right now. 

As divided as our country is now, we do not need something taken away that can safely make it easier for us to function and get along and work with each other to try to heal as a society.  Kratom is just part of the solution, but a part of the solution none-the-less.  

I must state further that kratom is not a drug, but an herbal supplement that will not cure any condition, but absolutely helps and improves chronic issues to the point where life becomes manageable.  We will have new administration now, and the president-elect wants people back to work, but people need to be able to work, and kratom can definitely help with that prospect.  Not to mention, the kratom industry itself is sizeable, and our economy needs it.  Again, the amount of work and productivity that could be lost if kratom is unavailable is incalculable.  I know there have also been many references to kratom helping to ween people off dangerous opioids and other actual drugs, again, which kratom is not. 

Proposing a worse case scenario, if kratom is addictive, and research is absolutely needed so that everyone can learn about it and make determinations regarding aspects such as addiction, I would think it would be better to be "addicted" to a substance like kratom which (on its own) will not kill you rather than to be addicted to a true opioid which can and will kill you. Kratom users are everyday people trying to function in integral parts of society, as teachers, ministers, constructions workers, and so on - people that are not expendable.  Kratom is vital to keeping our culture moving at this point and without any doubt needs to remain available.

documents.commentText:
I am very disappointed that this plant is even being considered for scheduling. This is not how you take care of any issues you may have with kratom. Regulation like with other supplements may be okay, or just leaving it alone in general.

I'm a 30-year-old male that has been using this plant on and off for 2 years. I have PTSD from an abusive childhood and other things that happened to me. I've had panic attacks, nightmares, and a number of other issues that make it hard for me to work. The medications I have been on ranged from anti-psychotics to anti-depressants and they made it hard for me to do anything at all due to how cloudy they made my mind feel.

During the time I was getting medicated, I started to experiment more and more with alcohol and drugs. This led me to a much worse place, and eventually someone told me about kratom. First, I had to quit the drugs I was on, and then I had a battle with alcohol for a while. This ended in a hospital visit, and before that there were many bouts of alcohol poisoning and other dangerous situations caused by a legal substance.

I ordered some kratom after going through withdrawals from alcohol in a hospital because that withdrawal gave me seizures. You cannot tell me that it makes sense to schedule a plant but you are going to keep alcohol legal.

Now that I've been using kratom, I can work again and have become a productive member of society. I got married, take care of my stepkid, and am able to actually leave my house without being drunk or high.

Please reconsider this ban. I honestly don't want to have to make a choice to either be a criminal and keep using kratom or switch to something much more dangerous. It really doesn't make a lot of sense why this is happening, beyond some kind of ulterior motive which I hope is not the case.

This plant can help people. Anything can be abused or done in excess, but there are far worse options for people. If you want to work on the opioid epidemic in this country and come out ahead, you have to understand that banning everything doesn't help anyone. Making prescriptions hard to get doesn't help, either. You are just going to make heroin more and more popular or cause people to get on strong drugs like methadone. Why not help everyone out and keep kratom legal?

You can save lives, or put more people on the track to serious problems. I trust the government to make the right decision after reading our comments and looking at the scientific evidence.

Thank you for letting us comment on this.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.


Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.


Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
I'm a 27 year old, married, father of one. I'm currently attempting to get on disability due to chronic, debilitating pain from having osteoarthritis and a rare condition called Ehlers Danlos syndrome. I have been prescribed medication in the past, but nothing seemed to take the pain away or I'd have unpleasant side effects from it. 

One day, I was on the Internet looking up alternatives to pain medication. For one, most people my age don't look up that sort of thing on the Internet. I'm fairly young, but I will have deal with these conditions for life, barring some huge medical breakthrough. During my search for something to relieve me of pain, I came across something called kratom. I began to read about it for the next couple days and finally ordered some.

I'm an extremely skeptical person, so I had my doubts about kratom being effective. I wasn't worried about it being dangerous after all the literature had pointed to it being safe, with some minor side effects. Long story short, I received my package of kratom in the mail a few days later and tried some. Within 15-20 minutes, my back and neck pain vanished. I wasn't left feeling intoxicated or like I couldn't function, on the contrary, I felt more able to do different things.  For the first time in awhile, I was finally able to sleep through the night. Kratom has had a huge impact in my life. Not only has it helped my physical pain, it's made me more active and I'm also more social as I don't feel miserable and actually talk to people. 

Please reconsider prohibiting people like myself from just wanting to feel normal and pain free. I urge you to please think about all the people who have experienced great benefits from kratom. I thank you for being considerate enough to hear the voices of the kratom community.

documents.commentText: Kratom is very effective at relieving pain and anxiety without the risk of addiction or misuse inherent in opioids or benzodiazepines. There is no real "high" associated with use of Kratom and I would rate it's potential for abuse as extremely small (maybe on the order of coffee). It's benefits, however, are manifold and include pain relief without sedation, rapid anxiety relief without euphoria, efficacy at a wide range of doses, a lack of withdrawal effects as a dose wears off (so no "chasing the high" or desire to take more to avoid "coming down") and an inherent feeling Kratom provides that dissuades the user from taking more once a dose wears off. I began taking Kratom to manage chronic back pain and have recommended it to several of my patients with chronic pain, all of whom found it helpful. Kratom is not something one would seek out solely for intoxication- it is simply not that reinforcing or "fun". I believe that scheduling it as a C-1 drug is both unnecessary and a bit ludicrous. There are few effective remedies for chronic pain a doctor can offer patients apart from opioids; but Kratom is effective, well-tolerated and non-addictive, and I would like to keep recommending it.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

I suffer from chronic migraines, that I have had since I was 17. I also suffer from chronic bladder infections. I have tried a whole mix of things, nothing works 100%. Every medication has a side effect, weather it's tingling fingers of memory loss.. That's topomax to burning feeling in the face and possible heart attack... Imitrex 

I believe in a mix of medication and self-healing measures, such as yoga and meditation. I also believe that its not good practice to rely only on one medication for pain management. My neurologist and I have agreed that diversification of pain medication helps to reduce the risk of rebound headaches, and the risk of dependence.

This past February I was researching herbal pain remedies and came across an article from Vice News (http://www.vice.com/read/why-banning-the-controversial-painkiller-kratom-could-be-bad-news-for-americas-heroin-addicts) about kratom, a natural substance known for its pain relieving qualities. Could this be another way to manage my pain? Maybe this would replace or cut out other pain meds that I use. I took to the internet to obtain facts, check on addiction rates and understand how to ingest kratom. Here are some of the facts I found (with references) that made me decide that I would try kratom as one of many branches in managing chronic pain.

According to Kratom Science (https://www.kratomscience.com/strains-effects-and-dosage): An important distinction is that unlike other administered drugs like oxycodone and morphine, kratom exhibits less dependency and addiction potential on the user. As mentioned previously, I am very cognizant of not becoming too dependent on any one substance and believe that diversification with kratom can be beneficial to my pain management plan.
Vice News reports that it is used to wean addicts off of heroin (http://www.vice.com/read/why-banning-the-controversial-painkiller-kratom-could-be-bad-news-for-americas-heroin-addicts).
Those with multiple sclerosis, back pain, chronic fatigue syndrome and Lyme disease have reported relief when using kratom.
There have been a limited number of deaths attributed solely to kratom. Only 15 reported in the last 10 years. The majority of overdoses where kratom is present, other drugs and alcohol were all contributing factors.  Unlike opioids, kratom does not suppress the breathing function, which is an element of overdosing.
These findings led me to try kratom. After trying different strains and dosing, I can say that I finally have my life back. Kratom takes the pain away. I found that it gives me a little boost, allowing me to be more productive. I have been pleased with the results and love that kratom is less toxic than opioids.

Over 100,000 Americans signed a petition (including myself) to halt the DEAs two-year ban on kratom. During the temporary ban, the DEA would conduct studies on this natural supplement. To me, it makes more sense to conduct studies and then come to a conclusion on whether or not to ban kratom. It clearly helps at least 100,000 manage their pain in an era where taking any type of opioid is completely taboo. People with pain matter. Completely blocking access to kratom will have a direct impact on those who responsibly take pain medications to deal with a chronic medical issue.

documents.commentText:
I am a 23 year salesman for an emergency preparedness and asset protection software company.  I also have an undergraduate honors degree in Psychology from Trinity College Dublin, Ireland. One of the modules I attained high marks in pertained to the study of drug addiction.

The big difference between kratom and opiates is that mitragynine prefers so-called delta opioid receptors, while opiates bind to mu opioid receptors. This is believed to be the reason that kratom is not (strongly) addictive (1).

My current role involves dealing with top executives on a daily basis via phone calls and face to face meetings. Thus my job requires incessant amiability, alertness, punctuality, and professionalism. I tend to only use kratom on weekends, and its use has not affected my performance in any way, shape, or form. This would be true even if I used it everyday. I never find myself craving kratom or feeling like I need higher and higher doses to feel the same effect.

As I'm sure the DEA knows, 88,000 people a year tend to die from alcohol-related causes in the United States (2). Over 480,000 people tend to die per year from tobacco-related causes (3). There have only ever been 15 'kratom-related' deaths known in the United States in the past 16 years. Additionally, autopsies for those deaths revealed that kratom was always far from the only drug in the person's body at the time of death. It thus can not firmly be concluded that kratom has caused a single death.

To even consider making kratom, which cannot be firmly associated with a single death, a Schedule 1 substance in a nation where two widely-used drugs, alcohol and tobacco, are completely legal and known to contain poison as well as to have caused hundreds of thousands of deaths, is utterly preposterous. Such a consideration is a complete waste of time, effort, and money for the DEA and all those involved. 

As a government entity designed to protect citizens of the United States from harmful substances, I implore the DEA to do just that. If alcohol and tobacco are not considered Schedule 1 substances in our society, no reasonable argument can be made that kratom should be. 

1) www.mitragyna.com/usage

2) https://www.niaaa.nih.gov/alcohol-health/overview-alcohol-consumption/alcohol-facts-and-statistics

3)  https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/health_effects/tobacco_related_mortality/

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be added to a scheduled substance list.
 As someone who has lived with severe chronic pain for most of my life and is unable to utilize most conventional medications due to allergies to nearly all prescription options, I am most appreciative for the positive impact in the quality of life that I have been able to have since finding out about kratom.
I have found this tea allows me more freedom to be the mother, wife, and productive member of society that nothing else has ever been able to provide.
Without the nasty side effects that come from medications to which I am not allergic to, Kratom helps ease the discomfort I had the displeasure of living with for over 25 years. 
When I use kratom I am able to continue to have the ability to focus perform tasks avoid nausea and remain clear-headed without feeling as though I have taken something that alters my mind. While Kratom may not be for everyone it has made a significant positive impact in my life.
I believe this tea, when speaking of the 100% unadulterated plain leaf,  is the safest possible option that I could have access to. Myself and countless others have benefited significantly from this leaf. To take away this natural plant option from adults would be an asinine move. It makes zero sense why there should be any control over this alternative. Kratom is not a drug. Kratom is a plant. It is a tree, most often grown in the wild- organically- and safe sustainable farming practices allow these leaves to be harvested, ground up into a fine powder or into crushed leaf and used safely by thousands of people worldwide, in some countries for more than a century. It is used for a variety of reasons, but it helps improve lives not destroy them. The DEA nor the FDA should be able to take something so beneficial away when it is not a danger or a threat to lives. 
To classify this leaf as anything other than for what it is,  a tea, would be devastating to countless families, like mine. Please do not limit adult access to kratom. We have organizations working to make sure that responsible safe handling practices and product quality is held to the highest standards. I believe the direction this industry is moving and working towards, being handled by these organizations is the best solution to any agencies hesitation. Once these organizations have all the guidelines in place and as a community those who refuse to abide by these standards are rejected, we will be one of the most safe and effective communities there is within the United States. We have had no guidelines of standards in the last 10-15 years, when kratom really began to be used by a large number of people within the US, but yet even without these industry standards in place we've been doing a great job and had one of the safest possible track records of nearly any other product available in the United States. I know of very few other products that have a track record of safety as strong and well established as kratom. 
We are not criminals looking for a new drug or something to elicit a "high", we are far and widely mature adults looking for natural ways to help improve our quality of life. Kratom is my answer. Don't take this away from us. If anything, I believe states should be the highest level of "control" such as in my state of Illinois where they already established an 18+ law. I believe that is more than adequate. I know you already have seen the studies showing the safety of kratom in various ways and controls, including the study by Ole Miss led by Dr. Christopher McCurdy. Kratom should be more well-known and you can believe that IF it was a danger- it would have already been far more known. Before the announcement published in August, if I asked anyone who hadn't been around me since 2014 (when I found out about kratom) they had NEVER heard of it. When there is a danger of anything that's been around for more than 5 years,  people are aware- if I ask anyone what a Lortab or Heroin is, by age 13- they know. That in itself should speak volumes about just how safe kratom truly is. Kratom is a safe natural plant helping thousands of people lead better, more productive, higher quality lives. Keep our tea available for ALL adults. Thank you for your time and attention to this extremely important matter. 

Sincerely, 
Cherity C

  I'm writing tonight to express how kratom has helped change my life in many ways. Since I was younger ( school aged ), I was prescribed medications for ADD and mood disorders. As I grew older I went through emotional trauma and suffered from depression,  anxiety and PTSD. I had many issues with mulitiple doctors constantly changes doses and medications.  After feeling as though I'd lost hope and wanted to give up I had a friend tell me about an all natural herb called kratom. I can honestly say after using it in my tea every morning I feel like I am truly happy again. I no longer need the pharmaceutical medications to control my life. I have finally graduated college, and am privileged to be at home with my wonderful children and hard working husband. Kratom has changed my life for the better and I pray that kratom will not be banned or made illegal. But if it does I will obviously abide by the law. I just wanted to put it out there how it's changed my life for the better and how I've read so many stories of how its improved others. I am now free of depression, anxiety and have let go of the past which brought on PTSD. I am healthy now and I know others will stay this way too if it stays legal. Thank you for taking the time to read my story.

documents.commentText:
I was addicted to pain pills 7 years ago. I went through treatment for that addiction, but then ended up in jail for the medication I was prescribed to stay off opiates. I attempted suicide twice while I was in jail which was a direct result of being forced into coming off anti-depressants, anti-anxiety, and buprenorphine medications, "cold turkey", in jail. I had no criminal record before that time, and now at age 44, I have a felony and misdemeanor conviction. 

Along with a vegan lifestyle, and daily exercise, for the past 3 years, I have taken only kratom to help manage any desire, I may have to go back to opiates. It also helps with my anxiety, and depression issues that I have had my entire life. If I would have known about kratom before going into treatment for opiate addiction, I am certain, I would not have the criminal record I have today.

My felony conviction has made it very hard to find a job that provides an income where I can be independent, and provide for myself, so I sell kratom. I get a lot of satisfaction knowing that I am helping others by offering them a plant based alternative. 

I am not going to downplay the addictive qualities of kratom. I know it is there, and it can be unpleasant, but not deadly, and the focus should be on harm reduction, and my kratom use has never put me in the types of harmful situations that pharmaceutical drugs did. With caffeine, sugar, nicotine and alcohol we accept that consumers must exercise personal responsibility in using the products, and we know that a certain percentage of consumers will not. For good or bad, that's life in an open society with a free market. We don't punish responsible consumers for the missteps of the minority. I ask that you please keep kratom as legal, and available as its sister plant, coffee.

documents.commentText:
Good Afternoon,

My name is Jessi, and I support the use of Kratom for all Americans. 
I am a daily Kratom user for two years now, and it has improved my quality of life in more ways than I can count. Aside from myself, my grandfather, a Korean War veteran, takes Kratom regularly as well. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer over ten years ago, and after several years cancer free, it returned. He can no longer receive chemotherapy treatment or radiation treatment. My grandfather also does not like to take the opiate painkillers he has been prescribed for pain associated with cancer and nerve damage- these medications cause him much more harm than good with the unpleasant side effects he experiences. He was introduced to Kratom and such a small amount gives him the pain relief and energy he needs to get through each day with cancer and other medical issues he suffers from at the age of 85. I cannot understand why anyone, government agencies included, would want to see the elderly people of our country, the war vets who gave up everything so many times for this country, to suffer and live out their lives in a miserable state. Once he has passed, he is gone, there is no going back to try and make things better, to make his quality of life better. I cannot imagine by fun loving, wise-cracking jokester of a grandfather having to go through each of the last of his days unhappy and in pain. Please consider our vets, and our Americans who have outstanding amounts of medical debt, as I do myself. Allow them this small chance to live pain free, anxiety free, DEPRESSION FREE, and debt free. It's such a small sacrifice for our government to make to allow our people their freedom to chose what plants they put into their body to better themselves. There are absolutely NO deaths associated with Kratom by itself. I can attest to the effects, both short and long term. I went through surgeries, pain relief treatments, and medications without any improvement. Also counseling and anxiety treatment. I found Kratom, went to my doctors as needed, had a healthy and happy pregnancy, and was regularly checked and seen by doctors all while on Kratom. I have had zero side effects or health issues associated with Kratom. Please can we all come together and do what's best for our people and our beautiful country. I am absolutely willing to do my part for the people. Our government has the potential to show the world how important and strong our people are, and that our people will fight for their rights which other countries do not allow. 
Please consider regulating Kratom. If we can allow alcohol and Tabacco into the lives of adult Americans, I believe we can certainly allow for adults to make the right choice in herbal remedies such as Kratom. I do believe in our people, and at a state level, we can safely regulate Kratom. Thank you for your time and your understanding.

Sincerely,

Jessica Grace Vermilyea

documents.commentText: Hello. I am a 42 year old professional woman who works in the medical field as a nurse. I have been using Kratom for approximately 2 years. I started taking Kratom after my doctor took me off of Tramadol cold turkey. I was in several car accidents, my second accident in Jan 2001 was the worst. I developed severe back pain and was unable to walk. I was put on several pain medications but nothing worked until I started taking Tramadol. I took Tramadol for over 10 years until my primary doctor left and I was assigned a new one who decided to take me off entirely without warning or tapering. I was miserable and in excruciating pain on a daily basis. I was told about Kratom by my dad who stays up-to-date with different alternatives to pharmaceuticals. It helped me so much with the negative side effects of opiate withdrawal and not only that but it helped with the pain. I have never felt "high" with kratom and do not take it in excess or on a daily basis. I take about 2 teaspoons three times a week. I am never foggy or drugged up. In fact, kratom actually helps me focus more and has helped relieve other things I've experienced in life such as anxiety and depression. I understand there are people out there seeking different things to get high and some have achieved that with excessive use of kratom but that could be said for something such as alcohol. Putting kratom on the list of scheduled drugs would hurt people such as myself and I ask that you reconsider doing that. I appreciate you taking the time to read this and I thank you for the consideration.
