documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,
I am taking this opportunity to voice my concern on the recent proposed Kratom ban. I am a Kratom user. I depend on Kratom daily. I suffer from endometriosis, extreme ovarian cysts and Severe Menstral complications. For my complications, there is no cure. I have been told multiple times by numerous doctors that I have three options " pain medication, abrasive surgery or to deal with it." I didnt like those choices so I looked for something natural and that's when I found Kratom. I have been able to keep my pain tolerable with Kratom for the last year with zero side effects. Kratom helps with more then just my pain, I am a mother of a special needs daughter and I don't have time for the fatigue that comes along with my illness. Kratom gives me energy after a long day at work to take on my house hold and motherly chores. 
When they first announced the ban I stopped taking Kratom completely, I was terrified that I could be charged the same as a person using heroine. I stopped that day and I must report I had no withdrawal symptoms. I don't drink, smoke or use any street drugs so Kratom has never been a "replacement drug" in my case. I have panic attacks and anxiety, Kratom has helped me to cut my medicine in half. So I am asking you please take my comment into consideration when coming to a final decision. Kratom has helped me actually enjoy and live my life for both me and my daughter. Please don't take my hope away.

documents.commentText:
My name is Megan King. I'm 37 years old, I'm a single parent and I'm a responsible adult consumer of kratom. I am opposed to any scheduling of this plant. I live with a chronic pain condition called Trigeminal Neuralgia. The pain strikes without warning and lasts for weeks to months on end. This condition is known as the 'suicide disease' due to its exceptionally severe and persistent nature. I feel very strongly that I should be allowed to choose natural options like kratom to help with this debilitating condition that leads many to deep depression. Kratom lifts my mood without impairing me in any way and while it does not always ease the excruciating pain it does help me to remain functional. It has returned me to productivity. It allows me to live a full life and to be the mother my son deserves. Please don't take this plant from me.
 
The US is currently in the midst of an atrocious opioid crisis that is worsening everyday. It is inconceivable that kratom might be made unavailable to the public during this critical time. Pure leaf kratom is safe and it saves lives! While addiction to narcotics is something I have managed to avoid thus far (thanks to kratom), it could very easily happen to me and it does happen to millions of others. Per National Institute on Drug Abuse, as of 2012 it was estimated that 2.1 million people in the United States were suffering from substance use disorders related to prescription opioid pain relievers and an estimated 467,000 addicted to heroin. Heroin-related deaths increased 439% from 1999 to 2014. In 2014, opioids were involved in 28,647 deaths. That's 61% of all US drug overdose deaths. Additionally, 10,574 were related to heroin, in particular. Sadly, these statistics are only increasing. Kratom helps people struggling with addictions get their lives back! Please do not ban this plant! Do not take away this option in our greatest hour of need! 

I am fully opposed to ANY scheduling of kratom.

documents.commentText: I am a 44 year old male Surgical Tech/ Operating Room Materials Manager. As a young man I was in the U.S. Army. I have been employed at the same hospital in Okc. for 20 years . At the age of 39 i started to have some severe/complex health problems. I became a type 2 diabetic and developed sever painful diabetic neuropathy in the lower half of my legs i also had a sever cachectic reaction to diabetes. I have tried all of the FDA approved medication for PDN and only mild if any relief  was achieved. After attempting to treat with these medications and numerous narcotics.  I decide to try going with no medicine and my quality of life was so bad I struggled with work and my family suffered for 2 years becoming fed up and feeling like i was about to loose my wife of  20 years at the time I went back to the narcotics Loratab 10   1-2 a day when pain was overwhelming typically in the evening. I hated the thought of taking Loratab the rest of my life but it allowed my to spend some decent time with my family. I was visiting with one of my old Army buddies and discussing health and he mentioned I should research and try Kratom he was taking it daily and in his words changed his life for the better and returned him back closer to the man he used to be and wanted to be. I researched it and gave it a try, completely changed my life i have been taking it since that was almost a year ago. Now I guess i will get into something a little more personal and private but i feel is very important. The very first side effect of type 2 diabetes i experienced was erectile dysfunction not something you really want to discuss or make public knowledge. My E.D. was sever and non responsive to treatment, I tried them all Viagra, Cialis, Levitra, combinations of them all under the direct supervision of a few Physicians, nothing worked. I was reduced to having to give myself an injection in the side of my Penis just before any sexual event and sometimes it would work sometimes it would not. I was in a really miserable situation with sexual function and only 41 years old. Since starting Kratom I have had a sexual life without the injections, it is the craziest thing. If i quit taking Kratom for 2 weeks I am back to giving myself an injection. One last important note I was spend a small fortune on medication over $500.00 a month, luckily i have a great job and good insurance, since kratom my medication monthly charge is less than $100.00. Kratom is a supplement in my mind not a medication that is taken for one or two ailments it is a total health and body supplement.

documents.commentText: I suffer from 3 herniated discs, one in the top of my spine, (t3) one in the middle, (t6) and one at the bottom (L3). The one in my lumbar is completely worn out, and is now bone on bone, and the nerve damage has begun. Without pain management, I walk around like a 70 year old man. I can't work more than a few hours, regardless of how many ibuprofen I take. I was prescribed percocet, and got up to 45 mg a day, and it wasn't helping for more than an hour. I was also prescribed muscle relaxers so I could sleep. Then the doctor decided I was taking too much percocet, so she cut me back to 30 mg a day, which didn't help at all anymore. So I stopped taking them, and got sick from withdrawals. Then I found kratom. Not only does it cost a fraction of what the opiate drugs do, this natural, simple supplement not only eased my withdrawal symptoms to a bearable level, it gave me energy and helped with the pain better than opiate drugs ever did. I was able to get up and get a job. I got off of government assistance and a 40 hour a week job in a warehouse. Because of the extra pain relief, I am also able to work hard enough to be tired, and pain free enough to fall asleep on time at night. Which helped my back even more, because I was able to get real rest, instead of tossing and turning in pain all night. It also helps my appetite. Since I stopped taking the opiate drugs, I've gone from 145 to 185. I'm six foot tall. This natural, unadulterated herbal supplement has given me my life back. If kratom gets banned, I'm back to being unable to work. And I'm not alone. The ban will cause a huge wave of medicaid and disability claims. The fact that it cannot ease opiate withdrawal symptoms, without causing that doped out high, and allow people who are addicted to heroin and all of it's "legal" cousins, to get away from dangerous and physically addictive drugs that are running their lives. It might be the very best tool in the world for combating the opiate addiction this country is in the midst of. If an herbal supplement capable of helping people get off of life threatening drugs gets banned, at this point, it would tell the world that the DEA is getting money from the pharmaceutical industry to keep people on dangerous opiate drugs. Please act in the interest of the American people, instead of the corporate dope dealers that are killing this country one dose at a time.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it may Concern,
  My Name is Thomas, age 33, currently working in a manufacturing plant with administrative duties. Since childhood, I have experienced challenges with anxiety and depression, including panic attacks. In 2005, I was rear-ended in an automobile accident and sustained neck and back injuries. I then traveled down a dark path of pain medication and addiction. With the help of the herb, Kratom, I was able to piece my life and relationships back together.  Kratom has had a very positive impact on my life in recent years and improved my quality of life for me.  I would ask you to reconsider your classification of Kratom as a Schedule 1 substance.

   An FDLE ( Florida Department of Law Enforcement) Report stated, after extensive research and analysis that:
    
       Based on its research, FDLE concluded that Kratom does not currently constitute a      significant risk to the safety and welfare of Florida residents. Additionally, the report   cites that the Florida Department of Health has found that there are no pervasive health issues can be attributed to the ingestion of Kratom products in Florida. (1)

 

  Within the last period of 60 days, there has been an outpouring of concern over the recent consideration of classifying Kratom as a schedule 1 substance. In further research, you will find that Kratom benefits the lives of many American citizens. Kratom consumers include but are not limited to, the elderly, chronic pain sufferers, those with PTSD, persons with severe anxiety disorder, depression. Simply put, Kratom deserves the chance for more research seeing as it has improved the lives of thousands of people who responsibly consume it as an herbal supplement.  

 

  Please, I and thousands of other responsible , law abiding citizen, as you to re-consider and or strike down the motion to classify Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug.

 

Sincerely,

TJT

 

 

 

 

(1) https://flsenate.gov/Session/Bill/2016/0073/Analyses/h0073a.CRJS.PDF

documents.commentText:
I'd like to add an important point on Kratom - the DEA listed one of the alleged adverse effects as seizures. I respectfully disagree. My reasoning is my own experience. I use Kratom for wellness, motivation and an all around positive natural force. I do also take Wellbutrin daily, which is prescribed by the VA to help me with PTSD resulting from my time in Afghanistan. Wellbutrin is well known for lowering the "seizure threshold" in human beings considerably; the max daily dose of Wellbutrin is 450mg/day; at this dose, patients have a 0.4% chance of having a seizure. At 600mg, that number jumps to 4% - so essentially for every 100 humans that consume 600mg of Wellbutrin in a day (theoretically) 4 of them will have seizures. DEA and other opponents of Kratom have alleged it contributed to seizures. I have consumed Kratom for 5 years. I have taken Wellbutrin (off and on) during that time, including as I write this. The Wellbutrin is used to treat my PTSD (as opposed to SSRI/SNRI which are far more harmful and can have very adverse effects). My consumption of Kratom is part of my own personal wellness plan which also includes a very dedicated exercise regimen and a health diet. In the entire period I have consumed Kratom, I have NEVER experienced a seizure (or any adverse effects, for that matter), including while taking Wellbutrin.

Kratom is an amazing plant and it should be embraced not banned. Again, I take Kratom to help maintain a consistent wellness. It has helped at home, at work and while continuing to serve our Country. Please keep it available as it has helped so many good Americans. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Recently, it has come to my attention that the USA DEA has proposed classifying mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, two constituents of the kratom plant, as schedule 1 substances. This statement is in response to the DEA's invitation for public comment concerning this issue.

I have personal experience consuming kratom for purposes mainly related to relaxation and anxiety reduction. As such I feel qualified to have a strong opinion on this matter.

I believe that classifying mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as schedule 1 substances would be a terrible mistake; depriving millions of people access to the benefits of this gift of nature and preventing much needed research on the its stress and pain relief properties.

Kratom simply does not meet the criteria for schedule 1 classification. As stated, I have experience consuming kratom. I have also had experience with truly addictive substances (I'm referring here to nicotine ~~ I'm an ex-smoker). Having this personal basis for comparison I can safely say that: 

1. Kratom is not addictive ~~ certainly not physiologically addictive in the same way as cigarettes, alcohol, and schedule 1 substances,

2. Kratom does not have a high potential for abuse,

3. It can be, and is, used safely and poses little danger to  the user, 

4. Is ~not~ currently associated with any known health risks,

5. And also, it has potential medical benefits including at the very least; pain-relief, stress-relief and anxiety reduction.

As such, Kratom simply does not meet any criteria for classification as a schedule 1 substance. It is far less of a potential health risk than existing schedule one substances, and, perhaps most importantly, it ~is~ associated with health benefits and has medicinal value. 

Therefore I strongly urge policy makers not to deprive millions of folks who safely and responsibly consume Kratom of the benefits of this naturally occurring bounty.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely, 

H. Nicholas Nagel

I am a 47 year old mother, daughter, sister... I once was a productive member of society. I managed physician offices as well as a surgical center. I am well versed with the medical community and the resources it offers. 
I have used many different natural alternatives through the years to help with various issues as well as pharmaceuticals. 
I have RA, Ulcerative Colitis, Gastritis, Fibromyalgia, DDD, as well as injuries from an automobile accident. Through the years, I have found my quality of life deteriorating as the physicians added more and more pharmaceuticals. The anti inflammatories have caused bleeding in my stomach and colon. The pain medication left be foggy, tired and incapable of functioning normally. I found myself spending more and more time in bed. 
My days were becoming torturous. I began looking for alternatives. Thats when I found Kratom. It has given me much better pain relief and dramatically improved the quality of my life. I no longer use opioids, anti inflammatories, or blood pressure medication. My depression and mood are much healthier. I no longer need a handful of pills; I have chosen to treat naturally and found it has dramatically less side effects compared to the synthetic components I was previously using. 
I understand that the FDA has suggested any use of kratom is considered abuse, because it is not FDA approved. I should be the person responsible for my health care decisions. I do not support scheduling Kratom or it's active alkaloids. I believe it's my choice to buy and use a tree leaf and decide what works best for me. 
I do not want to return to the pharmaceuticals that failed me. Kratom hurts no one and helps me to be a productive citizen again. This is supposed to be the land of the free. Spend your resources on getting dangerous drugs off the street. Kratom is not a drug nor is it dangerous. Kratom is my choice!

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Just want to first thank the DEA for going back to take the right steps before just taking away something so very important to so very many people.

My story is short, simple and started a long time ago. While in high school 2002-2006, I became very addicted to opiate medications that were prescribed (actually over prescribed) to my father after he fell off our roof in year 2000. Which sadly today has become a normal story for so many kids with easy access to such powerful medications. I got to the point I was stealing and taking everything I could from anyone and everyone i knew, money, pills, whatever. My relationship with my family was severely suffering because of it. It also left me with the most horrible anxiety one could ever have, hard to live a normal life with that....Luckily and by the grace of god around 2005-2006 i stumbled across a simple little at the time unknown herb called kratom or mitragyna speciosa, while looking for a way out, little did I know this simple herb would SAVE my life. I guarantee within a year, i would have been dead on the streets had I not found kratom, sadly I know that as a fact. It's now been 11 years now since i found kratom, I live a normal, healthy, happy life, I own my own business, I pay my taxes, I have stayed out of trouble, I have great relationships with friends and family and i would NOT be here if it weren't for kratom. Kratom didn't do it alone, but it was a very very important tool that helped me and continues to help me. Please don't take it away from me and the many thousands of others that have been helped and saved by it. We have one of the most horrible heroin/fentanyl/opiate crisis in America right now, that was created from over prescribing medications for so many years. If you take away kratom I can 1000% guarantee that crisis will explode 100 fold, to the likes of nothing we have seen yet. Why would you knowingly want to do that? Most who take kratom are responsible adults, that don't take it to get "high", they take it to help themselves live a better, HEALTHIER life, to work again, to be active again, to naturally and safely take their pain and anxiety away, to be able to spend time with their kids without being so drugged up on medications and in so much pain, they couldn't before.. Kratom isn't the threat you like to portray it as, i know it and many more thousands do also, i'm a living testament now 11 years later, I don't need the FDA or anyone else to tell me different. We don't need more and more pills being prescribed in america, that only poison our minds and our bodies, kratom doesn't do that. So please think of these people before you decide take such a wonderful life saving thing away. I'm afraid everything ive accomplished will go away should kratom be taken away, as are many more people.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madam-

I am writing with the purpose to make the point for maintaining the legality of a plant called "Kratom."  I have never been, nor will I ever be, an addict.  I was, at one point, bound to prescribed pain medications for a period of approximately 4 months due to a lower back injury.  Not knowing what addiction or dependence was, I took them steadily those 4 months while my back "healed," and, for the first 3 months, functioned quite well.  The 4th month I felt my strain had improved but found myself challenged to stop the medication.  I felt sick- depressed- miserable.  Not knowing why, I went to my physician, who then prescribed me 12mg of Suboxone.  Let's just say, mg for mg, the dosage was entirely too high and it became an even worse problem than ever before, taking a solid 3 years and 8 attempts to finally quit.  Since then, I've never touched a pain medication and, honestly, don't  like taking any medication.  
Not long ago it was recommended I try Kratom for my frequent migraines, as well as some other ailments I had.  "It's not a pain killer like you'd expect- you won't get high, you won't be euphoric, and you may still have some pain, but it's certainly a valuable tool for your arsenal," I was told.  Since then, I've taken Kratom here and there for headaches/migraines, back aches, and various other ailments.  I've used it for long periods of time and short periods of time, each phase stopping for breaks and never feeling miserable.  I've cut back on coffee from it!  I am a happier person because of it.  I've never felt like I was going to overdose (though once, when changing my vendor source, I did take more than usual and ending up puking twice before I felt normal, thus teaching me the valuable lesson "less is more."  I've also helped others discover the benefits of Kratom and have observed them go from pharmaceutical relief to natural relief.  WHat a difference it has made for them and myself.
I am all for regulating certain things, but to treat kratom like a vilified plant, making it a Schedule I and illegal to own or possess or consume, is not only a foolish mistake, but a violation of our rights as US citizens.  Alcohol kills more people, directly and indirectly, than kratom ever has or ever will, meanwhile has no true benefits that can be touted, whereas kratom has a wide array of benefits.  I see no reason to outlaw kratom and make it yet another street drug- which is exactly what will happen- for the police to deal with and to load up our prisons.

I want to share a quick story about myself, this botanical supplement, and about how the DEAs intent  to ban it would completely change my life for the worst. 

First, let me start by saying that I am by no means at a low point in my life right now. I am a young professional in his early thirties who has a full time career working in the biopharmaceutical consulting industry as an analyst. 

Kratom didnt do the work to get here for me; kratom just gave me the chance to do the work for myself! I have used this supplement for over a year and have experienced no dangerous effects from it, but I have benefited greatly from its existence!

I deal with chronic anxiety which has always crippled me in taking on important tasks. When you live with anxiety, every day you feel unclear in your thoughts. You feel stifled, afraid, and unsure of yourself. It is almost as if you are viewing the world through a filter, a haze that acts like a curtain to block you from taking any positive actions and from connecting with those around you. Kratom helped to remove that curtain! When it did, I felt a heavy weight had been lifted from my shoulders, allowing me to pursue new opportunities I would have previously been afraid of. I felt able to fully express myself to friends, family, and colleagues instead of constantly feeling mentally restrained. When I take kratom, nobody even knows I am using it  they only notice that I am making positive changes! Kratom helped give me a chance to take the actions necessary to grow and improve my life instead of continuing to live in a mental cell of anxiety and fear.

If you have made it this far, I want to thank you for taking the time to read my story and to please support the legal availability of kratom as a botanical supplement!

documents.commentText:
Hello,

Two years ago , I WAS addicted to herion.  During my time using. I attempted to quit many times, each time was unsuccessful due to the physical discomfort and the mental duress of withdrawal.  At the time I didn't have the money or insurance to get on methadone or suboxone, so it took to the Internet for answers to me problem. 
I tried a bunch of home remedies for withdrawals I found in drug forums. The unsuccesful remedies I tried were taking anti diearrea medicine to taking large quantities of vitamin C.
There was one suggestion I found that not only worked but changed my life.
You guessed it, KRATOM! 
I had to expierances with the plant.
The first, was picking up a professional packaged product from my local "head shop". It was in pill form and the package was brightly colored, I was skeptical because of the synthetic marijuana and bath salts that were previously sold at these kind of stores and sold in the similar brightly colored packages. 
The pack of pills really didn't so too much for me , it did take the edge off of my withdrawls but that's about it.

I then tried an online shop that was straight from the source, Indonesia or somewhere I can't remeber.  It was much cheaper, sold in higher quantities and came in powder form.
This product was much stronger.  It stopped 95% of my withdrawals, gave back all of my energy, gave me focus and drive again. 
I took this product for two months, when I stopped I had no withdrawls, from the herion or the Kratom.   During my time of Kratom, I felt great,  I was not impaired, it never got me high in the traditional sense, and I only had minor side effects.. The side effects were some constipation and some restlessness sleeping.  I was more than happy to have those occasional effects over having the laundry list of withdrawal symptoms from herion. 

I beg you, please reconsider making Kratom a schedule 1 drug.
I am certain it saved my life and it can save thousands more!

documents.commentText: When I heard that there was a possibility that Kratom may be unavailable I was devastated. I have done extensive research on its properties which are helping addicts successfully abstain from opiates. I've been a heroin addict since 2009, and am currently participating in a medicated assisted treatment plan at the methadone clinic in the city where I live. At first I was terrified. I didn't understand how opiates could help me get off of opiates. What I found was that it offered physical and mood stabilization and allowed me to organize my life, a mess from years of use, and bring myself out of chaos and into a scenario conducive to recovery. It's been effective, but its purpose has been fulfilled, and I'm looking to take my next step toward a life free of chemicals (prescribed or otherwise). It is my dream to exist as ME, and not a combination substance reactions. With my counselor and the help and wisdom from some friends who have had unfathomable success abstaining from opiates with Kratom, I've created an action plan consisting of a gentle methadone wean down and a transition to Suboxone then Kratom then freedom. A lot of people know about the physical withdrawal symptoms associated with opiates, but most aren't aware of the emotional state, the anhedonia (the inability to experience pleasure from activities usually found enjoyable), a sort of drug induced depression that is often the reason for relapse. Why bother being clean life seems vague and meaningless? Kratom can help with this. Kratom can help people free themselves from the prison of addiction. It hurts me a great deal to think about this plant's ability to save individuals from prison, rehab, and often times, death. It hurts me a great deal to imagine anyone taking this away from myself and other addicts, each on our individual quests toward abstinence. Addiction is winning. We've seen AA, NA, Narconon, Brighton Hospital, A Forever Recovery, Methadone Maintenance- all recovery programs I've tried along with hundreds of thousands of others.They have proved effective for a short period of time, if at all. We are well versed in what's not working. Opiate dependance is an epidemic, and we are consistently losing people (in the figurative and literal senses) who might otherwise contribute to the beauty and strength of our country. This is a potential path to individual transcendence, and a happier, more fulfilled populous. This is something that deserves the chance to prove its value in the world of  substance abuse.

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

You assholes allow monolithic pharmaceutical conglomerates to get thousands nightmarishly hooked on boundlessly terrible chemicals like buprenorphine and methadone (which, it's no secret, are far more addictive and equally as damaging to the brain and body as the illegal drugs which they're a supposed alternative/treatment to.) yet for a whole cornucopia of dumbass reasons, plan to outlaw fucking kratom?? For real? The only real reason I've seen is the amount of calls to poison control centers regarding kratom. While you're at it, make household cleaners, cough suppressants, caffeine, and motrin illegal too. Actually, wait: don't. Don't make any of these things illegal because it's a fucking stupid idea. Even more ludicrous than the prospect of prohibition. 
Kratom is a far more superior alternative to the two accepted substances I've listed above, because it doesn't get the user intoxicated or negatively euphoric, nor does it have an equivalently high likelihood of killing those who consume it. Oh, and, big, BIG benefit here: it's not satanically addictive! You don't have any idea what it's like to come off of methadone compared to heroin or oxycodone. I do. I've been there. I'm one of the type of people whose lives you'll be fucking up with your totalitarian bullshit. It takes a grueling two or three weeks to finish the acute detox of methadone or subutex. Heroin lasts five days, at most a week, and then it's over. You know how it's okay to be prescribed methadone or subutex to detox off of opiates? I've taken it maybe three out of the dozens of times I've detoxed, preferring to go cold turkey. Why? Because I don't want to prolong my horrid plight by taking those evil goddamn pharmaceuticals.  
Kratom, on the other hand, does not do what methadone and subutex do. It's a natural and non-opiate method of overcoming the excruciating detox symptoms of opiate addiction. Just like Iboga, only it's a little less radical, so you people should be okay with it. But you're not. Because you have no idea what you're doing.

documents.commentText:
I am a 53 year old woman, married for 30 years to my husband, mother of six children all still living at home. 

Last year I injured my back while exercising. I could not lie down or sit without terrible pain. And I had no insurance (I belonged to Samaritan Ministries, but one must pay out at least $300 in doctors bills for a condition before one can submit a need to them). Our household of 8 has an income of less than $30,000 a year, so I don't go to the doctor much.

I've always looked for the most natural remedy in any illness or injury, shying away from pills and drugs. So I did the same in this case. I researched natural pain remedies on the internet. 

When I came across kratom, I was surprised that I had never heard of it, and that it was being so widely used by people with chronic pain. I read quite a lot about it, that it was used by some for Generalized Anxiety Disorder, others for PTSD, and that it was also helping those addicted to prescription opiates and street drugs to recover from their use. It was inexpensive in its powdered leaf form, so I found a reputable retailer and ordered some. 

I took what is generally thought to be a low dose, and the relief was almost immediate. Within about 20 minutes the pain was greatly reduced, and within an hour I was amazed that I felt no pain. I could sit, walk, stand and go about the business of taking care of my six home-schooled kids. The relief was so thorough that I thought initially that the injury had miraculously healed.  I felt no pain for about 8 hours, and it's return was so gradual that I did't need to take anything more until the next day.  After about  a week I was healed enough to go back to just Ibuprofen for the residual pain. I didn't suffer any withdrawal sypmptoms at all. But kratom has become a valued addition to my natural medicine cabinet.

Taking too much one time (I was in a hurry and didn't measure, but just took it off a spoon) resulted in an "overdose" which made me nauseated and dizzy. I recovered within an hour. 

I've continued to read on it and recommend it to people I know who could use it. My sister uses it for fibromyagia pain and for anxiety.  My husband has used it  for pain as well. I think it is nothing less than a wonder. It is inexpensive and effective for at least 70% of those who've used it for pain. 

My guess it that the drive to make it a scheduled substance is fueled by the big pharmaceutical companies who make money from addicting people to prescription pain killers. They are studying kratom, and it will be only a matter of time until they create from it a drug that is dangerous, addictive, expensive and patented. Money is always the bottom line. In this country we tell our children that drugs are bad, but then every other TV commercial in the evening is for some kind of drug. 

I pray the DEA will rethink its position regarding the use of this natural supplement. I take zinc, Vitamin C and Echinacea when I'm coming down with a cold. My husband takes Hawthorn Berries for blood pressure and Red Yeast Rice for cholesterol. It is a good thing to have kratom on hand to use for pain.

I am a 34 year old mother of two (single), business owner/entrepreneur in which I own 2 individual businesses of 1) Handmade Artisan Exclusive One of a Kind Gemstone Jewelry & 2) Selling high end boutique clothing & fashion. Prior to this, I was a teacher for over 14 years. I obtained an Associate Degree of Science in 2009 & a Bachelor's of Executive Business Administration Degree in 2010 in an accelerated 12 month condensed program in a private Christian University. 
I discovered Kratom through my own extensive & meticulous research after a horrible head on collision (Miata ran a red light & totalled out my mother's Lexus) accident in 2012. I began my search after experiencing a host of musculature spasms in the shoulders & back from the impact of the wreck so much so I would be nauseous from the spasms & my muscles refused to release for upwards of an entire month. Not wanting to be dependent on pharmaceuticals, I searched for herbal remedies which led me to kratom tea. For the two years following the accident kratom helped to keep my pain from the strain of whiplash completely controllable to the point where I could go to work & enjoy life without the flare ups of my back/shoulders to bother me. I also noticed while drinking the tea that my PMS was dramatically reduced & mood was a lot more stable - something I've struggled with since puberty. It has now been nearly 5 years since the wreck & I am not taking kratom anymore because my state decided to ban it in May of 2016. I do occasionally experience flare-ups of muscles seizing about seasonally. I think what saddens me the most is I have no relief for the hormonal issues I go through every 23 days. I have tried everything from midol to Topamax to control the syspmtoms I experienced cycling & nothing helped except the kratom tea. Please do not take the right to choose away from American people. The majority of people that consume kratom lead a much better quality of life, they're nicer, more pleasant, more productive, happier citizens than they were beforehand & that counts for everything in my opinion. I urge you to educate yourselves with an unbiased information in order to make the best decision you possibly can. Who knows, maybe you or a loved one would benefit greatly from this amazing plant. 
Sincerely, 
A Concerned American Professional

documents.commentText:
My name is Joshua Rhodes, I am 31 years old, and I work at a Union factory in Cedar Rapids Iowa.
I found inner peace and freedom after I stumbled upon kratom during a Google search 5 years ago.
I've struggled with an interpersonal detachment disorder for as long as I can remember. My earliest childhood memories often replay as flashbacks from when I lived in an orphanage and resided with multiple foster families. I've encountered many forms of abuse the while growing up. Love did not come naturally to me and I've always felt disconnected to everything and everyone.
My sisters and I were all adopted out later on but we were all split up and we eventually lost connection with eachother.
I've trialled several different medications prescribed by my doctor to combat my anxiety and nervousness but nothing really helped me. I just went deeper into isolation and gave up the idea of treatment.
I attempted suicide in 2011 on Father's Day with my 45 Colt Revolver and it turned out I have a guardian angel. The gun slipped from underneath my chin, rolled forward, and penetrated my knee instead.
In consequence of this event I developed chronic pain from the gunshot wound and I was prescribed a powerful opioid painkiller alongside a strong anti-deppressant. This combination made everything worse and it wasn't long until I was tightly clenched into the jaws of addiction. 
I scrambled to find a natural alternative and I luckily found kratom. It curbed my pain and it dissolved my anxiety. For the first time in my life I felt like I could breathe effortlessly. This therapeutic tea had the power to lift me up without any unwanted side effects, and it effectively kept all of my demons at bay.
I improved on every level and even got half custody of my 7 year old daughter. We are living so well and are as happy as can be.
Please do not ban kratom. I've never been in trouble with the law, not even once. It would be a shame to look at how I got better as being a punishable crime.
I just want to live my life without this useful tool being ripped out of my hands.
Thank you for considering my comment on this matter.

documents.commentText:
Shortly after I turned 21 I became dependent on alcohol and started using it daily. I couldn't quite get to sleep or quell anxious thoughts without half a dozen drinks to quiet down. This legal drug has in the past few years damaged my health and will continue to, as I have had a doctor advise me that on my current path I will have a very serious conversation with him in about 5 years. Alcohol is legal and condoned in our society yet I have had a medical professional flat out tell me by the time I am 30 I will have some very serious complications due to my usage. Objectively speaking it makes no sense that such a dangerous substance linked to disease, domestic violence and motor vehicle fatalities should be legal while an obscure herb with very limited research should be classified as highly dangerous.

Kratom has given me an alternative to alcohol and serves as a stepping stone as I explore my own shortcomings, seek help and  reverse destructive behavior. Like anything else it has a potential to be misused but given there are far more harmful substances that are legal (alcohol, tobacco and trans fats to name a few), it is a disservice to the American people to ban something that may help transition from harmful ways of living.

It is my sincere hope that the DEA and FDA which we the people have entrusted to act in our best interest, objectively study and understand what this herb does before taking action to classify it as among the least useful and most harmful substances known to mankind. Having the experience I do, I highly doubt this will be the case and personally can speak to the usefulness of this herb. Many people with far more dangerous addictions vouch for this herb's usefulness and I am concerned that should it be classified as a dangerous and deadly substance, they will be left with no legal options to deal with their problems. This will affect all Americans in that illegal activity will increase, law enforcement will need to respond accordingly and ordinary citizens will live in a less safe America.

Please do your best to fairly and accurately assess Kratom's potential for therapeutic use and should it be harmful after all, please ensure consumers are informed. But before it's known, while it is helping so many people, please do not automatically default to assuming the worst of this seemingly very helpful medicine.

Thank you very much for your time and consideration.

Kind Regards,

J.S. Torres

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

Kratom saved my life. I strongly urge you to reconsider your stance on this herb. Like many, I developed an addiction to opiate painkillers. After multiple attempts to quit, and a great deal of pain, misery, and money, I heard about kratom. Three days of brewing kratom tea totally broke my physical dependency on opiates. I drank it three twice daily, and after that, I was able to simply stop. My experience is mirrored by countless people. I beg you not to withdraw this option --- there are so, so few options already.

If you investigate the kratom-related deaths, you will see that kratom itself is not implicated in them. It has long been used safely. It is less addictive than caffeine, let alone alcohol or tobacco. In addition, it has tremendous medicinal properties: as I said, it saved my life, which was spiraling out of control as prescription opiates took over my brain. It is too awful for me to contemplate what would have happened to me without this herb.

In addition, I have a friend who suffers from sever chronic pain caused by multiple sclerosis. Nothing has worked for her other than opiate painkillers --- which are strongly contra-indicated for long-term use --- and kratom. She uses it once or twice a week, when the pain is too much to take, and has been doing so for years with no adverse effects and no dependence.

Please, work with us here. We trust the government to look our for our wellbeing and to not implement restrictions that serve little good and actually do harm.

I am confident you will make the right call.

documents.commentText: I am writing in order to strongly oppose the scheduling of "kratom" as a dangerous drug.  I have years of personal experience with kratom that have been nothing but extremely positive.  I started eating small amounts of the ground leaf three years ago because I heard it was a healthy alternative to opioid pain medication.  I have multiple ruptured discs in both my cervical and lumbar spine that cause moderate to severe chronic, daily pain, but also love to lead an active lifestyle as well as keeping my thinking clear in order to be able to read, learn, and interact with intelligent people.  All opioids have made that impossible, plus they are highly addictive and get me into the opioid spiral where I build tolerance take more, build tolerance, etc., which can end up being lethal as we are reminded of every day.  Kratom has been a miracle in my life.  It has a powerful analgesic effect, enabling me to work on my feet for ten plus hours a day, come home and be a proper husband and father.  I have noticed no ill health effects whatsoever, there are no side effects that I have noticed that make me "high" or altered in any way other than a general sense of well being with a notable reduction in pain.  My work consists of either public speaking in a high paced, critical role, or fabricating ultra high-end yachts in the winter.  I can't do this with an unclear mind and kratom has never once interfered with my ability to do my job/s.  The only alternative to this safe, natural remedy to a problem that modern medicine has not figured out how to solve, is opiod pain medication which is accepting a life of being a drugged out zombie, SSI disability, lost relationships and possible death from drug overdose.  It is impossible to see why any agency responsible for ensuring the well being of US citizens would chose to outlaw kratom.  Please, please do not.

documents.commentText: I am a 37 year old disabled nurse. I worked critical care for a decade before becoming paralysed due to a spinal cord disease. I have been using Kratom for a little over a year now. I first learned about kratom through a chronic pain support group. I researched kratom for many months before trying kratom personally. There was a multitude of information available as well as many testimonials from both long term and short term users of kratom. The general concensus I found through my research was that kratom offered great pain relief, mild stimulation, very few side effects, zero respiratory depression, no known overdose amount, and very little evidence that kratom alone had caused any fatalities. I must say I was very sceptical at first. The claims seemed too good to be true. Is it possible that something can actually help with pain, provide a bit of extra energy, all without being highly addictive or mind altering? As a nurse I had encountered patients that had overdosed both on prescription and illegal street drugs. It was never a pretty site, or an easy road to recovery. The possibility that kratom offered a safe alternative, without the possibility of overdose is a fascinating find for people across the nation suffering from addiction or opiod dependency. But, in order for my opinion to be truly objective I felt it necessary to actually try kratom. My first step would be to consult my physician. It was no surprise that he had never heard of it, but after reviewing the chemical makeup of kratom he was intrigued. We began to taper down my opiod medication. Although he could not recommend kratom to me, he was well aware of my intentions. After I had successfully completed my taper program, I tried Kratom in a tea. I ordered from a vendor online who came highly recommended by the community and offered lab reports to prove that the kratom was pure without any adulterations. I consumed a teaspoon and was waiting patiently for the "rush" that would come from my opiod medications. One hour after consuming the tea, there was still no rush, but what I did find was that my pain was significantly lower, and my joints were easier to move. Was I totally out of pain? No, but I  did notice a difference. It was surprisingly long lived. While my medication would wear off 2 to 3 hours after taking them I found that the effects of kratom lasted 5 to 6 hours. I found that at a larger dose of one and one half teaspoon in the morning,  that my pain was controlled almost all day long. Best of all, there was no roller coaster effect happening for me. This is what happens when you take opiod medications, they peak and your pain significantly decreases for a short time, then as the meds begin to wear off the pain seems to come back stronger than before. Thus, causing the need for more medication to treat the same amount of pain as before. This builds up a tolerance and dependency to narcotic pain medication. After consuming kratom for over a year now, I can safely say that kratom does not produce this effect. When I found out that the DEA wanted to schedule kratom as a class 1, I was highly confused. Then I read the sensationalism and how it was being called incorrect labels like "synthetic" or  "opiod". So it became clear why the DEA was concerned. However, I believe the DEA to be held to a higher standard than just falling for the sensationalism. I believe that appropriate investigation into kratom and it's effects would have prevented the entire misunderstanding. I am not against an investigation by the fda either. I do think it is important to note that these investigations can take years to complete and for some people addicted to opiods, it's time they just don't have. Kratom and it's effects are so benign that it makes no sense to try and regulate something that is not harming anyone. We are a nation of free thinking, capable adults. We should enforce a buying age much like alcohol, and include the "not fda approved" stickers on the sale, and go about our business as a country. There are much bigger problems that the DEA and FDA should be spending their time and resources on. Make kratom consumption, like alcohol, the responsibility of the consumer. We cannot and should not regulate every single thing on this earth. It has been a huge failure to tax payers and the medical community to do this to marijuana. Let's not make the same mistake twice. I am including a link to a recent publication that backs up my personal experience with kratom and it's possible medicinal benefits that would be stiffened by a ban. If it is the intentions of the DEA to protect the people from harmful substances, please consider that a ban on kratom would have the opposite effect by forcing many people back on harmful narcotics that are responsible for thousands of deaths a year.    jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am a 41-year-old mother of three children, with Rheumatoid Arthritis and a neck injury which both cause chronic pain.  Kratom has been of immense benefit to me, allowing me to live a more active life, and be a more effective wife, mother, and participant in society (specifically as a volunteer in the school system).

Kratom has allowed me to quit taking the six medications I was taking to deal with pain, and difficulty sleeping (prescribed by SouthEast Pain Care--a reputable pain clinic here in Charlotte), and replace it with a three-times-a-day glass of  ground-up Kratom leaf mixed with orange juice.  I have been taking Kratom for three years, and my health has improved a great deal now that I am no longer on so many strong, prescription medications.  The labwork from my annual physical has come back looking perfect each time, so I have not personally seen any ill-effects from long-term use of Kratom.

I have stopped taking Kratom twice in the last three years (once when it looked like North Carolina might schedule it, and once when the DEA's emergency scheduling notification was released.)  Both times I wasn't taking it for 4+ weeks in a row.  I was able to quit Kratom "cold turkey" with no difficulty.  I had flu-ish feelings for about three days in a row both times, but it was orders of magnitude easier than when I stopped taking the daily Lortab and Soma that my Pain Clinic had me on.  

When I stopped taking Kratom out of fear of it being made illegal, I really realized just how helpful and effective it was, and what a negative difference not having it in my life made.  Both times, I found myself in too much pain to participate fully in my family and community.  I really missed the wonderful energy that I feel when using Kratom.  It was so much more difficult to get out and exercise, or play with my children, when I didn't have Kratom to help me deal with the severe fatigue that is a symptom of Rheumatoid Arthritis.  

If Kratom is made illegal in any way, I would lose a safe and healthy (in my experience) way to live a full and useful life.  Many people in America live with chronic pain, and taking away their right to use a beneficial plant is inhumane.  I do not want to have to go back to taking prescription opioid pain medication.  I felt much worse when taking it.  I ask you to please, please take the experience of law-abiding citizens like myself, who use Kratom safely every day, into account when making any decisions.  If you schedule Kratom, you will change my life for the worse in a very real, powerful way.

Thank you

documents.commentText:
This comment is regarding "Docket No. DEA-442W" and the DEA's desire to classify the plant, known colloquially as Kratom, a Schedule 1 drug, thereby making it illegal and declaring it has no medicinal effects. I find it disturbing enough that the DEA continues to classify Marijuana as Schedule 1 thereby promoting their ignorance (really, flat-out lying to the public) about its medicinal properties -- even though there is an abundance of scientific and anecdotal proof that shows otherwise. I do NOT want any of my PERSONAL IDENTIFICATION DETAILS MADE PUBLIC.

Now the DEA wants to misinform the public about Kratom, stealing from us yet again,  a safe, natural medicinal plant. Right in the middle of the much-hyped epidemic of abuse and death from legal opiods. I have personally experienced the wide-ranging, positive medicinal effects of Kratom (and marijuana). I have a slew of health problems, including chronic and severe full-body pain from Anklyosing Spondylitis and Fibromyalgia; migraines; chronic fatigue; ADD; Major Depressive Disorder; anxiety; bouts of insomnia; and TMJ, among other issues. I am in pain Every. Single. Day. I've been prescribed a plethora of Big Pharma medications, including - but not limited to - an array of anti-depressants, biologics (TNF-blockers), and painkillers. I self-weaned from 20mg morphine sulfate & 60 mg hydrocodone/day to no opiates. The painkillers helped a bit, but over the years, I became dependent - NOT ADDICTED - and had to increase dosages until I realized that there was a real potential for addiction. And I know the horrors of addiction - my younger brother was an addict for years. He's no longer addicted to opiates. He's dead. 

Kratom's analgesic properties have helped immensely with my physical pain. I'm not saying my pain has been eliminated; just greatly reduced. Other medicinal properties of this plant that I've experienced are decreased anxiety, decreased symptoms of depression, increased focus, increased motivation.... Again, I'm not proclaiming Kratom as a panacea or that it's cured my various diseases and disorders --- but it has helped me in many ways, as has marijuana, and I'm a nascent Kratom user. 

Please, please do not ban/outlaw/control this incredible plant. Please do not deprive the millions of Americans from having the option to use a natural resource to manage their various forms and levels of pain. Yes, I know opiates are *derived* from the poppy plant, but Kratom is used in its pure, original form. There is no evidence of abuse or addiction or deaths from correctly using Kratom. Shall I get started on the statistics of abuse/addiction/deaths from ALCOHOL or NICOTINE? You *know* it's not right to Schedule or Control Kratom -- or continue to proclaim, falsely, that Marijuana has no medicinal qualities. Do the right thing.

documents.commentText:
DEA please reconsider your intent to schedule the active alkaloids in kratom.  It appears the information you have is very outdated or may or may not be actually about the use of kratom.  Some of what is mentioned in the letter of intent looks like it came from the Thailand government in the 1940's when they outlawed kratom due to their financial loss when people would consume kratom as an alternative to or to help with quitting opium.  It also looks as though the side effects listed are not from kratom but likely from products that may have contained kratom along with synthetic opioids. Hallucinations and delusions are definitely not something that happens from consuming it. 

I have been using kratom in my daily routines for close to a decade for its relaxing and stimulating effects. I am an IT professional that has worked in the same field for 17 years.   Kratom does not even come close to the stimulant effects of caffeine but I would say that is more consistent in those effects helping one to stay awake and focused.  As far as it being relaxing it is probably less sedating than an antihistamine.  I see it as something that can help calm a mind down and allow someone to relax naturally and be able to fall asleep a bit more easily. 
At least allow more time and research before making this a final decision.

documents.commentText:
I am not like a lot of other people who found Kratom and used it to ease the suffering of  addiction. I am an average person simply looking for an alternative to coffee.
When used properly for me it's similar to drinking a cup of coffee in the morning but but has much less of a stimulating effect.  I don't like the way coffee makes me feel Very much and when I heard that Kratom was related to coffee, not illegal, and won't get you "screwed up" I decided to try it. Admittedly the first time I tried it I ignored a warning not to take more than 2 grams. 10 minutes after I got naucious and threw up, however since then I have been using Kratom for about 2 years. These are the things I have noticed from my personal experience.

1. It is similar to coffee but not as harsh on my body.
2. When the ban was coming I stopped drinking Kratom with no adverse side effects after nearly 2 years of daily use.
3. Overdose while possible starts with vomiting which was different to me than taking too many multivitamins, I experienced no other negative symptoms.
4. I have never experienced "coming down" or withdrawal sideeffects like I have with alcohol (hangover) or even coffee (fatigue sluggishness etc)
5. though not an alcoholic my desire to drink ANY alcohol diminished significantly over the course of two years. While I was abstinent from Kratom during the emergency ban period I found myself starting to opt in to having beers again and going to the bar. A similar thing happened with ciggaretts.

In conclusion I feel strongly that Kratom belongs in the supplement aisle or next to your morning coffee. It hasn't impeded my ability to function in any way and I feel that if more people have Kratom a chance they would find all the benefits I have received and more. thank you for taking the time to read this and wish you a good day.

Sincerely; Jason Kenniston

documents.commentText:
Greetings DEA!  Thank you for the opportunity to let the Kratom community give you our testimony, comments, and opinions.  This subject is so very important to so many of us, we are incredibly grateful for your discretion.

I am a welder by trade, and have gone to school to get as many certifications as possible to further my career in order to support my family.  My family is everything to me.  I make a modest living as a pipe welder, manufacturing machinery, big and small.  Three years ago, The pain started.  First in my knuckles, and moving to my hands, I did everything I could to push through the pain.  The sole provider for my family, I kept working for months in unbearable hand pain.  My welds suffered greatly.  My supervisors warned me of my work quality in greater urgency, until the pain made it to my shoulders.  At my worst point, I couldn't even hold the tools of my trade.  The tools that defined ME.  

I was told to visit a pain specialist and in the end, I was too weak to fight any longer.  I just wanted the ability to function.  To hold my daughter.  I made it through 8 different medications, most narcotic pain killers, with little effect.  Nothing worked.  It was only after thousands of dollars in medical bills, money I wasn't making, and a life without sleep, that I found Kratom from a new friend.  From the first time I tried Kratom, until today, I have found relief!  I cried the first day.  My life had returned to me.  I was able to work again.  I was able to swing my daughter in the park.  I was alive again.  It has been two of the best years of my life as a productive worker, -an active member of society, and a father.  

Please consider the potential RUIN a ban could affect on so many people like myself.  I would love to see more information about Kratom by reputable scientists.  How is it that this plant works for me when any number of toxic, narcotic, side-effect ridden pharmaceuticals could not?  The community as a whole is behind research.  Please rethink the mentality of scheduling Kratom as an illegal drug.  This is an herbal supplement.  

Thank you for taking the time to read this account of a humble blue collar American.  Please be there for me and those like me.

The worst pain I experience is when I lay down to sleep, the muscles through my neck and shoulders are so sore and I often get headaches from it.  I didn't want to be one of those people that was constantly going to a chiropractor or pain management to deal with this.  I don't want to be limited on what I can do because I'm stuck no pain meds for the rest of my life.  Then I found Kratom.  I use it only on the nights that are the worst, when I have the worst pain I drink a tea made with it and within thirty minutes the pain is gone.  I don't feel groggy, I am still fully coherent, and I don't experience any ill side effects.  I also don't feel hung over the next day after taking it. documents.commentText: I am a 36 year old male in Denver, Colorado. I started taking Kratom for pain relief when I had a herniated L5-S1 spinal disc causing extreme sciatica in my right leg in January 2016. I was prescribed Percocet and Valium while I was in physical therapy, and while I would take the Percocet for episodes of extreme pain, the Percocet would sometimes make me a bit spacey, for lack of a better term. I found that what worked best for me was a daily dose of 1 teaspoon Kratom powder with 220 mg of naproxen sodium. This provided enough pain relief without any noticeable mental effects that I was able to get back to work while recovering, and after 4 months, my recovery had progressed to the point that I no longer felt the Kratom was necessary, and I was able to stop taking it without any noticeable side effects. I still have the occasional episode of painful back spasms, but when that happens, I know that the Kratom/naproxen mixture makes the pain tolerable enough for me to do the physical therapy stretches and exercises. The only negative experience I've had with Kratom was one time when I took 2 teaspoons of powder, and all that did was make me nauseous and light-headed. Had Kratom not been available to me, I would have taken quite a bit more Percocet. Whether I would have become addicted to it, I can't say, but I can say that my Percocet usage never became heavy because I was able to take Kratom instead.

documents.commentText:
I would like to submit this comment against the DEA's proposed ban on kratom for the following reasons:

1) Banning kratom expands the unsuccessful, destructive "war on drugs," while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
2) If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
3) Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
4) Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
5) Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
6) Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

  I have been a user of Mitragyna Speciosa for the past two years of my life. Before I delve into a bit of anecdotal evidence about what the plant has done for me, allow me to give a bit of background about myself.

  I am a software developer and pharmacology student who has and still does suffer from numerous mental and physical conditions. As a result of a sports injury, I have chronic shoulder pain. In addition, I also have Generalized Anxiety Disorder and Autism. In my field, communication with others is integral to your success as a team, and as a business.

  Originally, I attempted supplementing caffeine to ease the trouble of my mental disorders, and to increase my productivity at work. (I found that my pain was not bad enough to warrant strong opiates at this time). Caffeine worked pretty well, although it came with some negative side effects. It would overstimulate me, in both a mental and physical sense. It was bad for my blood pressure, and it raised my resting heartrate to nearly 100BPM after continuous use. 

  Over time, I became physically addicted to caffeine, choosing to go through the caffeine withdrawal. Having used various substances throughout my life, I will tell you that this withdrawal was far-and-away the most painful, agonizing drug-induced dysphoria of my life. So, I let my conditions go untreated, which effected my personal and professional relationships negatively.
 
  A while after this, I discovered kratom. Skeptical at first, as kratom itself is physically and mentally addictive (as it has light action on the mu-opiod receptor), I proceeded with trepidation. However, I found it to be a harmless enough substance to supplement daily. After a few months of use, my anxiety was nearly nonexistent, I had the energy to complete my work day and be available after work, and it was even helping my pain!

  I knowingly chose to become addicted to this supplement, as it was helping my life in such a dramatically positive way. This led to one of the most fruitful and stress-free periods in my life. Years later, I still choose to remain on this substance rather than seeking out scheduled chemicals. Besides minor constipation, I have not noted any negative mental or physical side effects. 200mg of Magnesium Citrate daily alleviates this. My physicals with my doctor have even been better than the period of my life where I was abusing caffeine. On top of all of this, the withdrawal from kratom only causes insomnia for me - not horrible headaches, crying fits, and anxiety like caffeine caused me.

  I urge whomever may read this: let people like me have an option. Give us the freedom to better our lives rather than banning yet another innocuous herb. Alternatively, I may urge you to ban the Coffee bean, Yerba Mate, or Cola to remain consistent in your legislation. Caffeine, a chemical that over half of Americans remain dependent on, does more harm and less good than this plant that you are proposing to ban.

  I appreciate the time you have invested in considering my comment.

kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

documents.commentText:
Greetings from Wahington state!
I need the DEA and other federal agencies to know how much kratom leaf has changed my life for the better.  I am 39 years old.  Non-smoker, rare drinker, no other recreational drug use. I have a couple of years of college under my belt, as well as numerous industrial trade school certificates. I am a well adjusted, productive member of society.  I was born with some congenital defects in the bone structure of both feet.  I also suffer from mild depression.  The foot issues never really held me back until I reached puberty & grew quickly and these defects started to cause unimaginable pain.  I grew up to be nearly 6'5" and in my early 20's I underwent a grueling series of reconstructive surgeries on the bones & tendons of both feet.  My doctors had always been fairly liberal with hydrocodone & tramadol prescriptions.  In my mid 20s, I realized I had become highly addicted to opioid pain medication.  It was either be in terrible pain, or be in slightly less pain in a fog of dangerous doctor-prescribed painkillers.  As much as my body told me I needed pain meds, they still didn't begin to touch the level of pain I was in.  I managed to limit myself to tramadol & asked my doctors to prescribe less.  Still, up until 2 years ago, I was still taking tramadol daily.  Tramadol is not the 'less addictive' med that it claims to be.  The stuff is terribly addictive and comes with a host of unpleasant side effects.  A friend who is knowledgeable about holistic medicine suggested I try kratom.  Thanks to kratom, I've been 100% free of pain medication for over 2 years.   Daily, responsible kratom use freed me from antidepressants as well. I believe that limiting kratom access to adults would be irresponsible and dangerous.  Our country faces a ridiculously tragic epidemic of RX drug abuse & dependence.  I know people who have died from taking too much Oxycontin because of unbearable pain from serious illness, which was legitimately prescribed by their doctor.  In the face of a well-documented RX drug epidemic, banning a simple tree leaf (related to coffee) would be absolute madness.   I am 39 and am employed full time at a very physical job.  Kratom has benefitted my body and mind.  I am able to get up in the morning without using a cane or holding onto the walls to walk to the shower.  I wake up rested & my pain is less than 50% of what it was when I was still taking tramadol.  
Kratom DOES NOT make a person high.  Good, unadulterated kratom from reputable retailers has a subtle mood boosting quality & noticeable pain relief effects.  In 2014, before I started using kratom, I was taking no less than SEVEN doctor prescribed medications.  Now in 2016, I take heartburn medicine & the occasional aspirin when my pain becomes more severe or work is especially tough.  I am one of thousands (if not more) responsible adults who have chosen to make kratom a part of my daily life.  I have never been high on kratom, no matter how much I have consumed, I have never experienced a single negative or unpleasant side effect from consuming kratom.  I always tell people that good kratom feels like taking a few aspirin and drinking some strong green tea.  The DEA has made a very good decision in not pursuing the emergency ban.  Because in regard to kratom, there simply is no emergency.   How many calls to poison control are caused by energy drinks? Alcohol?  How many lives are shattered by Rx drug use & abuse?  How many emergency hospital visits are a direct result of side effects or overdose of prescribed medications?  The statistics do not lie.  I am so very thankful to the US DEA for listening to the American Kratom Association, and pain patients like myself.  Kratom is a safe, unprecedented natural medicine that is very safe in its natural, unadulterated form.  I don't know what I would do if my access to kratom was taken from me by way of a poorly researched ban. I do know that many kratom users suffer far worse than I do, & if banned, many people might turn to either prescription narcotics or other illegal drugs.  I also believe if kratom were banned, the suicide rate of many pain patients would rise.  My pain is manageable, but there are many folks who are worse off than myself, physically and mentally.
If we as a nation were to ban mitragyna speciosa, then we should ban alcohol, cigarettes, e cigarettes, energy drinks, coffee and cough syrup. These things all do far more damage to families and individuals than mitragyna speciosa, or kratom.  It gives me hope in our country's government to see than the men & women of the DEA have listened to stories like mine and taken the time to research the benefits of kratom, before going through with a ban that I believe to be dangerous, irresponsible and against the freedom of choice we hold so dear in our great nation.
Thank you so much for your time.
-Aaron R. Lee
Washington state kratom user.

documents.commentText:
I think it's absurd that banning kratom has even been suggested. I can walk into GNC right now & choose from a variety of supplements, many of which have known to have negative side effects. I can go to any gas station & buy cigarettes, which have literally killed millions. I can go to any almost any grocery store & buy alcohol- which, like cigarettes, have killed millions either directly or through the reckless inebriation of other people. Yet it is being suggested that kratom- a plant that's been safely used in other countries for ages- is just so dangerous that adults shouldn't have the option to choose whether or not they use it. Kratom has been the cause of NO deaths, when taken alone. Hundreds of thousands of people (medical staff, military veterans, police officers, recovering addicts, professionals, etc) have spoken out loudly to make sure people know how much kratom has helped them or the people they know & love. 
So to recap- 
Cigarettes: kill millions, no known positive effects- legal for age 18+
Alcohol: kill millions, no known positive effects- legal for age 21+
Kratom: kills no one, positive effects include increased energy, positive mood, helps insomnia, decreased anxiety & depression, effective for pain management, has helped thousands of people get off or avoid opiates- may stop being accessible.

Hi my name is John.  I'm a 43 yr old Journalist.  I've been following and researching kratom for 2 yrs.  Based on my journalistic research and personal experience I think banning kratom would be a huge mistake.  Kratom has been helping people live a better quality of life through a very safe herbal supplement.  Restricting the people's access would be a violation of civil liberties and is nothing more than political grandstanding by the DEA.  With little evidence to support claims of kratom being an "imminent threat"  the DEA and Chuck Rosenburg push forward their agenda in order to look tough.  Kratom is not part of the problem it is part of the solution. 

I started using Kratom 2-3 years ago to help me sleep.  Every night of my life I would toss, turn in bed getting not enough sleep. I could not even be comfortable enough to sit on the sofa and watch a movie with my wife.  Please imagine how these things would affect any person's desire for a normal life.  This went on for nearly 15 years.  I came to try kratom by purchasing it over the counter (OTC) at a local nutrition store.  It had a very profound effect on me.  I was able to sleep much better, improved interpersonal skills with my spouse and I returned to being a fully function and contributing member of society.  I just put 1 teaspoon in a cup of cocoa at night while sitting on the sofa and watching tv with my wife. 

I urge you to keep kratom available OTC so Americans can express their freedom to choose.  

This letter from the CRE to the DEA touches on more persuasive scientific and legal reason why scheduling kratom is not in our best interest.  Thanks for your time.

documents.commentText: I suffer from chronic back pain from scoliosis (a curvature of the spine) and kratom has helped relieve my pain without the use of more addictive and harmful forms of painkillers. Adding kratom to any of the five drug schedules would do nothing but make criminals out of normal human beings looking for a healthy way to relieve pain or anxiety. documents.commentText:
We respectfully request that you NOT ban kratom for the following reasons:

1) Banning kratom expands the war on drugs which is a failure and the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

2) If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind   
    bars.

3) Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain 
    reliever and opioid replacement.

4) Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising 
    scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down by making it a scheduled 
    substance.

5) The side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to 
     the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

6) Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose which has now become an 
    epidemic.

Please do not make Kratom a scheduled drug. It is NOT an opiate and does not have the same harmful effects.  Kratom is a plant and should not be banned or scheduled in any manner.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
As you know, the DEA plans to place two chemical compounds found in the Kratom plant in the Schedule I category at the end of September. These two compounds are: Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine
According to the DEA website, Schedule I drugs have no currently accepted medical use, they state this on their website here: https://www.dea.gov/druginfo/ds.shtml
The two compounds that the DEA is scheduling, are currently used in a commercial medicine called Tramasol: tramasol.com/howdoesitwork.html
This Supreme Court ruling cleary states that a substance may not be scheduled if the Secretary of Health and Human Services recommends that in not be: https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/osg/briefs/1990/01/01/sg900272.txt
Therefore, I am contacting you to request that your agency recommend against scheduling these two chemical compounds.
All it takes is one letter from you and the ban is stopped. Obviously the chemicals don't fit the requirements of a Schedule I drug, not only because its currently used in a commercial medicine, but extensive medical use testing has been done on the alkaloids found in Kratom and has been proven to be effective for a variety uses: appft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PG01&p=1&u=/netahtml/PTO/srchnum.html&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=%2220090221623%22.PGNR.&OS=DN/20090221623&RS=DN/20090221623
There has not been a single death backed by forensic evidence that Kratom or the alkaloids in Kratom were the specific cause of death. There are documented side effects as with any substance. I believe that allowing this plant and/or it's component alkaloids to be scheduled at this time would be a disservice to millions of American citizens who could benefit from further research and development of medical applications.

Thank you, respectfully yours, Ben
