documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

A very close friend of mine hurt his back a few years back and was prescribed loads of opioids.  His journey through addiction, graduating to heroin and overdosing multiple times would have almost certainly killed him if it were not for Kratom.  After another near fatal overdose, he was desperate to get clean and his friends and family had been scared to find this wonderful person dead one day.  It was a very scary time for us.  Through research, he found hundreds of threads online of people getting clean from opioids through Kratom substitution.  After about six months of using Kratom to ween himself off of heroin, he is now completely substance free and the happiest he has been in years.  I should also mention that he does not even use/need the Kratom anymore.  His ambition has skyrocketed since finding Kratom and turning his life around.  He is now making a good living on his own and is very grateful to be alive.  

From the research I have done myself as a cautious individual, I cannot find absolutely any justification to take this away from people and let them just continue dying.  The active ingredient itself (Mytragynine) does not actually attach itself to the opioid receptors, but only stimulates them and floats around.  As for the legal opioids, they drill themselves into opioid receptors like a screw and require extreme difficulty to quit taking.  

Please do not make the literal fatal mistake of taking this away from people, just so big pharma can go and make it addictive and expensive.  Clearly, there are already Pharma Companies trying to take advantage of this for money and have no concern for the welfare of the general public.  

I trust you will make the correct decision.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText: To whom it may concern: Please reconsider placing Keaton on Controlled Substance, Schedule 1 listing. I have finally found something that is natural, affordable and not a big pharma product. Here is some of my history as a chronic pain sufferer. I was an active person, running marathons and enjoying all outdoor sports. One day in 2002, I happened to lean over to pick something up and hurt my back. After many months, tests and diagnosed with degenative disc disease and was finally scheduled for my first back surgery. I had some pain relief for a year.  The pain returned worse then previous, 24/7. All types of medications were tried by my dr. Steroid injections were also tried along with epileptic drugs, antidepressants, pain meds with no relief. I had given up of any kind of "life". Could only work part time, used all sick and vacation time to supplement my pay. Elected for a more evasive back surgery with fusion of L5/S1 in 2007. Titanium rods, cage and screws. No guarantee of success. I was lucky. I was excited for a new, no pain/ reduced pain type of life and tried to resume a "normal" life. After a couple of months I started to have fatigue, all over tenderness, migraines, foggy brain and a long list of other ailments. Now dr appts were more frequent. As a runner I was on no medication. Dr continue to treat me with multiple meds without relief. Increasing pain meds. In June of 2009, I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia and chronic pain syndrome. In addition I was diagnosed with disc disease in my neck C5-C7 and upper back T4-T7 since. My life has never been the same. I have exhausted all sick and vacation time. Have not taken a vacation since. I have not pulled a full Paycheck in over 4 1/2 yrs.  My previous long time dr prescribed Oxycontin, Percocet, valium, etc together. These did not work either. I thought even to get a medical card for Marijuana but never liked it or feeling "high". I have since changed drs and have gotten off all these drugs. I have tried chiropractic, Bowen, meditation, physical therapy, Reiki, acupuncture, essential oils, over counter pain creams and lots of Tylenol, to name just a few. I can't take Aleve or naproxen due to stomach issues.  I don't get much sleep, I am in pain constantly, I am no longer social and don't accept invitations to functions anymore for fear of disappointing friends/family when I hurt to much to attend and have to cancel. Chores don't get done after work or on weekends due to being exhausted with fighting pain all day with horrific migraines. Recently, I have started to be able to walk the dog after work, go grocery shopping, make it through work with a smile throughout the day due to a friend that also has chronic illness' and had a friend that suggested a herb called Kratom. Did some research and thought to give it a try, couldn't hurt was my thought. Now that I have found this change to my life, I find that this maybe taken away. Again, having the rug pulled out from underneath me. I am 57 years old now. Will still need to work many more years.  I have lived in pain and a hell that only some can understand or have empathy. I want continued increased better health instead of going on disability will limited income. I want to be able to enjoy and play with my granddaughter who will be born in April 2017. This can only happen if I am able to purchase Kratom legally. Or do I become a grandmother that has a terrible secret, that lies and can't set a good example for my granddaughter. Please take this item off your hit list. I was fortunate to not become an addict from the multitude of pain meds.  This is my shortened version of my life history with chronic pain.

My name is Daniel A. Watson. I am 29 years old and I am a Paramedic in a rural community in Northern New York State. During my EMS career I have seen many overdoses from heroin and prescription opiates. This is not a problem limited to urban areas. In a community with more cows than people we still see these cases weekly. 

From hearing different people in my community and through social media, I have learned that Kratom may be beneficial to those with opiate addictions. All too often our "frequent fliers" go away to rehab only to relapse again. If Kratom can help these people then I believe and opportunity for more research should be taken, and the Scheduling of Kratom should be held off until there are more studies about the helpful and possible harmful effects of this plant. 

I am opposed to the Scheduling of this plant and its alkaloids at this time.

documents.commentText:
I am commenting on the Kratom ban as I believe banning such a substance will do little to curb it's use and just create an endless prosecution of those who have safely used the substance for years. As we claim to live in "the land of the free" why does the government (aka the people of this country) feel the need to regulate substances and tell others what they can or cannot do with their bodies by using criminal laws to do so. If we truly are "the land of the free", why don't we own up to that motto and allow people to take personally responsibility for the decisions they make and the drugs and substances they chose to put into their own bodies. I personally feel that the government nor anyone else should try to stop someone from using or abusing a substance through the use of laws and the criminal justice system. Drug abuse is an issue of education and public health and making someone a criminal in an attempt to stop them from committing a nonviolent crime that hurts no one but themselves does nothing but: 1. waist taxpayer money 2. waste law enforcement resources that can be put to better use (IE. solving murders, rapes, and other violent crimes) and 3. ruins the person's life by adding a misdemeanor or felony to their record thus making them unemployable. 

After a person has a criminal record, their life continues a hopeless downward spiral and then perpetuates further drug use because they can no longer find decent employment and feel more hopeless thus pushing them to give up and move back to drugs. Drug abuse will never be controlled nor contained by using our brave men and women in our law enforcement agencies to try and stop the impossible. Just as prostitution is morally wrong in the views of many people including myself, I don't have any thought or hope that making it illegal and trying to arrest the problem away will have even a sliver of success. The same holds true for drugs and drug abuse. All we are doing is ruining people's lives further by turning them into criminals for what should be considered a disease treated through the heath care and rehabilitation systems. 

As I have tremendous respect for the men and women of law enforcement, I ask that these brave people be allowed to focus on violent crimes that require brilliant minds to solve and help victims desperately in need of their help. By focusing so much effort to try and eradicate a problem that simply will never be solved, we are taking away resources from solving violent crimes and giving victims of violent crimes the closure they seek. Those who use and/or abuse drugs make a conscious choice that only effects themselves and can decide to stop and seek help when they are ready to do so. Until then, turning these people into criminals further pushes them into the shadows and isolates them from society as "criminals" who are not worthy of being helped or rehabilitated. Let's all agree that criminalizing nonviolent behaviors will never solve drug abuse issues just as it has never solved prostitution as long as humans have walked on the earth. 

There are countries such as Portugal who have decriminalized drug use and have had tremendous success as a result. Drug abuse has gone down while current addicts have stepped out of the shadows to seek help since they are no longer "criminals". When you crack down on one particular drug, another just takes it's place. I compare it to the game whack a mole. I ask that the government please stop banning substances and allow Americans to make their own free choices even if they are bad for the person as making a substance illegal has done nothing but further damage the person and their situation. Let's make people accountable for their own actions which in turn will drive them to seek help on their own when they need it rather than hiding from the law and working a menial job for the rest of their lives because they have obtained a criminal record as a result of a sickness. 

I am all for prosecuting those who commit violent crimes against others and give our brave men and women the time and focus to help victims of such crimes.  Let's stop trying to wage war on behaviors that do nothing but hurt the individual who choses to engage in them and help that person when he or she decides to seek help. Let's also not brand them for the rest of their lives with a scarlet letter in the form of a criminal record so employers forever reject such a person at a time when they need a job and reason to move on. I ask that you please - no I beg - that you please do not make Kratom illegal and consider decriminalizing all other drugs so we can take power away from the illegal cartels and drug dealers and give those with a sickness the opportunity to come out of the shadows and seek the help they need. 

Let's please truly make this the "home of the free" and give individuals the freedom to make their own choices good or bad as long as it doesn't hurt another person. Thank you for listening to my comments.

I have a new lease on life and I'm finally  the person I've been wanting to be.  
I have 5 friends since then that became clean once trying Kratom.  All legal suboxone dependents.  If you're going to consider banning a substance, YOU SHOULD BAN SUBOXONE, because it is so harmful.  It ruins lives and doctors won't change because it makes them money.  Please keep Kratom safe and legal so it can continue to help heal people!  It's my godsend!  

Sincerely, ALM

documents.commentText: Please leave kratom alone and do not schedule it.  Many of us rely on this wonderful plant.  I was injured in a domestic violence incident that left me with a broken spine.  The surgery to fix it failed and left me with an incurable and incredibly painful condition known as arachnoiditis,  and set off fibromyalgia too.  Now I also have arthritis and hypothyroidism.  I don't have insurance.  Prescription pain medications are very expensive these days and only getting more expensive every year.  I cannot walk without my meds but I also cannot afford the meds that I was on before I had to stop working.  Kratom greatly helps my daily functionality and let's me use less medication.  I have small grandchildren to raise and a small business to run from home.  I absolutely have to be able to walk and semi-function.  Kratom helps me do that and I wouldn't be able to without it.  It's just one of the many tools I use in my chronic pain toolbox but every tool has it's purpose.  If we lose kratom I lose my ability to walk without a cane.  I'm only 44, not 84. My condition will only continue to progress and get worse.  I may eventually be in a wheelchair.  Let me walk now while I can.  Kratom is not hurting anyone.  It's HELPING!!  Taking this away from those of us who need it would be cruel.  Nature gave it to us to use if needed.  Let us use it.  It's been safely used for centuries in countries like Indonesia and their economy also relies on it. I've seen thousands of people change their lives for the better thanks to kratom.  This is a gift!  It's helping people get away from addictive substances.  Our country has an addiction crisis and unfortunately chronic pain patients are paying the intimate price now and being left with no medication they legitimately need.  Kratom helps the addicts AND the chronic pain community.  Leave it alone.  This country needs it more now than ever.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA -

I have the deepest respect for the DEA and the efforts they exhibit for the safety of Americans, but I urge the DEA to take a deeper look at the true effects of Kratom usage.  Most people who use kratom are not teenage thrill seekers but they are like myself.  I am a sixty year old audio professional and sound designer who works for Lincoln Center, New York City Opera and many other well know organizations.  I have been using plain leaf kratom very successfully for the passed eight years to control my depression and anxiety issues.  My doctors have had me on Lexapro, Paxil, Wellbutrin and several other ADs but none of them have the positive effect that kratom has had for me and without the nasty side effects attributed to those ADs.  I was introduced to kratom by by efforts to get off of the opioid pain killers that I had become addicted to after surgery.  Kratom helped me ween off off the hydrocodone and retake my life.  When I stopped the kratom use, the depression and anxiety that I had experienced before returned, so I started using kratom again and I have been a far more productive member of society and a better father and husband that I was without it!.  I do appreciate that extracts of kratom can be used in nasty head-shop formulas, but it is very short sighted to ban the entire plant and lose all the benefits that responsible users have gained due to this small number of miscreants.  We do not ban the cocoa plant and all its products because it is the source of crack cocaine.  We must have a similar approach to Kratom so that we do not screw responsible users with serious pain management needs due to a small number of irresponsible idiots!

Furthermore, kratom is essential in helping this country get grips on the Opioid crisis we are in.  To ban kratom and take this away from opioid addicts who are trying to reagin control of their lives is short sighted and irresponsible.  

PLEASE, for the sake of the health of our nation, DO NOT make kratom a Schedule One substance.  It is far too valuable and for too effective and far too SAFE to be treated like heroine and LSD.

Thank you for your time and service to our people,

Sincerely,

David Meschter

documents.commentText:
I'm probably in the minority of people who have submitted comments. I don't have chronic pain, PTSD, debilitating anxiety, alcoholism, or any other condition that is remedied by the use of kratom. If kratom is made illegal, I won't be forced to take street drugs or dangerous pharmaceuticals or slide into a life of manic depressive, alcoholic decline. My life won't be ruined if the DEA oversteps its bounds and makes this benign botanical illegal. I suppose I should feel lucky in that regard.

I merely take kratom the way I take coffee (a close relative of kratom), Red Bull, or a fifteen-minute power nap -- as a relatively mild way to boost my energy and make it through my busy day of being a full-time husband, father, financial analyst, freelance writer, and law-abiding citizen. 

I've been taking kratom in moderation for three years and have never experienced anything remotely close to a "high." Had I taken kratom expecting a legal high, I would have been sorely disappointed. In my experience, kratom doesn't get you any "higher" than a Starbucks latte. 

Compared to the thousands of Americans whose lives have been saved by kratom, I don't  really have a horse in the race, so to speak. The absence of kratom would have minimal impact on my life. The real reason I'm commenting on this issue is to echo what tens of thousands of citizens and dozens of elected Congressional officials have already told you: you are overreaching your grasp by waging war against this nontoxic tree. With due respect, please back off and allow Americans to decide for themselves what works best in their own unique life situations. 

Kratom has not been an imminent threat to the public for the thousands of years it has been used around the world. And those who need it are not criminals. Neither are those among us who merely want it.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Cody, I am 30 years old, and I work full time for a paint manufacturer in Portland Oregon making batches of paint that is used throughout the United States and Canada.

I am writing this comment to voice my opposition to the proposed banning of Kratom, as I think it is an overzealous move by the DEA to demonize a plant which has been used by millions of people worldwide for hundreds of years for various reasons. Banning Kratom would not benefit anyone, it would only hurt hundreds of thousands of people in the United States whom rely on Kratom for one reason or another. It would also send many of those same people into a downward spiral in which they seek out actual drugs which are, and should be, illegal. It would also send many others (like myself) back to the doctor in order to find relief from opiate based medications, which nearly destroyed my life. Banning Kratom is only going to worsen the problems that our beloved country is facing with narcotics, and I fully believe that Kratom could actually benefit that problem by giving people a safe alternative.

I started using Kratom 7 years ago to relieve severe pain I was suffering due to Carpal Tunnel Syndrome and a bad back, both of which I got working for UPS in my early twenties, and a back injury which I received while enrolled in the Oregon Youth National Guard Challenge Program in Bend, Oregon as a teenager.

Taking Kratom has helped me remain active, work a full time job, be a full time father to my kids, and also go to school at nights full time. Without Kratom, I wouldn't have the energy or will to be able to do all of those things, and I might not even be able to work due to the pain I suffer from. Kratom is a relative of the Coffee Plant, and taking a dose of Kratom is much like drinking a really strong cup of Coffee. I have taken, and been dependent, on hard prescription painkillers before --- Oxycodone, Morphine, Vicodin, all of those things my doctor pushed on me when I was younger because there was no other alternative and Marijuana was illegal in my state at the time. Even though Marijuana is no longer illegal in the State of Oregon or Washington, I do not take it because I hate the way it makes me all doped up and slow. I cannot afford to be high in my line of work, or as a father and student. Kratom allows me energy and pain relief without the intoxicating effects of other drugs, and I am fully in control and competent when I take it.

Anyone who has taken Kratom can attest to these statements, and it is my belief that the DEA should retract any and all plans to ban this plant, and spend money to actually have scientific studies performed so that these claims can be verified, and so that the DEA will have concrete facts to base any decisions off.
Kratom is a wonder plant which should be embraced and supported by the world. It is not a silver bullet to the drug epidemic, and it never will be --- but it is a good start, and a step in the right direction.

Sincerely,

Cody Hanson

documents.commentText:
Hello,

As a medical and pharmacology-student, I have often recommended Kratom to patients (outside of the workplace) as it relieves their pain in a way many Schedule II and III drugs are unable to do so. Due to its availability over the counter, I recommend that they try this perfectly legal herbal supplement. 

I have had many patients comment that the pain relief they receive from taking various Kratom leaf and tinctures is superior to that of high dose morphine or 75mcg/hr Fentanyl patches. I have had many reports of considerably less drowsiness and fatigue. I have also been told that nausea, a common side-effect of chemotherapy, is not a contributing factor.

This legal and over the counter substance has many, many great uses. Whether an individual takes small doses to assist with their GAD (Generalized Anxiety Disorder) or severe pain (due to cancer treatment) all I have heard is positive reviews. Truly the only negative review I have heard is that the taste is foul.

I believe that many patients will be harmed by scheduling this substance. This is not the same type of substance as "bath salts" that cause hallucinations and strange behavior. Kratom binds to similar sites in the brain that block pain and increase dopamine production; additionally, this herb is used by many native tribes across the glove and has been used for hundreds of years. Certain tribes of Native Americans/United States (First Nations/Canada) are permitted the used of Peyote and other hallucinogenic drugs.

Thus far, no evidence has been shown that Kratom has any carcinogenic effect nor does it harm the body. At the first worst, taking too much Kratom may induce nausea. 

Please head my warning that Kratom is a very useful substance that will not lead to some form of pandemic of addiction. The users and researches of Kratom that I know quite well and follow have not show nor found any of the typical behavior of a drug addict.

Finally, many individuals have used this substance in order to desist the use of harder and more dangerous drugs such as diamorphine (Heroin), Oxycodone (Oxycontin, Diludid (Hydromorphone), etc. To remove this avenue of recovery would only increase the usage of these substances while creating a whole new means of arresting and incarcerating individuals that merely wish to relieve their pain, anxiety, and addiction.

A study has shown that even Marijuana itself, now legal for recreational use in several States within the U.S.A., is more addictive.

First and foremost, in my response to the possible regulation and addition of Kratom as a controlled substance according to the DEA, I would just like to say: KRATOM IS A PLANT. It is not a dangerous substance and does not cause death to anyone. Even the plant marijuana has been regulated by the government and made legal in many states. That's about the only way the two are comparable, however, because kratom is not nearly as widely known or used as marijuana. However, it a plant substance and the properties for which it is sought after are as follows: "Some of the most interesting health benefits of kratom leaves include their ability to lower blood pressure, relieve pain, boost metabolism, increase sexual energy, improve the immune system, prevent diabetes, ease anxiety, help with addiction, eliminate stress, and induce healthy sleep." (article via organicfacts.com). 
Whatever possible "high" or "rush" it causes people, depending on their body chemistry and their dosage (WHICH BY THE WAY IS CLEARLY SUGGESTED AND STATED UPON PURCHASE OF SAID PRODUCT OR CAN BE EASILY SEARCHED ONLINE) is not an unsafe or uncontrolled affect whatsoever. No one loses mind control; in fact, when too much is taken (too much=exceeding recommended amounts based on various desired affects) the person will simply fall asleep, similar to that of melatonin (vitamin). 
My personal experience with kratom was never more than a tbsp. which was like a caffeine buzz for me, which is what any average person gets from a LEGAL cup of coffee. Shall we regulate caffeine through the DEA as well?! It's caused many more harmful and lasting side effects than the plant Kratom. I found when I took a bit more, it served as a wonderful natural analgesic for my migraines, and helped me to fall asleep pain-free and relaxed, without the use of any harmful drugs. 
The only possible reason the DEA could be trying to regulate Kratom is for money; people medicating themselves in an herbal manner doesn't make the government as much money as it does when they're slanging prescription drugs, which can potentially cause addiction and other long-lasting bodily harm to humans. 
I'm a 26 year old hospitality worker; I've been in the service industry since I was 15 and am currently a server. Marijuana was just made recreationally legal here in Vegas where I currently reside, however, I am not able to medicate in that manner due to all the drug testing in the Union here. Kratom allows for me to not take drugs or spend tons of money on prescription drugs that had terrible side effects. It doesn't harm me at all, and I don't take it all the time. I've recommended it to friends who were not educated on the matter and have received nothing but good feedback. I'm always trying to make healthy decisions and find the next-best foods, vitamins, and herb-based remedies! Taking Kratom away seems completely heinous.

My name is Joe Mancini. I'm a 29 year old television producer. First and foremost, as an American I oppose the DEAs effort to make kratom a schedule 1 controlled substance because I believe we should have the freedom to do what we wish with our bodies, particularly when there is no evidence that the substance in question is dangerous or a public health threat. To me, it is sufficiently evident that kratom has enhanced the quality of life for many people, whether as an agent of pain management or a tool to reduce anxiety and manage opiate addiction. Furthermore, the dramatic scheduling of kratom will preclude any formal study and scientific research that may help us to better understand it.

I began using kratom nearly two and a half years ago. Prior, I had been addicted to pain pills and while I had already quit using them, I found that kratom -- even in very moderate use -- helped the cravings to subside and allowed me to focus on rebuilding my life. I've successfully re-established my career, I've become creative and productive again, and best of all, I am free of narcotics and able to nurture my relationships without destructive habits and distractions. I cannot give sole credit to the dried leaves of the kratom tree, but I do think it's harmless, natural aid that should remain available to those who might benefit from it. I consider myself a privileged person who has been fortunate and able to bounce back from my troubles, but others suffer more and are not so fortunate. As a society we should seek to provide them with the option to improve themselves of their own volition.

My name is Lisa, I am 46 years old with 3 grown children and 2 grandchildren, and I work retail, mainly unloading warehouse trucks and stocking. I am writing to ask that you reconsider scheduling or banning the herb mitragyna speciosa, also known as Kratom. I first learned of this plant through 2 of my children, both recovering addicts, one from heroin and crystal meth, the other a 4 year Suboxone dependency as a result of painkiller abuse and heroin. They did not tell me immediately of their kratom use, assuming I would think they were just replacing one drug for another. But I research things, intensely, and the more I learned, the more I liked this plant. It helps ease the horribly intense and painful withdrawals of opiates, it is a natural alternative to opiates for those suffering chronic pain, it has no known health issues to vital organs, such as the liver, like opiates do. In fact, I liked what I found so much that I tried it for myself, as it is great for improving mood and severe anxiety issues, for which I have been taking pharmaceuticals on and off most of my 46 years. I also found it helps with my muscle aches and pains from my job, which is quite grueling most days, much heavy lifting and constantly on my feet. But more importantly, my children have their lives back. My daughter has been free of Suboxone for 8 months with the help of Kratom, for the first time in 4 years. She is confident enough to go to work and finally function as a productive adult at 26 years old. She is finally, for the first time, getting her driver's licence, something so small to most but has been an incredibly daunting task for her, much like leaving her own home. My son has been drug free for nearly 4 months. I was certain the last 2 years of speedballing heroin and meth would kill him. I hated the sound of my phone ringing, just knowing, this is the call, this is the day my oldest, my firstborn, my only son, had finally accidentally overdosed and killed himself. Kratom is the only thing that helped with his withdrawals and the only thing preventing him from using these deadly drugs. Please, I implore you, do not put my children at risk by banning this plant, because that is indeed what is inevitable. Addiction is a horrible disease, and so many do not make it out. But this plant, Kratom, makes it possible to help break that vicious circle, and return to a normal life again. Please help my family live, and live our lives to the fullest. Every person deserves that. 

Thank you,

Lisa Lanier

documents.commentText:
I am a non-binary transgender, Hispanic, disabled person. It is my sincerely held religious belief that plants are given to us by nature's God for the healing of our mind, body, and spirit. Many share this belief, and I speak for all of us.

In November 2013 I was diagnosed with synovial sarcoma, a rare and aggressive cancer, and was given just a few years to live. The tumor was in my left arm, inner elbow, entangled with the nerves. After pursuing numerous alternative treatments, I was forced to have my left arm amputated above the elbow in May 2015, ostensibly to save my life. Since becoming disabled I have used various natural botanicals rather than drugs to help with my constant phantom pain, which feels like a rock crushing your arm that is no longer there. Prescription drugs had undesirable effects and did not heal me, so I turned to plants. Kratom is one such plant that I have found relief from, as well as kava, often in combination. I am writing to urge you to not place kratom or any other plant on Schedule 1, or any other drug schedule. There is no public benefit to this, and it would hurt people like myself who have found some relief from kratom, often used in combination with other plants. Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars for simply trying to relieve their pain. Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose. 

I implore you, do not schedule kratom, or any other plant. All currently unscheduled plants in their natural form as created by nature's God should be specifically excluded from enforcement under the controlled substances act. Please consider using your executive enforcement discretion to halt all current and future actions regarding any plants that are not currently scheduled.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it.

Kratom is a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do. Kratom uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

documents.commentText:
TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN...

Hello, my name is Evan Bradley Johnson. I am 24 years old. Currently I am working on a Bachelor's in Social Work at Bloomsburg University of Pennsylvania. I will be graduating this coming spring. I plan to pursue a career in either substance abuse treatment or in medical social work.

I am greatly opposed to the DEA's decision to categorize kratom as a schedule 1 drug. I believe that such a decision will have immediate negative repercussions that will damage the lives of thousands of American citizens. Here are just a few examples of the damages that may occur:

1.) Taking away kratom will reduce the productivity of people who use it to help with pain.
2.) Banning this plant will make responsible adults who use it into criminals which can damage opportunities for employment, stigmatize them, and subject them to financial difficulty due to fines.
3.) Banning kratom will open up a dangerous black market for it and thus extend and complicate the war on drugs.
4.) America is in the midst of an opiate abuse crisis. People have used kratom to help them escape opiate and other forms of addiction. 

As someone who will be working in addiction treatment, I find it disturbing that something that could be saving lives is so easily taken away. I also must note that things like alcohol, Tylenol, and even peanuts have been directly responsible for more fatalities than Kratom, and they are readily available. _Source: Center for Disease Control_

I began using kratom quite recently (summer '16). I heard about its potential to promote a good mood and an energetic yet relaxed mindset. I work a part time job at McDonald's and also part time at my father's steel fabrication shop to support myself while I finish my final college courses. I will be working an unpaid internship this spring and so I need to save money. The bottom line is that I work A LOT. Since my jobs are very fast-paced or physical, I am often exhausted at the end of my shifts and the last thing I usually want to do is school work. I will often make a kratom tea to help reinvigorate myself and get the motivation to get my school work done.

I also must note that am an alcoholic. Alcohol almost killed me several times and led to various legal problems: DUI, public intoxication, and disorderly conduct. The irony here is that alcohol is completely legal. Kratom is absolutely no alternative to treatment, but in my case it promoted a sense of well-being and has helped me remain sober. I believe I may not be as productive as I am now if it were not for kratom.

It is for these reasons why I wholeheartedly believe that kratom should not be taken away from Americans who benefit so greatly from it.

Sincerely,
Evan B. Johnson

I am disabled and I also work part-time.  I have had back issues for as long as I can remember.  I had my first surgery when I was 15 years old.  My second when I was 20.  I had 2 more back surgeries, one in 2010 and one in 2012, and both hips replaced within a 5-yr period.  So, I am no stranger to pain or pain medications.  I have always tried to manage my pain with other things such as massage, therapy and exercise, as well as prescriptions.  My brother introduced me to kratom several years ago and it has helped me stay off of narcotics.  It doesn't have the side effects some of the medicines I have taken in the past do and has GOOD side effects (such as helping clear sinuses and helping with irritability) unlike pharmaceuticals.  I am a mother and even consider it safe enough to give my older children (in small quantities) for things like toothaches or menstrual cramps.  This has done nothing but help me and several in my family manage pain and other issues without addictive drugs.  

I am a contributing member of society with children and jobs and responsibilities.  I am pretty sure that is not the case with heroine or cocaine users.  Please do not take this very useful, non addictive, harmless, natural remedy away from us.  It is from the leaves of a tree in the coffee family!! The last time I checked we lived in a free country and I should be able to decide for myself if I want to take something like this for my pain so that I can continue to contribute to my family and society.

Hello,
  My wife became addicted to opiate based pain pills in the years following the birth of our son(2011). She had daily migraines. She was prescribed many drugs; opiates, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and saw 9 different doctors, all of which only offered more drugs as a solution. My wife, in the end was a mess- addicted to pain relievers and dependant on a plethora of other pills to cope with the still persisting headaches and now growing anxiety issues. We became disenfranchised with the medical community and started looking for our own answers. After great length we came across the dietary supplement Kratom and learned of its reported success in helping opioid addicts.  My wife began taking Kratom and over a short time was able to stop the daily use of opioids for pain relief. She also noticed a reduction of her anxiety in conjunction with the Kratom, and over the next year she stripped away her pill dependencies until she was taking only Kratom as a daily dietary supplement.
 In 2013 after searching for answers from all fields of medicine my wife was taking 5 prescription drugs all with significant side effects and detriment to her long term well being. She was still suffering. After finding Kratom in the fall of 2013, fast forward 2 years and she is now drug free, only using Kratom as needed as a semi-regular supplement.
  I have seen 'hard drug's and have known those who have struggled with them and fallen to them first hand. These experiences include having a friend die from the addiction to prescribed opiates. Kratom is no schedule 1 drug. It is not harmful even in the hands of fools. Please do what is right for people, for humanity do not be influenced by the money and myths of big pharmaceutical.

documents.commentText:
I am 40 years old, a single mother to 2 wonderful and extremely active children, but so many times I haven't had the ability to be the mother I want to be because my body is constantly fighting me.  I have Systemic Lupus, Fibromyalgia, Ascending Thoracic Aneurysm, Endometriosis, Severe Asthma and Allergies.  In order to just be around to see my children grown up, I take a myriad of pills and see multiple specialists to fight back to a body that hates me.  I live in constant pain, debilitating fatigue, fight to breathe, constant sickness and that all causes depression and anxiety.  I have no control over my body.  I have no control over the symptoms the 20 plus different medications I have to take every day just to stay alive,.  I've lost friends.  I mourn my old self, but most of all I mourn the fact that I miss out on parts of my children's lives due to my body giving out on me a different way, every single day.  

I've been prescribed strong opiates to combat the pain.  But those only work for so long before I need more and more to even be able to get out of bed.  I've seen people fight addiction.  I do not want to be that person. The usage of those almost killed me with the way they affect my liver.  

I was introduced to Kratom from a fellow Lupus sufferer as medical marijuana is not legal in my state.  Nor do I really want to take marijuana because of the way it makes me feel and I'm still not able to be the parent I need to be or really work.  

From the first time I tried Kratom, I felt better than I had felt in years.  I have the energy to work full time and be a productive member of society.  I love being able to work.  It has improved my mood, depression, anxiety, lowered my blood pressure which is important so I won't have to have open heart surgery. It has given me the best rest I have had in years.  Without the ability to use Kratom, I believe my myriad of diseases will kill me within the next 5 years if not sooner.  

I am happier, am able to practice football and softball with my children, I am a better employee, a better friend, daughter, sister, aunt, niece and co-worker.  Kratom has become my saving grace.  My will to live has returned.  My zest for life has returned.  I have been able to stop taking some of the medications that cause even worse side effects than what they are trying to 'help.'  I love that its natural.  I truly believe that if Kratom is banned, people will die, end up in jail for just trying to live a normal life and the people that have absolutely no control over their bodies will just give up.  

I'm just a mom that wants to watch her children and someday grandchildren have wonderful lives.  Please don't take my son and daughter's rock away from them.  They need me, I need them and I need Kratom.  I have my life back and don't want to get back to that dark place I was when I was ready to give up.  

Please keep mine and everyone else's story about how Kratom has saved them when thinking of banning it.   All we want is a better quality of life with something natural, not synthetic.  As an American, we live in the land of the free and the brave.  People that are as passionate and have such a zest for life that need Kratom to make that happen will make this country a better place.  We deserve that. American needs that.

documents.commentText:
As a physician from Oklahoma (Board Certified in Psychiatry and Child and Adolescent Psychiatry), I want to register my strong opposition to the proposal to ban the plant Kratom. I belive this plant has considerable potential for benefit and very low risk of harm (less than OTC NSAIDS). A ban would not only remove it from legal use by people who have found it benificial but would also stifle much needed research. It could also have unintended consequences (such as  emergence of adulterated black market products and potential drive to substitute legal and illegal opiates).

     I have some personal experience with this plant substance: I suffered an acute spinal injury about 3,years ago and was in great physical pain for several months. I used Kratom to lessen my use of narcotics. I believe it helped me get through my ordeal with less dependance on opiates and minimal opiate withdrawl when I stopped needing pain medication. I was made aware of Kratom by a young man who had used it in his (successful) battle to kick heroin addiction. 

     I ask the DEA to carefully weigh the evidence and the opinions of scientific researchers, medical practitioners, and those who have personal experience with Kratom. "Thank you" to those who helped open this to public comment instead of rushing to a hasty decision.

documents.commentText:
I will try and keep this short as I know there will be thousands sent in. My experience with kratom was due to having chronic pain issues. But not just pain, I had digestive issues concerning pudendal nerve entrapment and pelvic floor dyssynergia. I had a horrendous symptom called tenesmus, which is the constant urge to defecate. My life quickly spiraled downward as you can imagine. I woke up each morning having diarreah every 15 minutes, and after that i had theconstant urge even though there wouldnt be anything left. I was literally running to the toilet 30 times a day. For a couple months, I suffered day in an day out, losing 30 pounds I already could not afford from constant diarreah, anxiety attacks, insomnia, extreme depression, suicidal thoughts and the persistent pain in my ass, literally.

I then found kratom. First time I tried it, I was completely alleviated of all my symptoms for 4-5 hours. This was a miracle! Nothing else helped. I tried diet changes, physical therapy, yoga exercises, chiropractic care all to no avail. I saw many doctors and had many tests done during this time, but no one could figure me out. At least I could function and go back to work, eat enough, no more anxiety attacks or suicidal tendencies, all of this due to kratom. It truly saved my life. I was seriously contemplating suicide before this and the pain pills they gave me barely touched the pain.

For the next 1.5 years, I was dependent on kratom, although still seeking medical treatment. My doctors agreed to keep taking the kratom until we found something else as it was keeping me from pooping at a hazardous constancy and consistency that would severely dehydrate me. I held onto hope that there would be an answer, and kratom held onto my hand and guided me through the misery and shielded me from the worst.

After 1.5 years, I found a new medication that worked wonders called Amitryptiline for my form of pudendal nerve IBS/pelvic floor dyssynergia and pain. I also took ibuprofen as needed daily, but the digestive issues were cured finally. Over the past 6 months, I am down to 1 ibuprofen a day and cut my Amitryptiline dose in half along with no more kratom. I will soon be completely in remission. I wouldn't have made it this far without kratom.

It's safe in the sense you can't overdose on it, the worst that happened to me was nausea if I took too much, nothing too bad. I did have withdrawals when I quit cold turkey, but wasn't anything I needed medical treatment for. I did it on my own dropping from a heavy habit of 30 grams a day since the new medicine was working. Withdrawals aren't dangerous like alcohol and harder opiates can be, but they sure weren't enjoyable. I think it's safe to say withdrawals are akin to quitting a very heavy marijuana and coffee habit at once.

I do believe that kratom should be regulated to some extent, similar to how tobacco is. Considering alcohol and tobacco are legal, there is no way that kratom shouldn't be either. If anything, chronic pain patients and people with harder addictions have a RIGHT to use kratom. This plant has saved so many lives and denying access for people who truly need it like I used to, is a cruel sin. Many people will suffer and die due to pain and addiction if kratom is banned completely. I think you guys understand this though, so I will spare the lecture and finish my story. I know you have the best intentions for our country and believe you will do the right thing. I am grateful to have a country that is at least looking out for our best interests and for that I thank you. :)

documents.commentText:
My name is Sarah Woods. I'm a 46-year old woman from Carolina Beach NC, and I'd like to voice my concern about the possible de-legalization of kratom.

I began using kratom about 6 months ago, primarily to treat my peripheral neuropathy, which causes me a great deal of pain and discomfort. Prescription drugs such as Gabapentin and Cymbalta were ineffective, and I was very discouraged, thinking that I had run out of options and was going to simply have to endure the limitations of my disease.

After hearing about kratom online, I decided to give it a try, even though I was dubious. To my great surprise and relief, it works tremendously well! My pain level is almost nil. I am now sleeping through the night, which is something I haven't done in years. I'm performing much better at my job, and have the ability to exercise and participate in athletics like I did before my diagnosis.

I have also had problems in my life with substance abuse (specifically, alcoholism), and depression and anxiety. Kratom alleviated these as well. It elevates my mood and helps my focus and clarity. It also lessens my craving for alcohol substantially, and my cravings had always been a huge obstacle to staying sober. I have now been sober for over five months, which is something that had you asked me six months ago, I would have said was impossible.

I really feel like I have my life back. It's so novel to be virtually pain-free when you've been in nearly constant pain for years! I have a better relationship with my friends and family and actually look forward to the future, which is a feeling that had been slipping away from me for years. After I started taking kratom, I kept waiting for the other shoe to drop  it just seemed too good to be true  but the shoe never did. Kratom is also very affordable and I have experienced no ill-effects. I'm still on the same daily dosage I was on when I began taking it.

I would be devastated if legislation made kratom unavailable to me. The quality of my life would plummet, and I don't believe that any medical options are available that are as effective as kratom has been for me.

Kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important medicinal uses and has changed my life, so I'm asking you to please keep it legal and available.

If you have questions about kratom, please visit www.americankratom.org. Thank you for your time and service.

Sincerely,
Sarah Woods

documents.commentText:
I am commenting on the recent proposal to make kratom (mytragina Speciosa) a Schedule 1 Controlled substance, Docket No. DEA-442W.  This tree leaf brewed in a tea has proven to be a benign all-natural pain reliever over hundreds of years (in S.E.Asia and Indonesia) and more recently in the USA. I have used it for both migraine headache relief, and for help with a clinically diagnosed depression.  In both cases it seem miraculous to me--providing real relief in both cases, yet not leaving me foggy, or drugged-feeling, in any way.  Especially in the case of my depression, which did not react well to the classic SSRIs.  Yet kratom helped lift my depression--without any unpleasant side effects!--and allowed be to return to work. It saved my life then.  Please don't take this away from those of us who might need this simple, marvelous plant.

Kratom is not an intoxicant.  It simply is not.  Thanks the beauty of it. To link it to heroin and LSD is so wrong-headed as to beggar the imagination.  It's a modest herb, related to the coffee plant, that provides pain relief for those with chronic conditions.  It was of enormous benefit to me in both of those capacities some years ago.  I beseech you to at least allow for further research before this seemingly uniformed reclassification takes place.

Thank you for allowing a public feedback period.  It means a lot.  Kratom gave me my life back, and this benefit shouldn't be denied to others by rescheduling mytragina as a heroin-like drug.  Please think of the people when you make this decision.

documents.commentText:
My name is Holly Currier, I am a 24-year-old resident of Andover, MA. I am a substitute teacher in special education, an intern with a groundbreaking positive youth development program, and I am finishing a self-directed study on the psychosocial roots of addiction in my community as my undergraduate capstone project. I will be graduating in two weeks with an interdisciplinary degree in the cognitive and social sciences with concentrations in social psychology, addiction theory, criminology, and youth studies. I am vehemently opposed to placing kratom on the list of Scheduled substances, especially Schedule I.

I began taking kratom three years ago. Prior to taking kratom, the life I have now did not seem possible. After a progressive decline in my health that led me to being functionally home-bound by what was ultimately diagnosed as chronic fatigue and fibromyalgia, I failed out of college and could not work. Since my health decline I have taken countless pharmacological and complementary measures were taken to try and improve my quality of life. Some formal interventions have marginally improved my condition but nothing seemed to be turning my condition around enough to get a job or even take an online class, I was still mostly home-bound.

I ordered kratom using from a vetted vendor after reading about it on a pain forum. I paid for it with Christmas money. My mother brought the package to my bedroom, I took a half of a teaspoon, and didnt think much of it until I looked at the clock after showering and realized that I was up and moving before 3pm. Normally I would be tired after a shower, this day I wasnt. Kratom quickly became a part of my complementary wellness regimen. I began substitute teaching after four months and taking online classes within six months. In December 2015, my college took me back. I can function reasonably with less pain and fatigue now. It took a lot of work, and kratom gave me that extra push.

In the time that I was trying to rebuild my life, I saw countless friends, classmates, and roommates fall into the downward spiral of addiction. It takes more than two hands to count the number of my peers from high school and college who have died of opioid overdoses. It would take two more hands to count the number of youth from my hometown who have also died. I am researching addiction because of these young people, I want to do what I can to prevent even just one more person from ending up in the ground before their parents. 

 It breaks my heart to know that a plant in the coffee family that has helped my quality of life maybe could have saved theirs by placating their opioid receptors to help support recovery and sobriety. Placing kratom in the Schedule I category would hinder research into this plants potential to help those of us struggling with pain and those of us struggling with addiction. I now carry narcan on my person because of the number of friends I have who have struggled with opiates and for my fear of coming across an overdose in a public restroom or a parked car. Narcan isnt enough.

I fear that those who are currently using kratom to support their sobriety will face the possibility of relapse. I fear that those who use it to assist with pain could become suicidal or turn to demonstrably dangerous street narcotics out of desperation -many in the kratom community forums have expressed these fears for themselves. Banning kratom, even temporarily, would cause an imminent threat to public safety, productivity, and even commerce. Respectfully, what would the American population and economy look like if coffee was scheduled tomorrow? 

I have never been suspected of, arrested, or prosecuted for a crime. Kratom has supported my ability to serve my community, complete my studies, and retain gainful employment. My bad days are not as devastating as they once were. Placing kratom on the Schedule I list would place myself and countless other Americans in the position of choosing between continuing my life as a law-abiding citizen, and having a semblance of a quality of life. I have never experienced adverse effects from kratom, never withdrawal. I cant go back to being housebound, and I cant let my community down. 

I hope that we can address any remaining health concerns without affecting kratom consumers who are benefiting from it.

documents.commentText:
I just learned of the DEA's proposal to ban kratom and found this news to be very disturbing. I cannot fathom how the DEA can make a determination that use of a natural herb needs to be banned based on virtually no evidence of harm to the public. Over the counter pain killers and even peanuts and other foods that people are commonly allergic to are easily shown to cause more harm to the public health. 

Kratom is not a drug, it is a simple herb that has helped millions of people and there is little credible evidence that it has harmed anyone. The 16 deaths that have been attributed to its use over a 6 year period is not conclusive and is dwarfed by the number of deaths attributed conclusively to many other legal substances. 

Until credible evidence of actual and significantly greater harm than peanuts pose to the public, a ban on kratom is an over reach of power. At all levels of government, we the People are starting to wonder if this is truly a government "For the People; By the People." Banning and criminalizing the sale and use of what is essentially a herbal tea with no evidence of public harm when the public has not called for it and, in fact, those who  benefit from the sale and use of it spoke up against it is not, "For the public good."

As a law abiding citizen, I implore our Government to respect the will of the public it governs. The public has not asked you to criminalize this. The vast majority of the public are not even aware of this "dangerous" herb because there has been no significant impact to the public health in spite of the millions of people who do use it.  Do not ban herbals that are less dangerous than peanuts.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

To Whom it May Concern,
  My name is AJ and I have been using Kratom for over four years.  I began using it in January of 2012.  In September of 2010 I was in a car accident which crushed my left knee and left elbow.  After many surgeries which resulted in my having various pins inserted to hold my bones in place, I was given many prescriptions for narcotic painkillers.  I quickly became dependent on these painkillers and I developed a horrendous addiction. Not only that, but the various side effects wreaked havoc on my body. Doctor after doctor gave me different pain medicines to try, weaning me off one only to give me another. I felt I had no real control in the matter as my chronic knee and elbow pain made it difficult to work, get exercise and generally have a decent quality of life.
  On October 3rd, 2012, I attempted suicide but stopped at the last minute.  I was attempting suicide because my addiction had led me to lose my job, my partner, as well as my relationship with my family and friends.  I was isolated, had dropped out of college and had no money left. I tried to detox a few times on my own but finally decided to seek professional help in January of 2012.     
  After checking myself into a detox center, someone there told me about kratom.  I went and bought some online and within 12 hours of using some my pain had gone from it's usual 7 to a 4. Not only that, but I felt energized and motivated.  This, in turn, led me to find a part-time job rather than relying on disability and unemployment which I had nearly exhausted.  
  Then I had a full-time job, then I went back to college, then I graduated and got a real job in my field.  During this time, I used kratom twice a day (4.5 grams in the morning and evening) and was able to repair my relationship with my friends and family.  I eventually went to graduate school and got my Master's degree; I also met an incredible woman who is now my best friend, partner and roommate. 
  Kratom was what helped me control my pain and get enough energy to begin a virtuous cycle that hasn't stopped in the 4 years I've been using this incredible herb.  Where pharmaceuticals failed, Kratom did not. 
   Banning Kratom while keeping pharmaceutical narcotics legal is only going to worsen the opiate epidemic.  I can easily overdose on narcotic pain killers but I cannot on Kratom.  I can also easily destroy my life again with pain killers and yet Kratom has done the exact opposite for me. So, in closing, I strongly urge you the reconsider this ban as well as the evidence behind it.
                         Sincerely,
                         AJ
          AJ

USING UNDER 10 GRAMS A DAY GIVES ME ZERO ADVERSE EFFECTS.


9. In conclusion... Please....please do not take this amazing plant from us. Of course as with anything there is a potential for abuse. But eat enough IMMODIUM pills and it will get you high. Soak poppy seeds in lemon water...and it gets you high. Brew kava kava root and it intoxicates you. Eat enough cold medicine...it will get you high. documents.commentText:
I am a college English teacher. I'm also one of millions of Americans suffering from debilitating chronic pain. I've lived with symptoms of various autoimmune diseases for over half of my life, beginning in adolescence. My diagnoses include advanced/severe ankylosing spondylitis with axial psoriatic arthritis & a myriad of comorbid conditions, complications, & symptoms, such as chronic intractable nerve/joint/tissue pain with joint degeneration/fusion throughout my entire neck/spine/pelvis, spinal & foraminal stenosis, sacroiliitis, sciatica, kyphosis & scoliosis, muscle spasms, tension headaches, chronic depression, insomnia, chronic fatigue, the list goes on. Despite long-delayed diagnoses & many struggles, I have persevered. I have earned an advanced degree in my field. I contribute part-time to the work force. I have never given up. Over the last two decades, I've tried all manner of therapies, procedures, medications, "miracle cures," remedies, & natural supplements. I discovered kratom tea about one year ago, & I have found it to be a highly effective, safe herbal supplement for managing & coping with my relentless pain, fatigue, & other symptoms. I also haven't taken a single opioid since I started drinking kratom tea.

Like millions of Americans suffering from chronic intractable pain, I was prescribed opioids. Since I was offered no alternatives from my physicians, & opioids are covered by health insurance, I used them as directed for years. However, since discovering kratom, I no longer use opioids or go through the ordeals of their awful side effects & cravings. When I had to use opioids to manage my pain, they were frequently on my mind, like a dark cloud: counting down the hours to my next dose, calculating how many pills I had left for the day, week, month. My days revolved around when I could take my pills. I felt sluggish, foggy, & unmotivated. I felt nauseous all the time & had a poor appetite. I experienced horrible withdrawal symptoms when I would run out of my medication. This happened regularly because my state's health insurance required me to see my pain specialist in person every month to get my prescription refilled, & these visits would often get delayed due to health insurance red tape. Chronic intractable pain is a heavy chain, & having to rely on deadly, addictive opioids is a steel cage.

Conversely, my experience with drinking kratom tea to help manage & cope with my pain has absolutely nothing in common with my ordeal with prescription opioids. I drink kratom tea most weekdays before going to work, like many people who drink coffee in the mornings. Unlike coffee & opioids, however, I have absolutely zero cravings for kratom. Unlike opioids, there is no looming dark cloud of addiction; my days don't revolve around kratom tea. In fact, I haven't noticed any adverse side effects from kratom tea in the entire year I've been drinking it. It doesn't even upset my stomach the way coffee does. I have a healthy appetite again, & I'm more active than when I was taking opioids. Kratom is simply a tea leaf with properties that help dull my relentless pain in a safe, natural way. Furthermore, I would not describe kratom's pain-relieving effects as being similar to opioids at all; in fact, kratom is more effective than opioids at relieving my pain without making me feel foggy, sluggish, "loopy," or "high." Kratom is natural, which is important to me because I have to take enough pharmaceuticals to manage my autoimmune diseases & their symptoms as it is. Kratom is affordable, accessible, & gives me some agency & independence from my health insurance. In short, this wonderful herbal supplement helps to safely ease my suffering, which helps me participate part-time in the work force & live my life more fully & actively. Opioids were my cage, but kratom helps to carry the weight of my pain & walk more freely.

Opioids are killing Americans every single day. The pain & opioid epidemic in America is in dire need of more safe, natural, affordable remedies. Kratom is simply a tea leaf -- an herbal supplement -- & a Schedule 1 classification of its natural alkaloids, mitragynine & 7-hydroxymitragynine, is outrageous. This scheduling would turn suffering Americans like myself into felons for the act of drinking herbal tea to manage our chronic pain. Enforcing this scheduling would likely waste millions of American tax dollars. Classifying kratom's natural compounds as controlled substances would also severely restrict research into this plant when this kind of research is needed most by the American people.

Please do not move forward with placing the natural alkaloids mitragynine & 7-hydroxymitragynine on the list of controlled substances. Kratom is far from a public safety hazard; in fact, it improves & saves lives like mine. Kratom needs to remain accessible to consumers in the food/supplements market & unrestricted for research. Thank you for your time & consideration of my personal testimony.

documents.commentText:
I have tried kratom, and I found it to be a disappointment. Not because it is dangerous to use, or because I didn't like the effect, but mostly because it is relatively difficult to use. A typical dose, 4g, is quite a bit of powdered plant material to ingest. I mixed it with yogurt, but even then, it was not that pleasant to take. Regarding the effects, they are moderate, perhaps like taking a single Vicodin. One does not get high, or at least, not noticably high. It blunts pain, but not completely. On top of all that, it CANNOT be taken in higher doses, by most people, because in doses much over 4g, it induces nausea and vomiting. 

As this report suggests, although I still have quite a bit of the drug left, sitting on a shelf, I am not that incline to use it. If I find myself in pain, without any reasonable alternative (OTC analgesics don't work well for me anymore), I think I will be glad to have it. Otherwise, it will probably just sit there unused.

Therefore, I think that any reasonable observer would conclude that kratom does NOT have a high potential for abuse. It is also not known to cause ODs (because small overdoses induce vomiting), and it doesn't seem to be addictive, either, perhaps because doseage is strictly limited by the nature of the drug. All told, I think it would be extreme overkill to prohibit kratom. Prohibition would create far more harm, as was the case with alcohol and then marijuana, than the drug itself would ever cause.

Please, if you know what is good for America and Americans, do NOT prohibit kratom.

documents.commentText:
Hello, 

I wanted to center the main focus of my comments around 1) Kratom being as an effective tool for mild pain management, and on 2) claims that it proposes a risk of dependency that's comparable with opiates and opioid perception drugs. 

First of all, I would point out that numerous people have been able to stop taking undeniably, measurably-addictive perception medications because of Kratom's ability to produce similar though milder effects in the human brain. It can also prevent withdrawal without posing any measurable  risk of overdose or physical dependency. 

You'll likely see that expressed in these comments in form or another, and though its anecdotal, I've seen several of these cases in my own experience. For this reason, I do think there is much to be gained by further studying what the benefits of Kratom might be in the treatment of substance abuse as well as pain management. 

To that end, I nor anyone I've discussed Kratom use with   have seen signs of physical dependence from of self-medicinal or even recreational use of Kratom. 

I say that as someone who has used Kratom for extended periods of time, and then been able to cease doing so without much effort at all. Admittedly, Kratom can become a habit,  and if that occurs, someone habitually using it would certainly  prefer to do so rather than not. 

However, in the experience of most, it isn't much different than those who frequently use alcohol, nicotine, coffee, their cell phone, eat unhealthy foods....ect. In other words: Kratom is as habit forming as anything else human beings enjoy.

To my second point: Kratom is wonderful pain management tool that doesn't present nearly the risk of overdose or organ damage that opioid prescriptions cut with acetaminophen do. 

The effect on a person's sobriety also seems to be much less pronounced, and for many a, proper dosage can deliver pain relief without drowsiness or intoxication. I think this makes it a much better alternative to those who are trying to manage pain during a work day or during a recurring physical activity. 

For me, it was playing the drums. I'm still relatively young (30), but I'm more than six feet tall and crouching to play a drum set for hours can have sometimes wreak havoc on my back. 

We play a lot of bars and events, so I used to manage that discomfort by drinking alcohol. For more than a year now, though, I have taken a small dose of Kratom and drank water, which has kept my back from causing problems and enabled me to stay more focused on performing. 

I know that's certainly not "chronic pain" on a diagnosable level, but for those who are facing much worse medical circumstances, I can't imagine their experience would be much different, especially for those working in construction, manufacturing or any number of physically-demanding fields. 

Finally, I want to say I understand the concern that Kratom's complete lack of regulation causes. I think many in the "community" don't have qualms with addressing retailers who put unregulated products in front of and in the hands of people who may not know what they're taking. 

However, I hope to covey to the DEA the sheer volume of responsible, wonderful and thoughtful adults who, not only use Kratom, but depend on it for their sustained quality life, physical health and emotional well-being. 

Thank you for allowing the public this opportunity to comment on this issue.

Ketamine isn't covered and I can't afford cash pay. Kratom is cheap and effective, not to mention much safer. I won't choose between food and lights, or medicine. With Kratom, I don't have to. If this becomes illegal, costly, or difficult to get, I will likely end my life to rid myself of a pain level most can't fathom. You have no idea. That's my personal account. Now, for science. Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, the main active constituents of the Kratom leaf, are proven to be physically safer to the user and to one's bodily systems. There is much legitimate research available on the subject and it is your responsibility to be attentive to the findings. It is safer than opiates, safer than alcohol, cigarettes, and even as safe or safer(depending on who you ask) than your morning cup of coffee. These are statements proven by rigorous scientific study. It would be a great disservice to the American people to make this plant a schedule 1 substance. I'm not going to tell you what you can't do in good conscience, as I've found that government agencies possess no such thing. I merely require you to utilize only hard science to arrive at your conclusion. No "reefer madness" scare tactics or falling into manipulations from external sources and people with vested interests. If you are not aware, several drugs are being patented based on the chemicals naturally found in Kratom. A ban will insure that real people who are in pain can't get relief in a timely and affordable manner, but will allow these drug companies to profit with huge margins, when the people are forced to go through their monopoly to obtain said relief at an insanely huge mark-up. The drug companies and their trolls, along with miserable and ignorant people have tried to use scare tactics based on lies to manipulate a ban in their favor. It does not serve the will of the American people as evidenced by the white House petition signatures. If your goal as a regulatory body is only to keep Americans safe from harmful substances, you are barking up the wrong tree. So far anecdotal evidence of calls to poison control, and about 16 deaths are cited by proponents of the ban. Here are the facts: most of the calls were from doctors who were seeking information on the plant and possible drug interactions, so as not to harm their patient who takes Kratom. Of the deaths, not a single one was Kratom alone, nor ruled as cause of death. In every instance, other toxins, from alcohol, to pills, to heroin was found and ruled as cause of death. The presence of Kratom mere coincidence. If half the people who commit suicide have chewing gum in their mouth or pocket, it is illogical to conclude chewing gum had anything to do with their demise. This is a similar instance. I implore you to not let ignorance and fear dictate policy when there is sound and reasonable, true scientific data on the matter. Skewed and easily manipulated statistics made to spark fear are not the standard by which laws should be made in the face of actual clinical study on the matter. Kratom has saved many lives and prevented many suicides also. I would hate to see that change.

When I returned home I sat down on the couch and began to feel a general sense of well being.  it was a warm comfortable feeling that was far from impairment of any kind.  I've been succesfully managing any and all anxiety issues since then and have even found my alcohol intake had decreased signifficantly, so much so that I've lost ten pounds.  I'm a family man with a hectic schedule and this leaf is a godsend.  But as a family man, I can not and will not have any schedule I drugs in my house. I understand there are some potential withdrawal issues, but after all of my research I am troubled by this attemp to deprive so many of a safe and effective treatment while other widely accepted and FDA approved drugs for the same conditions are MUCH more dangerous. Perhaps there are powerful groups that want to harness the capabilities of this plant for their own gain?  I can see no other reason to restrict this wonderful plant to such an extent.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing to contribute my voice to the tens of thousands of people who are asking for the DEA to desist in its efforts to classify Kratom as a Schedule 1 controlled substance. There are no data to indicate that it is addictive in any way and there is no research to substantiate the existence of deleterious side effects related to its use.

I am a 61-year-old female, with a demanding job in the field of special education training and consulting. I have no history of drug abuse or addiction. I have been using Kratom for approximately 10 months as a way to relieve minor to moderate back and joint pain related to standing for several hours a day as a staff trainer and classroom consultant. In addition, I have found it to be helpful in alleviating the symptoms of  a longstanding sinus drainage and post-nasal drip issue that I have struggled with for over three years.  I use it two-three times a week, depending on my schedule, and have been very pleased with its effectiveness for both of these purposes.

I am asking that you follow sound scientific practice in evaluating Kratom's effectiveness and potential side effects before making any determination as to its substance classification. I believe that your agency must have an established standard protocol for this type of assessment. 

Thank you for this opportunity to comment on this subject and for your consideration of my input and the input of my fellow Kratom beneficiaries.
