documents.commentText:
I would like to begin by stating that I am opposed to any scheduling or banning of kratom for a number of reasons. I strongly believe in the human right to use anything that occurs naturally if it provides a benefit with minimal risk. Placing kratom on any Schedule, especially Schedule I, would deprive millions of Americans of an inexpensive tool which at a minimum can promote a sense of well-being as part of a healthy lifestyle. In many cases, it can save lives.

My wife has survived PTSD, depression, and severe anxiety for most of her life. Since age 16, she has been on 24 prescription medications with varying degrees of success. She has managed her illness, but by 2014 (after several seizures led to an epilepsy diagnosis) she was forced to retire from a career position after being declared totally disabled by her psychiatrist, who recommended she apply for Social Security benefits. We moved to another state to be closer to my family, and she resigned herself to part-time employment, at best. We were no longer insured, and she had to endure withdrawal from benzodiazapenes and SSRIs after suddenly stopping them when she was unable to obtain and pay for new prescriptions. Withdrawal from benzodiazapenes can and does cause seizures and death, but she made it through, vowing never to take them again. It was then that we began researching natural remedies and found kratom. 

With no real expectations, she began using small quantities of kratom mixed into smoothies a couple of times a day. Almost immediately, she noticed an improvement in her anxiety and began sleeping through the night, something that hadnt occurred in years. She applied for a part-time data-entry position through a temp agency which quickly led to her being hired on to a full-time position. Data-entry led to a promotion to a software-testing position, and early this year, she applied for and obtained a promotion to her dream job within the same organization. The change has been profound from my point of view. None of her illnesses have been cured, but she has found a natural herbal supplement that has given her a foothold and allowed her to leave the house and has helped with her depression and anxiety. Shes happier and the PTSD symptoms like flashbacks have been kept at bay. We both feel immense gratitude to kratom for helping her get her life back. It would be beyond devastating to have that essential tool taken away.

The day back in August that we learned about the potential ban was one of the scariest days in either of our lives. For my wife, it was the potential loss of the most reliable way out of the darkness that she has yet found. For me, it was the potential loss of my wife. I sincerely hope that the stories you have heard since then lead to kratom remaining available to any adult who may find a use for it. Thank you for listening to our voices.

Sincerely, 

C. Smith

documents.commentText:
Please do not ban kratom, a medicinal plant used for millennia in Southeast Asia and that's currently used by millions of people in the United States as a pain reliever and to help alleviate opiod addiction.
-Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
-If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars. These people do not belong in our already overecrowded prisons.
-Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
-Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
-Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
-Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.
Thank you for considering my comments.
Kristy Rotermund

documents.commentText:
My name is Laura Hyle, I'm 31 from Akron Ohio. I would like to voice my opposition to the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. This would put kratom, a plant helping millions of people suffering chronic and acute mental and physical conditions that is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem naturally, on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin.	
     I have been diagnosed with chronic migraine disorder which I have been suffering from for quite a number of years. I have been through countless doctors and specialists trying to find a solution to manage my extreme pain. Chronic migraine disorder is the 8th most disabling disease in the world with headaches that occur more than 15 times a month. I have been on preventative medications and triptan medications and have received Botox injections to try to help with my symptoms most of which I dont find much relief with. I have struggled with daily living from my disorder and find it very difficult to manage a job and hold on to my medical benefits which I so desperately need.
    Im a responsible consumer of the botanical kratom. Through constant research for my disorder I came across Kratom which is a plant that grows in Asia that I read has benefits to those with chronic pain. Within one day of taking it I noticed I did not have a headache and the frequency of my pain from migraines was becoming less and less. This plant has given me my life back I feel. I am more of a productive person because of it. I have been able to return to work and I have a better quality of life now. Ive gone from having a daily headache or migraine to only a small amount in a month without any side effects. 
   Kratom is a safe herbal supplement that I believe should be accessible to any adult.  I fear this action by the DEA will only lead to more tragic deaths of victims of the opiate epidemic. I know that my own quality of life as a productive member of society will not be the same without kratom.

Sincerely, 
Laura Hyle

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Sincerely,
Elise Marguils

documents.commentText: Hi, i was in a bad car accident when i was 12 and broke my spine and ribs.  I have metal rods (from 1992) fusing my back from top to bottom not to mention buldging disks in my neck and lower back pain below the rods.  I was on strong opiates for 2/3 of my life.  Finally a yr and a half ago i was switched to Methadone with a cocktail of other stuff and ended up passing out behind the wheel on my way to pick up my daughter from school and flipping my car and had ankle surgery.  I should have been dead but i think the Volvo I bought when i had my daughter saved me as many of the first responders, etc stated.  After that, i was done with opiates.  I was 34 when this happened and it was hell on earth trying to get off.  The kicks, the sweats, the vomiting.  I had to take weeks off of work to go through withdrawal (while on crutches) but i was introduced to Kratom.  It helped relieve some of the withdrawal and then helped with my chronic pain with no side effects.  I was not drowsy, i did not build a tolerance and many more im sure you already know.  I had my life back and could have fun with my daughter.  Im not sure if whoever is reading this has ever has chronic pain but it makes you mentally crazy.  Thoughts of suicide you would have never thought you would have come into play.  You start to hurt yourself in other ways just to get some acute pain and adrenaline going so you can sleep at night.  I know thats not right, i am a highly educated person with a full time job.  Many doctors have told me to go on ss disability but i want to show my daughter what its like to be a strong role model.  Please leave Kratom on the shelves for people like me.  I am pretty sure you can't overdose and i think only about 1% of people are using it to get high.  I have gotten higher smelling whiteout so that is just crazy.  I also have ptsd and anxiety and it helps with all of that.  If you take this off the market, so many people like me may turn to hard opiates like heroine.  In my opinion, Kratom is safer that Tylenol and works better.  I don't want to live in pain.  Please don't do this, just leave Kratom for sale as is.  I understand if you want to put an age limit on it but you mght as well do that with coffee as well and outlaw cigarettes and alcohol.  They kill way more people than Kratom.  Thank you for listening to my story.  Please consider it in your decision making pricess.  Im happy to talk to you.    Thanks again.

documents.commentText:
Hello. My name is Chris Hoffman, and I am 53 years old. I am a Chemical Engineer. I oppose the addition of Kratom, and the active alkaloids in the plant, to the category of Schedule 1 Controlled Substances. I began using Kratom in 2011 to help manage pain when I was unable to use OTC pain relievers due to limited kidney function caused by those same OTC pain relievers, namely Ibuprofen, but I can not use any other of the NSAIDs either. I did not want to become dependent on the opiate pain relievers and through research found out about Kratom, and gave it a try. I have found Kratom to be an excellent pain reliever with a minimum of side effects. I have discontinued using Kratom several times and found there were no problems of the sort encountered with other opiates with discontinued use - Kratom is not addictive. Nor have I had to increase the amount I use to obtain pain relief. If Kratom was to be made Schedule 1, important research on the plant would become difficult, and I would appreciate serious research on Kratom and its active alkaloids to determine scientifically their properties in order to find out how this plant could help people suffering from pain and opiate addiction, and to properly determine usage.
In conclusion, I have found Kratom to be safe and effective, and a good alternative to the opiate based drugs that cause so many problems, and would hate to see its promise destroyed by it being classified as a Schedule 1 Controlled Substance.
Sincerely,
Christopher Hoffman

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:


My name is Diana Morton, I am a 37 year old, freight broker and small business owner. I began using Kratom in 2012, as an herbal supplement that was recommended to me for alleviating the symptoms of the anxiety that I had been experiencing for years, which burdened my life, in all areas, with many struggles and limitations. 

Since I began using the herbal supplement, Kratom, I no longer live with the struggles and limitations that were caused by anxiety, so the quality of my life has greatly improved in all areas. In addition to consistently and effectively alleviating my anxiety symptoms, Kratom has provided me with an increased energy level (which was previously low, due to the levels of anxiety I was experiencing), along with increased mental clarity and sharpened focus. 

The energy increase and mental clarity / focus that I experience when taking Kratom is comparative to a cup of coffee in the morning, but it is a much more level, natural feeling without the jittery nervousness, or caffeine crash later in the day. In my experience, Kratom has always been a very mild feeling, herbal supplement with zero side effects and zero withdrawal symptoms. I've gone days and weeks without using Kratom, at various times over these years, and I have never experienced any withdrawal symptoms during those times, nor have I ever needed to increase my intake for effectiveness when using Kratom daily for months at a time.

Kratom is such an important resource for me to be able to maintain optimal health and quality of life, because in addition to the health benefits that I've experienced, it has given me a natural alternative to synthetic prescription drugs for anxiety which come with harmful side effects. Many people, including myself, seek natural supplements whenever possible and avoid prescriptions with harmful side effects, at all costs, to protect our health and doing that should be a fundamental, protected right and freedom for all. 

I am very concerned about the possibility of Kratom being made illegal and reclassified as a schedule one narcotic, because I believe that this would have an immensely negative effect on the quality of life and health of many others, besides my own. I truly and wholeheartedly believe that banning Kratom would be a tragic mistake, a potentially life threatening, if not fatal one for those whose lives have been so greatly improved by it, like the many military veterans who are using Kratom to help with their PTSD, or the many opiate addicts who are using Kratom to combat their addiction and the many people suffering with chronic pain who have found relief with Kratom.

The United States of America is the land of the free, and we have made great strides in recent years to ensure that we are living up to that ideal, which so many Americans have died for throughout our history. For example, we are beginning to see the legalization of marijuana happen from state to state which is greatly helping to improve the lives of many medicinal users with chronic illnesses, as it will help in saving our tax dollars by reserving prison space for criminals that pose a true danger to society. That was a very progressive and successful move towards our national ideals of freedom. 

Banning Kratom would not only directly oppose and contradict those ideals, but it would be very costly to tax payers, because it would fill our prisons with non violent offenders that pose no threat to society and are simply seeking to improve their health with a natural herbal supplement, that taken alone, has never proven to hurt anyone. Banning Kratom would be a hugely regressive failure, as the vast majority of Americans would find out that it is an unnecessary infringement on our freedoms with scientists already proving it's harmlessness and potential benefits, so it would inevitably create a movement of opposition, a rising of American people demanding that Kratom be legalized once again. Banning Kratom would be the ultimate offense against the people of a nation that stands for freedom and justice for all.

I am requesting that the DEA, please, take into consideration that no one has been proven to have been hurt by taking Kratom alone, and to please, consider the many lives that will be adversely affected, if no longer allowed access to this herbal supplement. I am requesting that the DEA, in good conscience and in upholding of the values of the United States of America, please, keep this harmless plant, a natural, herbal supplement, legal for the good of all.  

Thank you for allowing this time for public comments to take our concerns into consideration, and for taking all facts, evidence and thorough scientific research into consideration, prior to making this extremely important and life altering decision.


Sincerely,


Diana Morton

To Whom It May concern,
I am a year old scientific professional working at a non profit  institute as a Flow Cytometry specialist.   I started using Kratom about 1 year ago.  Since I was 13, I've suffered from a hormone disorder Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder.  Some of the systems involve major anxiety, panic attacks, foggy brain, and unbelievable sadness.  I've found it hard to function at times.  I've been on a couple of antidepressants, birth control, and xanax to deal with the problems associated with this disorder.  There isn't much that you can do.  Although Xanax helped, I could only take it at night because it knocked me out and I was extremely worried about becoming addicted to it.  So, I usually wait till I'm pretty bad off before I take it.  A friend on mine suggested that I use Kratom and what a difference it made!  I felt normal.  i was able to focus, sleep better, and be more productive and calm.  It changed my life.  I felt hopeful for once in my life!  Because it's not addictive for me,  I felt comfortable to use it when for as few or more times as I need to help with my PMDD symptoms.  
Someone in my professional needs to interact with many researchers in collaboration.  It takes a calm focused brain to troubleshoot and deal with issues concerning projects or people.  When I heard that the DEA was going to put kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances, I was shocked.  How can Kratom be classified with other substances that stop productivity, destroy families, and destroy a person's well being?  I don't feel that with Kratom at all.  In fact, it gave me MY LIFE back.  Therefore, I strongly OPPOSE Kratom being classified as a Schedule 1 Controlled substance.  

Amy Cortez

documents.commentText:
Kratom has brought me significant relief from chronic back pain which I have been dealing with for over ten years! When I was initially injured, I was prescribed narcotic painkillers and rapidly developed an addiction which ended up costing me a great job, a marriage, a home, and several years of my life, as well as my previously spotless legal record when at the age of 32 I was charged with fraudulent attempt to obtain a controlled substance when I tried to call in a prescription on my own.  The judge was sympathetic and told me he didn't think I was a criminal, but an addict, and I ended up in a long term recovery program when I couldn't kick it on my own. I haven't touched a narcotic since...but it didn't mean the pain wasn't still there. After a chat with a man I met at a local health food store, I did some research and decided to give kratom a try. I've never second-guessed this decision! I feel like I have my life back!! Not only does it significantly reduce my level of pain... unlike the poisons the pharmaceutical industry pushes down people's throats, kratom does not put me in a brain fog. Quite the opposite actually! Taking kratom is very uplifting and I feel energetic, clear-headed, and happy! If I happen to run out or miss a dose, there are no terrible withdrawal symptoms and I don't feel compelled to rush out to get a "fix" by any means necessary. 
Kratom has been a total game changer for myself and many many others I've met both in person and online. I've turned several personal friends on to it and their experiences are identical to my own.  To outlaw this amazing plant, while maintaining the legality of deadly poisons pushed on innocent people by the medical and pharmaceutical companies would be nothing more than another example of corporate greed. God made this truly spectacular plant with the ability to help people, while the doctors and pharma companies are only interested in getting people hooked on their dope so they have to keep coming back...I speak from personal experience as a victim of their schemes. 
Please allow common sense and reason to rule the day! I do not want to go back to being in excruciating pain most of the time, and I certainly am never going to think about letting a doctor try to prescribe me a deadly poison again! Life has been so much better for me and so many others thanks to kratom!!! Thank you for allowing the people to be heard!

documents.commentText:
DEA-442W
I would like to ask the DEA to keep Kratom legal! There are hundreds of thousands of people, Luke myself, who use this wonderful plant to avoid all of the harmful effects of prescription narcotics. I suffer from System Lupus and have been on a myriad of pain medications and steroids. One of those pain medications began causing me to have severe grand mal seizures in June of 2013. My children watched their mother convulse helplessly waiting on paramedics. Since that time, I have discontinued all narcotic pain medications and rely soley on kratom to keep me mobile. Without it, I am bedridden with pain and fatigue. Kratom is a safe alternative to dangerous pharmaceutical drugs with none of the nasty side effects. Not one death has occurred from kratom use alone. Thousands die every day due to prescription drug overdoses. There are also many other Americans utilizing kratom to overcome narcotic addictions. People that otherwise would continue to abuse things such as heroin or prescription drugs. Kratom allows them to discontinue such drugs safely by reducing kratom and easing the debilitating symptoms of withdrawal. Banning this amazing plant would have severe consequences for so many Americans left with few other options. Studies have shown kratom to be a safe alternative. Laborers in Thailand have used this plant for thousands of years to treat several things with no I'll effects. Kratom does not cause the "high" typically associated with narcotics. It allows the user to experience relief from their symptoms without the loopy fatigue side effects commonly associated with narcotic medications.  I urge you to take our pleas into consideration. Let Americans have a choice as to what we put into our own bodies! Thank you!

documents.commentText:
Dear Sirs,

I am writing you regarding the  DEA classification of Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug. 

In light of all of the issues around oxycodone and tighter and tighter restrictions on pain killers- many people are turning to natural alternatives.  Kratom is one such alternative, and I can tell you that it has a very positive use, and reclassifying this substance would be a true crime!

My wife is just one example.  She was in a terrible car accident as a teen- nearly 40 years ago.  She was not expected to live. Her pelvis was crushed, her spleen, gall bladder and a good part of her liver were removed. Her intestines were "replumbed" for lack of an easier description.  She has been in pain ever since and always will be.  In recent years, she has had breast cancer, and a host of other afflictions, such as server type 1 diabetes, gastroparesis, fybromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome and depression. Her afflictions are severe enough that she is disabled and cannot work. It's a challenge for her to do basic things. Her having access to decent pain medication means the difference between her lying in bed all day because of the pain, etc., or being able get out bed and do a few things.
Oxycodone helps to a large degree, but it is getting harder to get and we fear someday it may be outlawed.  It also has it's own issues and is not a perfect drug. It aggravates her gastroparesis and sometimes gives her migraines. 

Kratom helps reduce some of her pain and does not have the side effects that oxycodone has... however, it is not anywhere near as strong.  It does reduce her pain to some degree, but it also helps a lot with her mood and depression...again with far fewer side effects that prescription drugs.  The fact that it helps with depression and pain, is a wonderful thing!!!

Kratom is a wonderful plant that should be embraced.  I think we could learn a lot from it.  I cannot help but think that big pharma may be behind pushing the DEA for this ban... it's sad for people like my wife, who find it a tremendous help.

The government seems to be really down on anything that has to do with pain killers.  They can be dangerous.  They have their issues.  What I would like you and all politicians to keep in mind is this:  Put yourself in the shoes of somebody that has permanent pain issues. They are not all drug addicts. They hurt.  ALL the time.  They would gladly accept the chance that it might one day kill them-because it makes the difference between not being able to get out of bed vs. being able to have at least some functionality and a chance to do a few things that most of us take for granted every single day.

Thank you for your time..
Please help keep Kratom legal.

Steve Thornton

I and many other Americans truly appreciate you taking our voices into consideration.

Thank you,

Adam Dewey

I am a 58 year old female and I take Kratom on and off some, not all days. I have been taking it for about 8 years. It helps for mental focus, clarity, and energy. I don't take any more of it than to feel just that. I suffer from Severe Depression and PTSD, however, I am a person who prefers to use natural foods, herbs, and substances to stay healthy, as opposed to any and all manufactured pharmaceutical drugs, or street drugs.

It would really be detrimental to people like me who take Kratom in a responsible way, to ban or limit it. I don't believe that natural occurring substances should be banned. Addiction or misuse of any substance, or in the case of Kratom use as an irresponsible combination of substances thereof, natural or manufactured, is and should be the sole responsibility of the person using it/them. 

Another issue that banning or limiting Kratom would create, is what I call the "Taboo Effect". When something is made illegal, it creates a fascination with younger people, especially, whereas if the substance was legal, they simply wouldn't care.

Banning Kratom will only make bigger problems in a new Black Market. Please let's not go back in time and create more failed Drug Wars, let us move forward. Please keep Kratom unregulated as a bulk substance, and entirely legal. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
I would first like to thank you for waiting accepting public comment on this matter rather than hastily moving forward without allowing comment from the many thousands of people, like myself, in this country who have first hand experience with the plant known as mitragyna speciosa.  

Back in 2011 and 2013 I was forced to undergo 2 spinal fusion surgeries in order to secure an area in my spinal column so narrow (spinal stenosis) that it was not only causing debilitating pain but also put me in serious immediate risk of paralysis.  The second surgery was a success.  I was no longer in serious danger but I  developed severe nerve pain in my arms that was making it almost impossible to even simply sit at my desk and type.  I went back to my neurosurgeon and received further MRI's to find the issue.  He confirmed I was in no danger and that I was lucky that all I had to deal with was the nerve pain.  He was was not being insensitive.  He was stating a fact. I needed the surgery to avoid nerve damage but my spinal column was still very narrow and would continue to irritate the nerves there.  Further surgery was not a viable option as a good outcome was not likely from more expansive surgical correction.  Opioid pain killers such as Vicodin or Oxycontin were also not an option because the pain was not going to subside and I would have become dependent on such substances.  Over the counter pain relief medication had no effect.

My quality of life was declining.  It was difficult to ever be in a good mood. I was quite literally living in constant pain, on the pain scale of 1-10, I hovered between 4 to 7 24 hours a day. (For reference, I have had kidney stones and I know what a proper 10 feels like on that scale.)  I was prescribed gabapentin (and still am) but in doses high enough to properly control the pain I would start having sleep attacks (narcolepsy) and that is a very dangerous way to live.

My wife was worried about me and did internet research on some options and she came across information about mitragyna speciosa and how it had helped some people with similar issues. I had little to lose and since it was completely legal it was as easy as ordering it online.  A little bit of research of first hand accounts helped me choose a reputable vendor online.

I just bought crushed leaf powder in bags. I tried several different strains, all a little different (as advertised) and was able to find one that not only knocked the pain all the way... that's ALL THE WAY out but it also counteracted the lethargy caused by the gabapentin.  All of a sudden I was productive at work again, I felt whole and happy and my home life improved. All of the work around the house that had been piling up I was able to slowly get through.  It worked.  Very well.  Better than anything the doctor had at his disposal to prescribe. I do complex technical planning and troubleshooting for a living (IT Manager). I was able to take mitragyna speciosa at work without hiding anything from my employer.  My performance was top notch. My employer had no issue with my behavior or state of mind.  Quite the contrary.

My wife worried after several months of my regularly using Kratom (mitragyna speciosa) that this plant might be dangerous and that by now I might be addicted since few things in life are that simple.  She compelled me to go have full a blood workup done to assess any damage. I complied.  My blood work came back perfectly normal except for my predictably high triglycerides (pre-existing). She then asked me to stop taking it for a while to see if I could.  I was worried.  I kind of assumed I would have to deal with a terrible withdrawl.  I was worried I would no longer be able to use this plant that helped so much.  But I quit.  Cold Turkey. I was pretty grumpy for 3 or 4 days honestly.  I slept more than usual.  Nerve pain came back LOUD. A rebound effect I guess. I went to work. I took care of my responsibilities. It was just a little harder.  About day 5 I woke up feeling back to normal.  Right back where I was before I ever took Kratom. I did not take it again for about 6 weeks. I discussed it with my wife that I was sick of dealing with the old nerve pain when I knew there was an answer.  She agreed and I started taking Kratom again. My dosages didn't creep up.  Every three months I stopped for a couple of weeks with the exact same results.  No big deal.  Safe stuff.  It even lowered my blood pressure a little.

In summary. While I very much disagree with the FDA/DEA decision to even get involved, I stopped using Kratom in mid-September to avoid being made a criminal. If made illegal, I will not use it again. I will suffer. It hurt to type this letter.  I have used several vendors over the 2 years since I found Kratom. All of them were reputable.

Please abandon this witch hunt and leave Kratom off of your schedule. Should people really go to prison or even be killed by police over a leaf that gave me my life back?

Sincerely,

Michael

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. 
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars. 
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. 
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. 
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. 
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose. 


Really looks like the DEA officers are looking for was to justify their lofty jobs.  SDD

I might just as well take cyanide.  They are all poison as well as alcohol.  I would prefer to just have the government just give the pharmaceutical manufacturers money rather than have them push their pills on the unfortunate people who need help for various reasons.  Let us decide our own fate.  I don't understand why we don't have the right to choose how we treat ourselves medically.  I fully agree children shouldn't be allowed access to any drugs or alcohol, but unfortunately, no laws are going to prevent this.

I do get some relief from various natural plants, not man made poison.  Unfortunately they are all illegal in Wisconsin and difficult to obtain.  Marijuana and mushrooms are already schedule 1 drugs, this really this makes no sense. There is absolutely no empirical data that supports either of them are harmful substances.  Now you want to do the same with another harmless plant in kratom.  Is caffeine next?

It sickens me that in a great country like ours, that money trumps our health and well being.  When it comes to my health, I no longer trust our doctors or pharmacists.  More precisely I don't trust the DEA, FDA and now the AMA.

Please reconsider making kratom, marijuana and mushrooms legal.  Do your studies and make the obvious choice.  It's ludicrous to say these plants haven't any medical value and even more ludicrous to say they are harmful.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v


There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
In regards to Docket No. DEA-442W, I oppose the placement of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule 1. The benefits of kratom have improved my life and the lives of many others. It is a safe and healing supplement. It's benefits are numerous and of great value to American citizens. It's value as a treatment for addiction to prescription painkillers and other opiates cannot be understated. It is also of tremendous benefit to Americans suffering from PTSD and other forms of anxiety and mental health issues. 

There are many people extremely knowledgable and informed on the benefits of this kratom. I would encourage opening up a discussion with the award-winning documentary director Chris Bell on the topic. There has been no evidence of deaths directly related to kratom. It is extremely important we continue allow Americans access to the kratom plant and fund research into the plant to discover all the benefits it has to offer. The more research done on kratom, the more mis-information and negative mis-conceptions will be dispelled. 

I look forward to more open discussion about kratom and its beneficial uses. Thank you for your time and consideration. 

Sincerely,


Jeff Turner

documents.commentText:
I have been a kratom advocate for almost five years now. Before switching to kratom, I had tried a number of different anti-depressants and anxiety medications.

The anti-depressants made me feel like a zombie. Life barely seemed worth living. The anxiety meds that the doctor gave me made me very tired. All the time. My doctor did not like the idea of me switching to kratom. Instead he wanted to up the dosage on my medications. Coming off the anxiety meds was extremely difficult. My doctor had told me that those RX meds were "unlikely to show noticeably addictive properties".

Anyways at this point I have been off over prescription meds for over four years. I no longer use kratom daily. At this point I only use it during the winter months, as I am prone to seasonal depression. Kratom truly has saved my life. It is much safer then the RX drugs. The side effects are minimal in comparison to the pharmaceuticals that I have tried.

More and more people are switching to kratom as a natural alternative to pharmaceuticals. It is a safer and more effective than many dangerous and addictive medications. Of course there are situations in which prescription meds are a better choice, but it is imperative that people may retain the right to choose a natural alternative.

documents.commentText: I have used Kratom for a number of ailments including pain, sleep, and anxiety.  Not only do I believe that the choice to make Kratom illegal is rash and unjustified, I believe that there are medical benefits that the public could benefit from with further research.  Just because a plant has recreational uses doesn't mean it's inherently harmful, by that logic, alcohol, tobacco, and coffee should be illegal as well.  The general consensus of users and reseachers online is that kratom has potential medical benefits, and does not pose any obvious negative issues beyond slight impairment, abuse potential similar to the abuse potential of chocolate, nausea, and tiredness..  I believe the reasons for the DEA's scheduling is not in the best interest of the public due to the insufficient evidence of abuse, death or injury, or social issues it's use would present (except the fact that it's use could potentially lessen the use of pharmaceutical opiates and similar medications).  Please for the sake of medical and social advancements, peoples health, and peoples freedom, allow the people to have the freedom to decide whether or not they can use this plant for there own benefit or not.  Thank you for considering what I have to say.

documents.commentText: I believe beyond a shadow of a doubt that Kratom should *not* be banned without thoroughly investigating its potential pharmocological benefits, especially compared to the Papavara Somniferum derived cousins. There is no argument that the classical opiods are wreaking havoc on the world today, but Kratom could offer a route into the same or similar pain-killing mechanisms while demonstrating less risky tenencies, for example a lower mu-opiod affinity couple with higher agonist actions at the other key receptors involved in pain relief. A cursory look at some of the new synthetic opiods (tapentadol for example) proves pain--management can be pharmocologically efficient while minimizing the sedative and risky side eddects. I believe that until we rule out all possible advantages of Kratom and its chemical derivatives, we should absolutely not ban the plant. This epidemic is too destructive not to look into every possible resource.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

My name is Joshua Bergen.  I am a 36 year old licensed physical therapist in the state of NY.  I strongly believe that classifying the herb kratom into a schedule 1 substance is a huge mistake.  Although I do not use kratom regularly, I have personally witnessed and can attest to the enormous benefits of this herbal dietary supplement for many people I have known both personally and professionally. 

In my professional work, I often come into contact with patients who are in severe pain and have been prescribed prescription pain killers.  Many of them become addicted and experience horrible side effects from these prescribed medications. I have always had a sizable patient population who wishes to stop using these medications but feels unable.  As kratom has grown in popularity over the past few years, I have seen a significant increase in the number of patients who have been able to successfully stop taking these dangerous medications and experience a huge increase in quality of life.  I have personally witnessed these individuals transform from medicated zombies into active, functional, productive members of society.  This cannot be ignored.  This plant deserves to be studied, not scheduled.  With proper research, it may prove to be a valuable tool for pain and addiction sufferers

In my personal life, I suffered a shoulder injury several years ago which resulted in a rotator cuff repair surgery.  I was prescribed opioids for my post surgical pain.  I used them for the first 2 days but after having seen so many patients become addicted to these medications in my professional life, I decided that I did not want to use them anymore. I decided to try kratom instead.  To my amazement, it effectively aided my road to recovery but left me feeling completely unimpaired, cognitvely intact, and free of addiction.  I was able to read, write, exercise, and perform any task that I would normally perform.  I used kratom for several weeks and was then able to stop without any side effects. I humbly beg that the scheduling of kratom be reconsidered so that it can be studied, available, and used safely.    

Sincerely

Joshua Bergen, MPT

documents.commentText:
Greetings DEA representative. This is Dennis Pelton. I am writing you today in order to voice my concern about the DEA banning the mitragyna speciosa (kratom) tree. I was first diagnosed with clinical depression at age 16. I am now 43 years of age. Since age 16 I have tried every pharmaceutical drug available to treat biochemical depression. None of them helped my condition. I only found relief for my life threatening condition after discovering & consuming kratom leaves. 
     I have successfully used the leaves to treat my condition for the past 8 years with no negative side effects. If the kratom ban actually get's enforced. My greatest concern is for those that have served our Country & have come back from Iraq/Afghanistan & use kratom to treat permanent injuries that they have suffered overseas. I also feel for the elderly that use kratom to treat arthritis, fibromyalgia & many other medical disorders. The leaves of the kratom tree are saving hundreds of thousands of lives. Many will be forced to choose between staying alive & functional or obeying the arbitrary whim of the DEA and possibly dying! Or at the very least going back to a miserable life of suffering! For many this is not just a difference of opinion. It's a difference between life or death! 
     The banning of kratom will also be a burden to the health care system, insurance & government. Thousands are functional only because of kratom. Without access to this miracle plant they will go back to collecting a disability check instead of being a productive member of society. Kratom is paid for by the consumers. Not by insurance corporations or government (tax payer). However, if kratom is no longer accessible. People will have no choice but to go back to burdening the health care system & government. 
     Furthermore, has anyone actually taken the time to think about what the enforcement of this kratom ban would even look like? Picture wheelchair bound Iraq & Afghanistan veterans in handcuffs! Picture grandmothers suffering from fibromyalgia in handcuffs! This is after DEA thugs dressed in all black, wearing black ski masks kick in their front door! Videos of wheelchair bound disabled people in handcuffs being wheeled off to prison! Then after they get bailed out of jail they tell the press how they had DEA thugs point fully automatic weapons at their heads! It would be a public relations nightmare for the DEA!
     In closing I strongly encourage you to join Senator Orrin Hatch (R-UT), Congressmen Mark Pocan (D-Wis.), Congressmen Matt Salmon (R-Ariz.) & their colleagues to stop the ban of the mitragyna speciosa (kratom) tree. Take care & may God bless you.


Sincerely,

Dennis Pelton

documents.commentText:
My name is Laura Huebner, I am 30 years old and happily employed as a landscape designer with a local company, after recently completing my Bachelor's degree.  I ask that you please reconsider making kratom illegal.  It has helped many people, myself included,  with a variety of issues, and has potential to help many more if medical research is allowed to continue.  

I first tried kratom a little over two years ago, after hearing reports that it had helped some people with anxiety and depression.  I have have struggled with these issues since I was  teenager--over the course of the last 15 years, I have seen all sorts of therapists and psychiatrists, taken part in in-patient and out-patient programs, been prescribed the gamut of anti-depressants and anti-anxiety medications.  I stopped taking these medications about five years ago, as they just didn't seem to be helping, and they had become difficult and expensive to obtain due to to insurance issues.  As I struggled to cope with these issues on my own, my relationships with my family and my self-confidence suffered.  I floundered in a dead-end job and took one or two classes at a time at the local college, just barely passing.

In the time since I started using kratom, I buckled down and finished my degree at the state university, driving two hours every day to get to/from class.  I have found confidence in myself and direction in my life.  My relationships with my family have vastly improved, and I am valued in my position at work, doing something I enjoy and believe in.

I choose to use kratom almost everyday, and for me, the benefits far outweigh the drawbacks.  Kratom is a supplement with subtle effects, the intensity of which are on par with coffee.  It doesn't get me high.  Kratom is not a cure, but it has been a very useful tool in helping me deal with my anxiety and depression, and I can say emphatically that my life has improved in almost every way in the two years I have been using it.

The people who report having a negative experience with kratom are not the majority.  Many thousands of responsible adults in the United States choose to use kratom for their own reasons, without ill effect.  Please do not outlaw a mild supplement that has more potential to help than to hurt.  Thank you for your time and consideration.

Respectfully,
Laura Huebner

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I'm writing to express my concern about the proposed DEA kratom rescheduling as a controlled substance.

My experience with kratom has been a fantastic one and, in my opinion, life-saving.  After a serious accident in 2012, I unfortunately developed an addiction to prescription opiate painkillers.  Kratom was instrumental in defeating this addiction, and I have been opiate-free for almost two years.

None of my experience with kratom has been negative, I don't feel that there are any downsides including physical or mental addiction.  There have been virtually no noticeable side effects or other health effects.  My physician is aware of how I used kratom and cannot find where kratom has caused any danger to my physical or mental health--in fact, quite the opposite.  I had also been treated for anxiety and depression and since I began using kratom somewhat regularly I have completely stopped medication for the issues without any negative effects.

I feel that the scheduling of kratom is heavy-handed and misguided.  I am of the belief that there are ulterior motives for some to try to influence the DEA and I hope that the DEA will make a fair and unbiased study of the benefits before taking such a draconian measure.  Looking at the original temporary ban, there are more than a few unsubstantiated claims and some that are absolutely false.  

Kratom does not, in my opinion, pose any danger to the public health.  It is not, as has been stated, an opiate, but rather a member of the coffee family.  Scheduling kratom as a schedule 1 drug will not only harm people who use it therapeutically, but will in my opinion cause an increase in the opiate epidemic that is harming so many Americans.

Please reconsider the scheduling of kratom.

Thank you,
Mark Wothe

documents.commentText:
My name is Anthony Marshall,

Since I was very young I've had problems with severe depression and anxiety. As a teenager I used drugs to try to combat this. As an adult I spent many years drinking heavily. My drinking would lead to me doing bad things that I wouldn't normally do and most of the time couldn't even remember what I had done. I went to an alcoholic rehab at one point because of this. I have also seen many psychiatrists over the years and been prescribed a variety of medicines. Some have helped while others have had terrible side effects.

About three years ago I came across something called Kratom. I found that it didn't get me high but did elevate my mood and reduced the depression. I have taken Kratom almost daily during this period. I finally stopped drinking altogether about 2 years ago. I have had no cravings for alcohol while using Kratom.

Is Kratom safe? I've taken it daily for about three years and I seem to be healthy. Is it addictive? I would consider it about like coffee. I have gone without it for a couple of weeks at a time and the withdrawals were minimal. This plant is certainly safer and less addictive than both alcohol and cigarettes - both of which are legal. 

Now, the DEA has decided that they want to list Kratom as a schedule 1 substance. This means they think it is comparable to marijuana, lsd, etc. To me this is absurd but if I continue to use Kratom if the ban goes through then I could become a felon and go to jail if caught.

Kratom has helped thousands of people with pain disorders, depression, and many other ailments. It has helped me immensely. Now a bunch of unelected officials have decided that I can't have it anymore. I am 47 years old and I feel that if I want to eat a plant then I think I should be able to. I'm not hurting anyone. Isn't this America? Shouldn't we be free to pursue happiness if it doesn't hurt anyone else?

Please do not make Kratom a schedule one drug. It should be treated as a supplement. If this ban goes through, you will be turning normal everyday people into criminals. Is this what we want to do to people who only want to treat their pain, depression, and possibly treat their other more dangerous addictions?

Sincerely,
Anthony Marshall

documents.commentText: My name is Eric Hutton, and I'm a 37 year old Doctor of Pharmacy working in a retail setting. Ever since graduating school and assuming a full-time position (an "upright" one, at that), I've dealt with a significant amount of back pain--significant not in its severity, but in its unrelenting presence--as well as the fatigue and stress that come with any job where your entire day is spent on your feet, often with the phone pressed between your shoulder and your ear. After several failed attempts to find something "wrong" with me (X-rays, MRI, ultrasound, etc.), I was starting to consider seeing a pain management specialist (and there are several in the vicinity of my work, so I was familiar with the types of treatment they offer). Still, I was hesitant, because without an official diagnosis, and an unwillingness to "play up" my pain level on command, I doubted they'd take me seriously. Plus, I got to see the cycle of dependency on a daily basis--patients who started out with a broken arm or some surgical procedure being prescribed short-term opioids, which gradually turns into long-term use, until they're referred to pain management where regular, around-the-clock opioids become a staple of the patient's regimen indefinitely (unless they're weaned off with an expensive prescription of suboxone, which often turns into an indefinite treatment itself). Luckily, it was right around this time that I discovered kratom. I was extremely skeptical that it would do anything, but within 30 minutes or so of consuming it for the first time, there was a mild but noticeable lift in my mood and energy, which then seemed to make the nagging pain more tolerable. After an initial period of finding the right level for me, I was able to take it at work, and get reliable relief that was just enough to enable me to smile and be engaged with our patients, even at the end of a 12 hour shift. The effects are about as noticeable as a strong cup of coffee (maybe two), but instead of being solely a nervous, jittery buzz, it provides a balanced sense of clarity and well-being. I've been taking kratom for nearly four years now, and have not had to escalate my usage to achieve the same effects. I've discussed it with my primary care physician, and he is thrilled that I've found something natural that alleviates my discomfort without putting me at the unnecessary risk associated with prescription pain killers. If a kratom ban were to go into effect, my quality of life would be significantly reduced without access to this safe, beneficial herb. Beyond that, I fear the quality of my care towards others would likewise be diminished--it's hard to be a truly good listener and problem-solver when all you can think about is how badly you want to sit down. With tobacco-related health care costs in the billions and ~480,000 deaths annually (CDC figures), I cannot understand why *this* harmless plant would be seen as posing an "imminent threat" to public safety. Additionally, considering the scope and severity of the current heroin/opioid epidemic, in my professional opinion it would be significantly *more* harmful to make a safe, natural alternative unavailable. I urge the decision-makers to look at the science, look at the data (not just in isolation, but as part of the bigger picture), and ask yourselves where the imminent threats to public safety TRULY lie. Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am a forty-one year-old software engineer from Austin, TX. I am a loving husband and father of one son. I am writing to express my disapproval of the DEAs intent to place kratom on the Schedule I list of controlled substances. Kratom has helped me maintain a healthy, active lifestyle, and to be a better father and a more engaged, productive professional. Criminalizing kratom would result in a huge setback for people who -- like me -- have found a way to help improve their lives in a natural way. We are harmless, and only interested in being the best parents, professionals, and humans we can be.

I discovered kratom in 2011. At the time, I was heavily medicated for depression, overweight, and had no energy to spend time playing with my four year-old son. I was falling asleep at my desk at work and struggling to be productive. I was also drinking at least several days per week. After a week of trying kratom, I had energy again. Within a month, I was playing kickball in the backyard with my son, even after a long day's work. Instead of taking naps after work while he watched TV, I was a dad again. At work, I began contributing again, and it was quite a novelty not to nod off during a meeting!

Today, my career is back on track. Im working to improve my skills as a software engineer daily (and nightly). I now work out four times a week and enjoy power lifting, and am about thirty pounds lighter than I was five years ago. My interest in/desire for alcohol has also decreased, and my alcohol intake is limited to weekends. Overall, I am a healthier and happier person. While I wouldnt make the claim that kratom has been a panacea, I can say it has been a catalyst thats driven me to make better lifestyle decisions and ultimately become a healthier person.

Please consider the thousands of us who are good, decent, tax-paying citizens. We are loyal employees, spouses, and devoted parents who simply want to be healthy. Undoubtedly, the pharmaceutical industry has -- and will continue to -- provide important and life-saving drugs. That doesnt mean that we shouldnt have the choice to seek alternative natural treatments for ourselves. We are not criminals.

Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText: My name is James Barnes, and I work at A ProLogistix Warehouse. I used to be an alcoholic. I used to be able to drink more than A fifth of 80 proof liquor in A day. I have used Kratom for almost three years. One reason I use Kratom because it takes away my urge to drink. I live A healthier lifestyle because I no longer am an alcoholic. If Kratom was no longer legal and available to me that would be very detrimental for me. Kratom isn't A drug. Kratom is an herb. Kratom should remain legal and available because it helps people with opiate and alcohol problems, and it helps people with pain, anxiety, depression, insomnia, and other ailments. Kratom isn't A drug. It's A medicinal herb. Kratom has helped me so much in my life it is miraculous. Kratom is very safe compared to over the counter drugs like acetaminophen. It is estimated that about 150 Americans die every year from overdosing on acetaminophen. Acetaminophen has A narrow safety margin from the dose that is affective, and the dose that can cause serious harm. One study even showed that overuse of acetaminophen can increase a person's risk of early death as much as 60 percent, the study authors found. Acetaminophen can cause serious liver toxicity. You can't overdose on kratom, and Kratom isn't toxic to the body. In fact Kratom has antioxidants in it that are good for you. Kratom is safe compared to over the counter drugs that A lot of think are harmless when in reality can cause fatality. When you compare Kratom to tobacco cigarettes Kratom is obviously safer. It doesn't make sense to try to ban Kratom when tobacco is legal and available, and alcohol is legal and available. Tobacco and alcohol kill hundreds of thousands of people every year in America alone. When you propose A ban to Kratom when tobacco and alcohol are legal and available it makes me question why A ban was ever proposed to ban A benign herb in the first place when alcohol and tobacco combined kill about 580000 people every year in America alone. It is only fair to hold every drug and herb to the same standard as far as legality and availability go. The reason being if you keep alcohol legal, and ban chocolate. It's unfair to consumers that we can't eat organic dark chocolate, but can drink ourselves to death. Consumers will look at A list of system of scheduled drugs in that theoretical circumstance and logically they won't accept that chocolate is A schedule one narcotic while alcohol remains legal and available. A lot of people would find laws like that unfair and might even get angry. This is no joke. Taking away people's Kratom causes suffering in the people that have pain management issues that got off of pharmaceutical opiates, and just use kratom to manage their pain. It is no joke to take Kratom away from heroin addicts that do two to three grams of heroin A day, and are trying to make big improvements in their life. It's no joke to take Kratom away from people that have severe anxiety and got off of powerful anti anxiety pharmaceutical drugs like xanax, and just use Kratom to help them manage their anxiety. It is no joke to take Kratom away from alcoholics that are in alcohol withdrawal and feel really sick. If you become very consciously aware of what taking away Kratom from those people would do to the trajectory of those people's life you wouldn't be to take away Kratom from those people without behaving selfishly. Kratom is A medicine for me and the millions of other Americans that chose to take it. Please don't make Kratom illegal and unavailable to Americans. It will only cause more societal problems. A good example of this is that States that have banned Kratom have higher opiate overdose rates then States that Don't have prohibition laws on Kratom. The drug enforcement agency has A ethical responsibility to be A benevolent force in society. Please be fair and virtuous on this important Kratom issue, and keep Kratom legal and available.

documents.commentText:
My name is Melissa. I'm 39 years old. I've been a stay at home mother for eleven years now. I have struggled on and off almost my whole life with unexplained chronic fatigue, anxiety and  depression. As I grew older and had children, I developed chronic pain and my other symptoms became much worse. My depression was labeled as "treatment resistant" because I had tried so many psych drugs that either didn't help or had intolerable side effects. For many years I complained of the same symptoms. Even checked myself into the mental health ward in a hospital for a week. Finally, I developed a large goitre on my thyroid gland along with some smaller ones. I had half of my thyroid surgically removed along with a parathyroid gland. Turns out that I have an autoimmune condition called Hashimotos disease which caused my thyroid to be attacked by my own body. I went from hyperthyroid to hypothyroid over the course of a decade at least. It went on for many years before I was diagnosed. Before, I was told that it was fibromyalgia and mental illness. My pain kept me from living a full life. I felt so much guilt as a mother and wife.  Along with it I would get a flu-like fevered feeling. It lasted for days, weeks, even months at a time. And, I had two in diapers to care for. My thyroid issues caused me emotional instability. Because there's an issue of opioid abuse in my area, doctors would not treat my pain. I ended up with stomach problems from taking ibuprofen on a daily basis. Finally, I was prescribed Valium for my anxiety. It worked very well for a few years. We moved and a different doctor switched me to xanax. I didn't think it was much different from Valium. But, I became physically dependant on xanax after taking a small amount of it for only two months! I figured that out after I decided that I wanted a break from it and I got very sick. It's dangerous to go cold turkey off of xanax. I didn't know this before because my doctor never told me. My xanax also turned toxic to me. I was sick with it but also sick without it! I suffered to the point of being bedridden and suicidal. I read about kratom from a facebook group for xanax withdrawal. I ordered a small amount and from the first day I started using it I have felt SO much better! Like I would imagine a normal, healthy human to feel! It's not a party "drug". It makes me feel better but not high. I've been able to decrease my xanax, I only take half a pill at night before bed. Sometimes I don't even take it at all. And, I'm off of my antidepressants! Kratom makes me feel more productive and energetic. I get more accomplished! I have went without kratom and didn't get any withdrawal symptoms. The only things I noticed was that I was tired and my legs ached. That was common for me even before kratom. My legs and feet were my chief complaint as far as pain. I only found kratom just six months ago. Please don't schedule it as an illicit substance! My kids need me to feel healthy! 

Sincerely, Melissa Bradley

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

My name is Steve W., and I am an office support staff at a mental health facility in California, aged in my 30s. I am writing you today to urge your organization to reconsider classifying Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug. I wish I could claim to be an expert on the topic, but I can only offer anecdotal evidence of the benefits of Kratom. I sincerely hope you will find my experiences helpful when considering how to classify Kratom. 

About five or six years ago, I was diagnosed with recurrent Major Depressive Disorder and Generalized Anxiety Disorder. However, I have felt and dealt with the symptoms that led to those diagnoses for much longer, since my mid-teenage years. After my diagnosis, I had been prescribed many antidepressants and anxiolytics (including those in the benzodiazepine family of drugs). I found very little relief from my symptoms in any of the medications I had been prescribed, and, in some cases, felt much worse due to side effects. I am disappointed to say that I gave up on trying to find a medication that helped me with my disorders. 

After some time being off of medications prescribed by a psychiatrist, I turned to self-medication through alcohol. It started off slowly, just a drink here or there to calm the nerves. Over the next several years, however, it gradually built. Soon, I found that I was unable to go more than a day without something to drink. I would get severe headaches, volatile moods, crippling anxiety, and more that would only seem to get worse without drinking. While my drinking never affected my employment (I only drank after work and on days off), my over-consumption of alcohol was at serious risk for becoming a detriment to my health and mental well-being.

My brother (who has no doubt shared his own story in these comments), told me about Kratom and how it has helped him. I decided to try to quit drinking, taking Kratom when the withdrawal symptoms became unbearable. I was surprised at just how effective Kratom was, and that I experienced no side effects. With the support of Kratom, I was able to completely quit drinking on my first attempt. I was then able to taper off my use of Kratom as the alcohol withdrawal symptoms subsided. 

I have been completely free of alcohol for some time now, and only occasionally use Kratom when the symptoms of my anxiety or depression become too distressing. Without Kratom, my battle would have been much more difficult, and I am very doubtful I would have had so much success, so easily. I find Kratom to be very effective at helping to alleviate my symptoms of depression and anxiety as well. I have never experienced side effects or any addictive effects while using Kratom. It seems safe and effective, but my only evidence for that are my own experiences. 

As I'm sure you have heard through the thousands of comments you've received, Kratom seems to have the potential to help an huge amount of people with an immense variety of ailments, addictions, disorders, and the like. Please take these cases and mine into consideration when your organization decides the fate of Kratom. It is a substance that seems to a great potential to improve the lives of many people.

Thank you for your time and consideration of our comments.

My name is Lynne Thermann. I'm a former landscaper, builder, maintenance worker and elder caregiver. I am 56 years old.
I'm very strongly opposed to the DEA's proposed prohibition of the herb kratom (Mitragyna Speciosa) under Schedule 1.
Kratom has been enormously helpful to my well being for almost three years.
I've been in chronic pain for most of my life, due to scoliosis and lordosis, two types of spinal deformity. In recent decades I've also developed fibromyalgia, arthritis, severe fatigue and migraine, with increasing pain, physical weakness and disability and attendant anxiety and depression. I've been prescribed various pain medications throughout my life and have used many different over-the-counter pain remedies in efforts to address my illnesses. I also began self-medicating very early, at age 9, due to physical pain and fatigue as well as attendant emotional discomfort.
Like many others, I first learned of kratom in online research about pain management.
Obtaining and preparing kratom successfully for the first time, without undue hardship or expense, opened up a new world for me: it gently lessened my physical and emotional discomfort; it directly assisted my overall sense of well being and helped me function more normally in my daily responsibilities. Over time, it's become clear that kratom has definitely helped my well being, assisting me in reaching a healthful balance, in tandem with nutritional and spiritual practices. I've never felt as well as I do at this time, with the help of this simple herb. 
I'm not alone in experiencing a change for the better with the help of kratom. Generations of others have felt an enormous improvement to their own well being because of this traditional herbal supplement. I see no justification whatsoever for this simple herb to be scheduled similarly to synthetic drugs like heroin and LSD. Kratom is a gift of nature and we are literally built to benefit. 
Please do not prohibit kratom!

documents.commentText: I am against the idea of making Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine a schedule I. I first discovered Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine by way of Kratom at the beginning of 2014. I have been a daily consumer a few months short of three years.  Shortly after discovering Kratom I began using it daily, it wasn't until April that I ceased all illicit drug use, including methamphetamine and opiates/opiods. I am a 26 year old father of two beautiful toddlers, I work in the Receiving Department of a factory near by. I have had this job for a little over a year, the longest I have ever held a job prior to 2014 was 6 months.  I was diagnosed with ADHD at age 10 and was medicated with various medications up until I was 15 when I began using opiates in place of the ADHD medications. In the middle of 2014 I ceased all illicit drug use cold turkey, and moved 45 minutes away with the mother of my children as we prepared to bring my daughter into this world 9 months later. I experienced very minimal withdrawal symptoms considering the high doses at which I was consuming both methamphetamine and strong opiates such as fentyl. I then decided to go back to the doctor and got prescribed medication for ADHD as well as depression and anxiety that I have suffered from undiagnosed for all of my teenage years. I then stopped using Kratom for a few months as it was no longer sold locally. After experiencing no withdrawal symptoms what so ever, I came across an online community which pointed me in the direction of online Kratom Vendors. In that short period of time, my medication no longer relieved my symptoms completely the way I thought they did. I began suffering from severe social anxiety and depression again which made me unable to follow through with any important life decisions and plans. When I began ordering Kratom online from US vendors who imported from overseas, I noticed that my social anxiety was completely released. I was confident like I was before I stopped taking it. I became very optimistic on a daily basis, I no longer had an the feeling of impending doom. I saw how I wanted my life to go, and the necessary steps needed to make it happen and I took action. No longer do I live in fear of going to Walmart and paying with a live cashier. I was so afraid before that I would stiffer or be unable to speak when ever talking to anyone outside of my imidiate family. I was no longer afraid to just be my self. I have a great sleep schedule, something I never knew existed. Throughout my teenage years and all the way up until I began Kratom and stopped using illicit drugs I had sleeping problems, my mind would race and It would take hours to fall asleep. I get sleepy and fall asleep around the same time every night now and wake up around 5am every morning with no alarm clock. Of course this could be attributed to becoming older and not being on drugs. Kratom gives me an amazing mood and energy boost, I work 8 hours a day and some days I lay carpet/tile for four hours after I get off as well as some weekends. I never get tired while working, I never lose my motivation, I constantly see my achievements and I work hard until the finish line. I can't truly put into words what Kratom has done for me and how devestated my fianc and mother will be if I lose it. This is the first time since this announcement that I have been in tears about this situation. Please, reconsider this and go about it differently. I am not opposed to some sort or regulation. Maybe 21 and older? I understand that young people do not need something like this, but I also understand that it cannot be outlawed or made only available by prescription. Please do this right, please do your research and truly think about this situation. We are in the middle of an opiate crisis for gods sake, and this is apart of the answer. I am so sure that I am willing to bet my life on it, literally. Thank you for taking the time to read my comment.

documents.commentText:
Genesis 1:29 - And God said, Behold, I have given you every herb bearing seed, which [is] upon the face of all the earth, and every tree, in the which [is] the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for meat.

Revelation 22:2 - In the midst of the street of it, and on either side of the river, [was there] the tree of life, which bare twelve [manner of] fruits, [and] yielded her fruit every month: and the leaves of the tree [were] for the healing of the nations.

Genesis 9:3 - Every moving thing that liveth shall be meat for you; even as the green herb have I given you all things.

It is a God given right to use and cultivate any and all plants that were made in Earth. Kratom is a blessing, I had been living with pain from unsolved back, and knee injuries for 12 years, until I found this plant. I spent thousands on MRI's, doctors evaluations, all with no results, and they couldn't prescribe me anything to help with the pain I live with. Well, kratom, it relieves pain when needed, and some of the anxiety that comes with it. It's not needed everyday either. It is not addictive as some claims have said, it is completely controllable, and there is a threshold of tolerance that doesn't rise. It doesn't cause hallucinations or a high, it is a mild sedative and/or energy boost and that is it. It is not much different from coffee, and in fact, quite related.

You claim there is no medicinal use, yet that is still under review, and more research can't be done if it is under Schedule 1. However, the Big Pharma companies have pending patents on the mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitraginene? They must think there is a possibility for medical use, which many would say yes to already from simple use. There is no need to take this simple plant from the public, and then turn around and try to make it a prescription 'drug'. Yes more research should be done to see how it affects the body, but in general people haven't had problems with it. It doesn't give you respiratory issues or addiction like prescription narcotics, opiods, opiates, whatever you want to call it. You also said it is an 'imminent hazard to public.' How is that?  There are no chances of overdose. It is only preferred by certain people, and is quite tame and benign.
At around '20,000' deaths a year from prescription drugs, which as we know so many people are addicted to, that is more of a hazard. Taking away kratom would put people back in pain, or worse, lead them back to prescription drugs, heroin, and alcohol abuse. That isn't liberty.
Yes, people need to take kratom responsibly, even though the worst effects would be getting nauseous. But common people naturally learn their tolerance levels and know what to take. There's always a few that maybe don't know how much they should have, and that's with anything.

You also claimed there were deaths associated with kratom. Keyword, 'associated'. That was proven false as all the suspected 14 deaths or so all were involving other drugs, narcotics, and medical issues. There is no evidence of one single death, involving kratom only. The closest to that were some I believe in Europe, but that was from kratom being laced with something extremely potent and hazardous. So again, 'associated.' Pure kratom, as long as it is pure, has no impacts of death to date and really no health hazards, unless otherwise proven by the research you should allow.
It has been used for hundreds, if not thousands of years, and even by Buddhists.

As you saw from the backlash of the first attempt to ban this plant, it is saving lives of veterans with PTSD, people with chronic pain/anxiety, and recovering heroin/pain killer/opiates/and alcohol addicts. Kratom is saving the lives of veterans who bravely fought for this country in the name of FREEDOM. Freedom to choose. There are many countries who have kept this plant accessible and you see that they don't have problems with it. It would be a violation of freedom, privacy, personal health choice, and religious beliefs if this plant were banned/scheduled.

So please keep Kratom on the market, it is not an imminent hazard, it is quite the opposite. It is saving lives, and you'll keep that miracle alive by dropping your proposed ban.
Also, it is ultimately up to the President- not the Attorney General, not the head of the DEA or anyone else, please consider all relevant information with the President of the United States.

If this hasn't been seen by the DEA please read this in depth study to date: http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524

And this: http://www.americankratom.org/press_releases

Thank you! And God Bless America.
