documents.commentText:
KRATOM- the first month.

I learned of Kratom just a month ago. I survived Guillain Barre Syndrome from which there are three chronic, disabling lingering symptoms: Chronic Fatigue, Chronic Pain, Neuropathy and muscle damage. For ten years I've hoped for a miracle and have had the rug pulled from beneath me over and over. We GBS survivors are very rare and no two patients are left in the same condition.
      I do not feel lucky.
      For a decade I've been controlled by disability and prescription drugs. I take vast amounts of opiate based pills, neurological drugs, but NO drug helps Chronic Fatigue. (Illegal or otherwise) Then a friend-an exceptional sculptor and artist in Black Mountain, NC- told me of Kratom. She sent me a small amount and I was amazed. 
      Skip ahead: I purchased a kilo and was out of bed, using only 60 mgs of morphine, for ten days in a row. This for me is astounding. Unprecedented. Prior I was able to rise about once a week. Kratom's miraculous ability to lift the fog of Fatigue feels REAL. To hell with pain (Kratom also took my pain to a zero, another first) the true miracle is being able to speak my thoughts aloud, to lift my hand. On day eleven I was up again and making grilled cheese, something I've not been able to do since August of 2005. The muscles in my legs began to shake as damaged nerves sent insane messages through my body. I felt like a marionette being manipulated by two children fighting for control. The following day-up again-my heart was pounding, my fingers quivered and twitched and I recognized the loss of control from chronic fatigue. I slept for several days and faced coffee withdrawal (Ah, to enjoy coffee every day like a real person; the sound of a grinder, the smell of the brew, the warmth and comfort down the throat) and I learned the multiple facets of this medicine along with the same respect I give to Morphine, Hydromorphone, Fentanyl. Mostly I learned how little I know about it. 
      I learned something very important about Kratom: it is TOO close to a miracle. It is not a cure but is the most remarkable symptom barrier I've tried and I've tried everything that's come my way. But Kratom makes me believe I'm well again and even with the most subtle movements (using a pencil, rising to get a drink, picking up a dropped item) it allows me to abuse myself; to push my body farther than I should and can.
        I cut back, spent a day in bed. Somewhere between the past twelve days and the last ten years lies an answer. But it will take me months, perhaps years, to find the balance-the very carefully measured doses at the precise time, how to balance with pharmaceuticals, food, sleep, action. The key to living with chronic illness is to listen to the body, a  skill requiring re-learning based on your "before and after" moment. Kratom deafens the voice of your body, something that can be dangerous, as made clear by my rising twelve days in a row. Additionally, those around you, who have hoped as much as you for a miracle, begin to expect more from you and our nature is to not disappoint them. We carry guilt for having become so sick in the first place. This is additional pressure to push ourselves. But how do we stop at a wall that we cannot see or feel until it is too late?
      I'm writing this long and personal account to educate you all on the effects of Kratom which, like GBS, affects us all differently. I received some brief instructions from the members of this group. My package arrived with ginger candy, which was very sweet. Yet I've never had nausea from Kratom. I suspect I've adapted as I was taking 40mgs of Dilaudid a day and got accustomed to chewing ginger root. But it has now been 15 days since I took Dilaudid. 
      Kratom IS a miracle but SOME organization needs to study and research it, collect data such as I've provided, and do an equitable job in dispensing instructions. We all need to respect the power of this plant or the DEA and the FDA will take control and then license it to Big Pharma who will restrict it and then multiply the price by 100,000%.  (60 tablets of morphine costs me $197 a month, for example.) Ever person who distributes it must responsibly include  instructions and warnings so that when fighting these agencies we appear more knowledgable than gardeners, botanists, and common street dealers. I will do all I can to help; my own research continues and I shall continue to let you all know what works for me. Our collective experience creates a highly important and respectable dissertation. 
By David Seaman

Okay, so, seriously? Let me get this straight. You assholes allow monolithic pharmaceutical conglomerates to get thousands nightmarishly hooked on boundlessly terrible chemicals like buprenorphine and methadone (which, it's no secret, are far more addictive and equally as damaging to the brain and body as the illegal drugs which they're a supposed alternative/treatment to.) yet for a whole cornucopia of dumbass reasons, plan to outlaw fucking kratom?? For real? The only real reason I've seen is the amount of calls to poison control centers regarding kratom. While you're at it, make household cleaners, cough suppressants, caffeine, and motrin illegal too. Actually, wait: don't. Don't make any of these things illegal because it's a fucking stupid idea. Even more ludicrous than the prospect of prohibition. 
Kratom is a far more superior alternative to the two accepted substances I've listed above, because it doesn't get the user intoxicated or negatively euphoric, nor does it have an equivalently high likelihood of killing those who consume it. Oh, and, big, BIG benefit here: it's not satanically addictive! You don't have any idea what it's like to come off of methadone compared to heroin or oxycodone. I do. I've been there. I'm one of the type of people whose lives you'll be fucking up with your totalitarian bullshit. It takes a grueling two or three weeks to finish the acute detox of methadone or subutex. Heroin lasts five days, at most a week, and then it's over. You know how it's okay to be prescribed methadone or subutex to detox off of opiates? I've taken it maybe three out of the dozens of times I've detoxed, preferring to go cold turkey. Why? Because I don't want to prolong my horrid plight by taking those evil goddamn pharmaceuticals.  
Kratom, on the other hand, does not do what methadone and subutex do. It's a natural and non-opiate method of overcoming the excruciating detox symptoms of opiate addiction. Just like Iboga, only it's a little less radical, so you people should be okay with it. But you're not. Because you have no idea what you're doing.

If imports coming into America from other countries are KILLING our citizens how can we sit back and continue to let them into our country? We are so worried about attacks on America and out citizens being killed by outside countries, but the biggest threat to our people is the regulations in this country not looking out for the citizens best interest.  It's too late for my big brother and the pain this has caused my family is unbearable.   There is nothing I can ever do to make my family whole again but i will fight to have this substance along with other harmful substances banned from being imported into our great country so that no sister has to lose her brother and no parent has to lose their son. My brother's drive and charisma has gone to waste, but he was a very special man and i know that he is working with us to stop this horrible injustice.

-Elaina Moradi

documents.commentText:
Hello,
My name is Sara. I am 30 years old and work in solar array inspections. I am writing to oppose the DEA's proposal to put kratom on the list of Schedule 1 controlled substances. 
I have used kratom casually to help curb stress since 2012. I particularly used it to help calm myself while I was quitting smoking cigarettes, along with other herbs such as raspberry leaf and valerian. I have not smoked a cigarette since early 2012, after five years of addiction. I also particularly used kratom when going to the dentist for a series of oral surgeries that gave me extreme anxiety. Kratom helped calm my fear of the dentist, in fact the dentist remarked on how calm I seemed.
I believe that kratom should absolutely remain available because although I am prone to addiction ( I was previously addicted to cigarettes), I have never developed an addiction to kratom in almost five years of casual use. The effects of kratom are noticeable but not incapacitating in any way. There is very little evidence to support an argument that kratom is being abused in the way of recreational drugs, and in fact I believe it is helping a lot of people with opioid addictions to wean themselves off that horrible burden. While I myself have never abused opioids, I have one friend who said he was effectively using kratom to remain sober from them. In the age of an opioid epidemic, I think scheduling kratom would cause loss of life from addicts who depend on it to remain free from opioids.
Kratom is the type of herbal remedy we should want people of the United States to use to address their problems, not powerful pharmaceuticals that have a direct path to injectible street drugs. I think kratom is a boon to public health and I hope the DEA can see this as well.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

My name is Ashley Smith, wife and mother of two beautiful and bright boys. I discovered Kratom  about two years ago while I was seeking an alternative to the highly addictive and dangerous opioid medications that my Dr. had prescribed to me for my lower back pain. I used the prescribed narcotics for 3 years and they worked ok for a while, then they stopped working as well so I started taking more, this led me down a path of dependence and addiction on the drug. Luckily I was able to break away from using the opioid medication by slowly switching and adding Kratom tea to my diet. I now am free from using the narcotic medications.  Narcotics had several adverse effects on me including nausea, drowsiness, and respiratory depression and I never felt safe using it. I have found that Kratom does not cause any adverse effects for me. I am a full time nursing student and I maintain an A average. I am a contributing member of my community and society as a whole. I have found that kratom tea does not give me the addictive and dependence feelings like the narcotics, but relieves my lower back pain so that I may function in my daily life. I feel that Kratom is not a drug, but a dietary supplement. I am opposed to the DEAs proposal to make the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, two constituents of the kratom plant, schedule 1 controlled substances. This would negatively affect my lifestyle and that of many others. Narcotics are dangerous and kill thousands of Americans a year. More research needs to be done on Kratom before we decide that it has no medical use.

documents.commentText:
I'm Aaron. I run a dog-sitting business out of my home and am also an artist. I'm 30 and have a bone disease called Fibrous Dysplasia. I have broken my femur upwards of 25 times in 30 years. I have had insanely major surgeries that have, in the past, led to me taking high doses of extremely potent opioids. I was physically and psychologically addicted to oxycodone, hydromorphone, hydrocodone, and even tramadol. I had two major surgeries in 2014. I have had around 10 total in my lifetime. The first in 2014 was a double osteotomy. The doctors broke my femur in two places, removed metal rods and screws, straightened my deformed femur, then put new metal in to support it. After the surgery, the doctors moved me to a post-op bed and when they did, one of the rods slipped through my bone and nestled underneath my knee cap. I had to have a 2nd double osteotomy 12 weeks later. Needless to say, I was on opioids for about 8 months. I weened myself down and got completely off of them for almost 8 months when I hurt my leg again and a rod slipped through my upper hip. I NEVER wanted to go through opioid withdrawal again, so instead of taking what the doctor prescribed, I looked into Kratom. I have taken Kratom off and on since then. It is NOT addictive, and the only side effect I get is similar to coffee/caffeine. I take it on average about 3 times a week when my leg is hurting badly. And I don't take it two days in a row.

Kratom has helped me to not take overly powerful prescription opioids when in pain due to a bone disease. The anguish these opioids cause when you try to stop taking them is indescribable. Kratom has helped the pain level to go down with very few side effects and every day life has improved dramatically in my work and relationships. I do not take Kratom daily. I only take it when necessary, and it has done wonders in a world where too many people are overprescribed very powerful narcotics. Please keep these amazing, helpful constituents legal. It's natural and it's safe, as we know with past studies that it does not cause respiratory depression like real opioids. More studies can be done and it can help millions of people around this world like it has helped me.

I am a 59 year old male, I work as a purchasing manager for a laboratory equipment re-selling business.  I am emphatically opposed to the DEA intent to place Kratom as a schedule 1 substance.  I have been taking Kratom daily as a dietary supplement for about a year and have seen it to be a valuable assist to my health and well-being.  I have not experienced any noticeable or dangerous side effects.  Before I began taking it, I did extensive research on the internet to see if taking the Kratom powder (but not the extracts) at reasonable and sensible doses might pose a danger to me.  I found in the vast majority of cases people were reporting beneficial effects in several areas of their physical and mental health.  I strongly believe the Mitragyna Speciosa plant powder should remain freely available and that education is the most sensible way to inform the public of  any possible adverse effects, and that criminalizing this substance would have very negative consequences for the many thousands of people in our country that use this regularly to help with their well-being and their ability to lead productive, useful lives.

Sincerely,
Samuel Schlufen

documents.commentText:
This ban would really hurt the United States in a number of ways. 
The two most prominent effects of this ban that you are going to notice if it goes through are a large jump in deaths around the country and a surge in the amount of money the country is losing by paying for people to be in prison. 

- Many people will die because so many of the kratom users in the USA are using it to not be addicted to pain medication and opioids. Let me be clear; this is helping people not become addicted to illegal AND LEGAL medication and drugs. A lot of people get over prescribed pain medication in particular. As I am sure you are aware, their is a huge problem with opioid use in this country right now. A great deal of that, and arguably a majority of those with an opioid problem, comes from this over prescription. Giving a construction worker with back pain 3 Vicodin per day for 3 months is basically starting a new gateway drug. 
People in every facet of the United States use kratom. The New York Times even showed this when your ban was first proposed and going into effect the first time. Doctors, people labor-intensive jobs like construction, lawyers, people in the military... someone in every sector of the USA uses kratom to their benefit and successfully contributes to this country. Take that away and you will have deaths all over the place from all of these people needing to help their anxiety or relieve their pain and not having a non-addictive and totally affordable source to help. They will go for things like heroin and oxycodone and drugs that are dirtier and scarier. This will happen within months, if not weeks.

- With this being a big possibility and probability, many people with saner heads will go the other route and try to get kratom illegally. They will get caught and go to prison for something that they have already been doing for years without causing and harm and actually helping the country function better. Now all of our money will be put more towards feeding and clothing these people for years.

Please do not go through with this ban. It will simply add to the already pressing issues the United States faces. Kratom is not the battle right now. And even though it should never be the battle, at least take some time to test what you want to ban first. 

Thank you for reading.

documents.commentText:
My name is Regina Lupo. I'm 51 years old. I have one grown son and I own and operate a daycare center. 
16 years ago I was diagnosed with 2 types of arthritis. Due to the chronic pain I was prescribed many different medications. Before long I was also diagnosed with depression and anxiety coming from my pain and poor quality of life. 
Within 2 years from being diagnosed with the arthritis I found myself in the middle of a horrible addiction from all of the prescription drugs I had been prescribed. I couldn't work anymore and was absent from my family and friends. By December 2012 I had no desire to live. I was just waiting to die. 
One day about 4 years ago I was searching YouTube for videos on natural remedies and came across a video on Kratom. The man on the video had many of the same ailments that I had and was getting great relief from taking the herb Kratom. I placed an order for it. I didn't hold out much hope but at that point in my life I figured I had nothing to lose. 
After starting on Kratom within 3 months I had tapered myself off of all prescription drugs. My quality of life started to improve by leaps and bounds! My pain was under control better than any of the prescription drugs had allowed. My depression and anxiety were a thing of the past.
I have been back to work full time for 3 years now. My family and friends have me back also. 
It was that easy and that amazing. The only regret I have is that I hadn't discovered Kratom sooner. 
When I went online this past August 31st and read about the DEA's intent to place Kratom on a schedule I drug list I felt shock and fear, then the tears came. I knew without Kratom my life would go back to being intolerable. I knew I would rather die than going back to that miserable existence. I pray every day that Kratom will remain legal so that people like me can continue to benefit from it. 
Illness and prescription drugs took away my life,  Kratom has helped me to get back my life!  PLEASE KEEP KRATOM LEGAL. 

Sincerely,
Regina Lupo

documents.commentText:
Hello, my name is Jacob. I am 23 years old and I struggled with drug addiction since I was 15. About a year ago I got sober and was having a lot of pain in my lower back from two vertebrae turning in opposite directions. I used to be in acrobatics but I had a couple surgeries that left me unable to get the exercise my back needs to stay upright. So now I have almost constant pain. The pain makes me depressed and I'm afraid to see a doctor because they always want money and I can't afford it. 

I discovered kratom a few years ago when I was smoking weed and I bought some kratom for my mom at a headshop. My mother is a recovering addict and takes suboxoine for her opiate replacement therapy. She would run out of her prescription often and so she tried this and it worked so well that she used it along with suboxoine. 

There are too many victims of pain out there that would suffer from a ban of this proportion. To many mothers in pain that have lives that need to be lived pain free in order to properly care for their children. Taking away that pain is the only thing keeping some people from killing themselves because of their depression is to much for them to bare. 

The war on drugs and the current scheduling system is broken and scientifically incorrect. 
How about actually making only harmful substances illegal? Most of the U.S population doesn't take your scheduling thing seriously because it's a joke. Cannabis, LSD, Psilocybin and many other substances in your schedule 1 list are completely NON-TOXIC. So why is Acetaminophen and Ibuprofen legal? It kills more people each year than any of the schedule 1 substances I've just mentioned. So who's controlling the DEA? Because something is very wrong with this system. It's an outright lie and at least three-quarters of the country knows it. So come out of the closet.

Every twelve year old in the United States knows that cannabis isn't dangerous. Yet the scheduling system says otherwise? It's an outdated piece of political injustice. Please allow for the safe use herbal, plant-based medication. Wake up DEA. Plants are like people. You can't make people illegal. Well actually you can. But that's it doesn't usually work. Because you are killing more people by not telling them the truth. Keep hard drugs out of the hands of our youth by regulating safe substances like cannabis and psilocybin. There are so many medicinal benefits that science has yet to discover! With laws like these you'll hold civilization back a thousand years!!! 

Anyway thank you to whoever is reading this for hearing our words.

Peace + Love

documents.commentText:
I am a 39-year-old medical social worker, and I am writing this as a follow-up to my comment (that was mostly an attachment due to length) of the proposed kratom ban from a medical social work perspective. 

In this prior comment, I had mentioned that an unintended consequence of a kratom ban would likely be that people who are currently working would become unable to work, exiting the workforce and then applying for disability benefits.  I decided to explore this further, and based upon my research, it appears that banning kratom could cost billions more in disability payouts and could have a massive economic impact insofar as moving people out of the workforce.

I recently conducted three surveys with kratom consumers.  The first survey asked how many people currently consuming kratom were working.  In a sample of 699 respondents, 69% stated they were working.  With an estimated 4 million kratom consumers in the United States, this means that there are up to approximately 3 million people currently in the workforce who consume kratom.  

The second survey asked that of those kratom consumers currently working (approximately 3 million) how many of them realistically believed that if kratom were banned and they could no longer consume kratom that they would then become unable to work and would be forced to apply for disability.  In a sample of 242 respondents, 32% responded that they did indeed feel this way.  That means that approximately up to 1 million  people would be out of the workforce and applying for disability if a kratom ban were to be enacted.  Of course, not all of these applicants will be awarded disability benefits, many will get denied.   According to the Social Security Administration, approximately 30% of those who apply for disability benefits end up being awarded said benefits  https://www.ssa.gov/OACT/STATS/dibStat.html   This means that approximately 300,000  people would receive disability benefits because a kratom ban.  In dollar amounts, this would cost approximately $4 billion annually in increased disability payouts.  This is a significant amount of money!


The third and final survey I conducted asked current kratom consumers how many of them had once been on disability but then were able to join or rejoin the workforce after they found kratom.  In a sample of 38 respondents, 18% stated that kratom had made them go from being disabled to being able to work!  This is also very significant.  As previously mentioned, the government does not award disability benefits easily.  In fact, of those who apply, about 70% get rejected.  The criteria for being considered disabled and completely unable to work, thus requiring the government financial support is very stringent.  So, for people who actually met the criteria for being disabled and were awarded disability benefits, it is remarkable that kratom made them able to work again!  


This is even more reason that banning kratom makes for terrible public policy.  This plant has been shown to keep people in the workforce.  An unnecessary loss of nearly a million workers and an unnecessary expense of almost $4 billion in disability payouts is economic insanity.  Even with all issues of civil liberties, government intrusion and loss of quality of life aside, it appears that a kratom ban would be significantly detrimental to the economy.

documents.commentText:
My spouse is diagnosed with a chronic condition called complex regional pain syndrome or RSD. She suffered this condition due to nerve damage from a broken ankle. She sees a pain management specialist who not only prescribes narcotic but non narcotic prescriptions to help with the feeling of constant pain and burning in her legs. After doing research and looking for an alternative to the narcotic prescriptions that could be addicting and only provided temporary relief we wanted a natural solution to help her deal with her pain. 
We discovered Kratom and she got the results of pain relief without the awful side effects of prescription narcotics. The facts on Kratom are pretty clear that it is not harmful, nearly impossible to abuse as a person would vomit before they could take too much and not addictive like narcotics. That is why I was surprised that the DEA wanted to schedule I ingredients in a fast track motion. There has not been one death attributed to Kratom overdose. The DEA wants to focus on reducing prescription drug abuse yet banning Kratom will only drive the millions of people using a natural pain relief to once again rely solely on the same prescription narcotics that are killing thousands of Americans a year. This does not make sense to ban an alternative that could help solve the prescription drug abuse epidemic in the United States.  
I believe that Kratom should remain legal not only so that my wife does not lose a natural way to deal with her chronic pain but also to be studied to fully understand the benefits that this plant can provide. 
I believe that as alternative to banning Kratom the FDA could help to regulate and standardize it as it does with similar supplements and vitamins. 
I implore the DEA to please look at the facts about Kratom to see that there is no reason to regulate a safe and effective supplement. The purpose of the Schedule I list is to protect the general public from harmful substances. Kratom is not a substance that is damaging or dangerous to the general population of the United States and does not belong on the Schedule I list.

documents.commentText:
IF A MAN WANTS TO KEEP WORKING BUT SUFFERS FROM PAIN


There are not many options left for the man that lives in pain.
You take whatever it takes to keep moving; then keep moving. You cannot afford to miss work. So, you dont. This is where the problem lies if one is taking opiates. Three weeks of horrible pain and your tolerance is built up. Then to start your day requires abnormal amounts of drugs. . 
    I want to get the treatment for my pain that is the reason for the pain clinic I was going to. The system is so broken that I cannot get the care I need or deserve.
    I have found a plant that helps me almost as much with my pain and I am able to function much better.  
I may not be able to continue the course of action I have chosen because the plant I use to control my pain is called Kratom. It is much less destructive to me than taking opiates. A hell of a lot safer for me than trying to kill the pain with alcohol. Does alcohol work? Yes, but it does not leave me functional in the least. Have I taken too much Kratom? Yes, I got very sick to my stomach. That was it!
     Does this plant help with pain? I know it helps my pain. I chose to try it because I read over and over again, of people just like me (IN PAIN) and they claimed it helped them. Does it kill all of the pain? No, but neither do the prescription meds. Does it help me function? Yes! I have become a very independant person thanks to being able to kill my pain enough to work and to even play a little.
   Ive had several problems with my back and shoulders.  My arm/shoulder now hurts so bad I can barely sleep some nights. I cannot reach straight out in front of me and pick up a coffee cup. It hurts months on end. If I try to do any tree work using a hand saw I am in unbearable  pain.  I also have DDD and even sciatic nerve pain from time to time. I have had cluster headaches since I was 4 or 5. I broke my skull when I was 7. Life long allergies; allergy shots for over a decade of my childhood. Rheumatic fever when I was ten.
      I worked climbing, trimming and removing trees for 25 years. I served my country for 3 years, Airborne! I have 2 children that are grown and productive individuals. I have accomplished much in my life and have a lot of life left. At times my headaches were so frequent that I did not want to live any longer. Think, major brain freeze that lasts for two to three hours with someone stabbing an ice pick into one of your eyeballs and you come close to what a cluster headache is. The last cycle ended around 2001 and every now and then I feel a twinge like one may be coming on, but Thank God they have not yet. They will be back one day.
        LIving in pain is DEATH. It completely rewires the brain. You cannot do anything you want to do. It is not a life.
    Do I still have pain? Yes. Can I function? Yes.  But not because of anything the broken system has done to help me. I had to search for a way to survive. I have found it and have a life as close to normal as one can have working nights and doing physical labor with a bad back and neck.  Just as my life is getting back to normal after nearly a year of school and I have made a plan to just deal with things on my own and use the money for something useful instead of throwing it away on useless insurance. I cannot afford the cost of insurance and then co-pays. The specialist and pain clinics are not affordable, I tried. The broken system is USELESS.
    I plead with the powers that be to keep this useful Godsend of a plant legal and allow the research to be done on it. By all means restrict the sale of it to keep it away from minors and insure the purity of the product but dont change it. Please do not make it illegal. It is very helpful for my pain. I do not want to die from pain medication. Pain medication is never prescribed in dosages that will allow you to live. If you do not get enough of it, you cannot function and if you get enough of it then the end of it is death. Pain management needs every way it can be given to work. This plant called Kratom helps me live. Over the last 4 years I have found a much better way to help with my pain and to be able to function in society. I want to work and be productive. I want to live.


Thank you

documents.commentText: Please do not ban this plant. I was severely addicted to every kind of opiate pill on the market, including black market heroin. I found salvation in this leaf when I needed it the most. I was heading down the path of death. I searched and searched for a way to get clean. Methadone and Suboxone are NOT the answer to addiction, those substances make addiction worse in my opinion. When I finally found out about kratom, and tried it, I was blown away how well it took my withdrawal symptoms away. After that I never looked back. Kratom got me off of pills within a couple months, with no out patient program or spending more money at the doctors office.  Taking this plant away from people who need it would be the worst thing my government could do. It's something a dictatorship would do, it will not help anybody. I've met hundreds of people who have used this plant for a number of different reasons, I don't know anybody who uses it recreationally. I just plead with you to listen to your heart and help thousands of Americans with chronic pain, anxiety, depression, and for people like me who are just looking for a way out of an opioid hell hole. Thanks for taking your time to read this.

documents.commentText:
I'm writing to declare my opposition to any scheduling of Kratom.  I have been drinking Kratom tea with some regularity for the past couple years and have not experienced any adverse effects.  I use the tea as a replacement for coffee most days as I find that it provides me with energy like caffeine but without increasing my anxiety.  Scheduling the plant would be a detriment to my quality of life and I am unaware of any benefit that would be gained from the scheduling.

That said, I recognize that there should be limits to anecdotal experience in determining policy.  However, as I mentioned, I am not aware of any compelling evidence or arguments in favor of scheduling.  If the DEA is still considering scheduling, I would ask them to first answer these questions:

Have studies been conducted on the effects of Kratom?  If so, have those studies shown Kratom to be harmful?  Have any studies conducted shown that there are benefits to using Kratom?  Is there reported evidence of Kratom being harmful to anyone?  I am aware that a number of emergency room visits have been connected to Kratom, but were the patients in those cases determined to be suffering from a health problem?  If so, was Kratom found to be the cause of those problems or were other factors likely responsible?  I have heard reports that there have been deaths in connection to Kratom.  In any of those cases, was Kratom found to be the cause of death, a factor in the cause of death, or merely present at the time of death?  Is there any evidence of other social ills in connection to Kratom or has Kratom use been found to cause any other crimes?  If it is the case that Kratom has not been found to lead to harm in any of the previous questions, does the DEA have other evidence that Kratom is either harmful or that scheduling it would produce any benefit on society?  If not, would the DEA still intend to schedule Kratom?  If so, what would be the reasons for the DEA's intent to schedule?

Thank you for considering these comments.  I look forward to an receiving an answer to my questions.

documents.commentText: I am an average middle aged man who wanted to get an occasional performance and cognitive focus boost in my off-time. I work as a database administrator and am told I do a good job by my superiors, but I sometimes find myself mentally fatigued after work and I wanted a way to make more consistent progress toward my own personal goals. I discovered kratom and I feel very strongly that it has allowed me to become a more productive person. If kratom was banned, I would certainly be less productive in my downtime. For me, losing access to kratom would not be the end of the world, but I feel I would finish projects less often. Specifically, kratom has helped me overcome writer's block and push through to finishing many musical arrangements and animated art. I use kratom occasionally: once or twice a month at most. I have never felt any adverse effects and I have never felt any sense of addiction.

documents.commentText:
I have never used Kratom, because I have been fortunate enough to not need it. That said, I would like to address the person reviewing this comment at the DEA -- the one who has some amount of power to influence how this process proceeds. As a fellow American citizen and, more importantly, as a fellow human, I have a question for you: why, in this great country of ours, are we in a position where people are required to submit repeated pleas to a federal agency in order to stop that agency from encroaching on the right to freedom, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness? (In the instance of Kratom, "the pursuit of happiness" can logically be inverted to mean "the avoidance of pain.")

Please take a moment to think about what this country stands for, and whether or not the decision you influence today falls in line with what we stand for. You are an individual working in the government, and you have the power to act from your individual conscience. The people using Kratom make a choice to use it because they weigh their options, just like you. Let them continue that right.

documents.commentText: Three years ago I sustained a serious back injury while at work, at the time I was only 24 years old. For the last three years doctors have tried over 9 different procedures, 3 surgeries. Nothing worked, I am too young for a safe spinal fusion, so my Dr proscribed me 110 mg of oxycontin a day and said this is your life now. I started taking Kratom a week ago, I was able to immediately stop oxy with very minimal withdraw. Even more amazing is my lack of pain. I have been given my life back. When I was on the oxy it was not enough to keep me pain free, I was still couch bound and truly disabled. So far with kratom I was able to shop for and cook an entire thanksgiving dinner by myself. I am not confined to the couch, I don't need my father and boyfriend to wait on me and nurse me. I have lost too much of my youth to pain and pain pills. Kratom allows me to walk and stand up without assistance, I can do basic household chores, I don't have to limit my showers because standing hurts. No 27 year old should live like I was living prior to Kratom. The thing I am most excited about if Kratom remains legal is getting back into the work force.
